events.title: Huck's Desperate Attempt to Offload His Fortune
detailed_summary: Reacting immediately to the discovery of his father's tracks, Huck flees downhill, constantly checking over his shoulder.
He arrives breathless at Judge Thatcher's house.
Judge Thatcher initially assumes Huck is there for his interest money, noting a recent deposit of over one hundred and fifty dollars.
Huck urgently states he doesn't want the interest or his principal sum of six thousand dollars and insists on giving it all to the Judge.
The Judge is taken aback and confused by Huck's request.
Huck pleads with the Judge to accept the money without asking questions, explaining that this would prevent him from having to lie.
Judge Thatcher, after some thought, reinterprets Huck's offer as a sale, drafting a document stating he has "bought" the property for a consideration of one dollar.
Huck signs the paper and departs.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was up in a second and shinning down the hill.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I signed it, and left.

events.text_segment:
I was up in a second and shinning down the hill. I looked over my shoulder every now and then, but I didn’t see nobody. I was at Judge Thatcher’s as quick as I could get there. He said:
“Why, my boy, you are all out of breath. Did you come for your interest?”
“No, sir,” I says; “is there some for me?”
“Oh, yes, a half-yearly is in, last night—over a hundred and fifty dollars. Quite a fortune for you. You had better let me invest it along with your six thousand, because if you take it you’ll spend it.”
“No, sir,” I says, “I don’t want to spend it. I don’t want it at all—nor the six thousand, nuther. I want you to take it; I want to give it to you—the six thousand and all.”
He looked surprised. He couldn’t seem to make it out. He says:
“Why, what can you mean, my boy?”
I says, “Don’t you ask me no questions about it, please. You’ll take it—won’t you?”
He says:
“Well, I’m puzzled. Is something the matter?”
“Please take it,” says I, “and don’t ask me nothing—then I won’t have to tell no lies.”
He studied a while, and then he says:
“Oho-o! I think I see. You want to sell all your property to me—not give it. That’s the correct idea.”
Then he wrote something on a paper and read it over, and says:
“There; you see it says ‘for a consideration.’ That means I have bought it of you and paid you for it. Here’s a dollar for you. Now you sign it.”
So I signed it, and left.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I was up in a second and shinning down the hill. I was not expected at Judge Thatcher's; nothing ever is when you are hankering and hurrying all you can to get there. I had to wait at the gate for some minutes, spreading news, and before I got in I had promised to tell it all over again the way it happened the minute I got inside. I laid it all out to Judge Thatcher, and Huck Finn he see it just like the rest. Then I told him about father and what happened. I didn't offer to tell him all about how pap come to be back there, because I didn't know myself, and besides, anyway, it warn't no matter now. So I told him all about seeing the tracks and about the cross in the left boot-heel and so on, and then I says:

"Come, Judge Thatcher! I want to give you all my money!"

He looked at me in astonishment. He couldn't seem to make it out; said he couldn't understand what I meant. I says:

"Why, Judge, I want to give it all to you—the six thousand dollars that pap hain't touched yet. I want to give it all to you to keep for me." It would all be his, as I was explaining, if he would take it—I didn't want more than a dollar of it. But he couldn't seem to understand no way. He says:

"Why, Huck, at the rate you're going you're going to be the richest boy in the county when you're a man. Everybody says it. And Judge Thatcher he'll be proud to handle it for you and keep it all right and safe."

"Oh, please take it!" says I. "I don't want it; please take it!"

He says:

"Well, he'll take care of it. Don't you trouble your head about that."

"Yes, but I do trouble my head about it. I ain't comfortable about it. Please take it and don't ask me nothing—then I won't have to tell no lies." He studied a while, and then he says:

"Oho! I think I see. You want to SELL it."

"Yes," says I, "I do. I want to sell it because I think he's coming back this time."

"All right. Then we'll fix it all right. I will buy it. I will buy it, and I will give you a dollar and some other property for it—and then you can't swear that you've got any money. I will give you a dollar, and you can make your six thousand dollars some other time; and—" He stopped a minute and looked at me pretty thoughtful. Then he says: "Looky here, Huck, what makes you want to sell it?"

I couldn't answer no way. I only said:

"Please take it, Judge—please do. Don't ask me questions."

He said: "Well, I won't ask no questions. You come right along with me." So he lit a candle and went into the parlor, and got out a pen and ink and a paper, and set down to write. But he couldn't write for a little bit, because the candle flittered so much, and his hands trembled. He says:

"Why, what's the matter with you, Huck? You look all of a sudden got scary."

"It ain't nothing, Judge. It's just a—a—" I didn't know what to say. "Take it and don't ask me no questions, Judge."

He said: "All right; I won't. Go ahead." So I took the pen and held my breath and shut my eyes, and cramped the words out the best I could, and he took it for his'n. Then we went out.

"All right. Then we'll fix it all right. I will buy it. I will buy it, and I will give you a dollar and some other property for it—and then you can't swear that you've got any money. I will give you a dollar, and you can make your six thousand dollars some other time; and—" He stopped a minute and looked at me pretty thoughtful. Then he says: "Looky here, Huck, what makes you want to sell it?"

I couldn't answer no way. I only said:

"Please take it, Judge—please do. Don't ask me questions."

He said: "Well, I won't ask no questions. You come right along with me." So he lit a candle and went into the parlor, and got out a pen and ink and a paper, and set down to write. But he couldn't write for a little bit, because the candle flittered so much, and his hands trembled. He says:

"Why, what's the matter with you, Huck? You look all of a sudden got scary."

"It ain't nothing, Judge. It's just a—a—" I didn't know what to say. "Take it and don't ask me no questions, Judge."

He said: "All right; I won't. Go ahead." So I took the pen and held my breath and shut my eyes, and cramped the words out the best I could, and he took it for his'n. Then we went out.

events.title: Seeking Answers from Jim's Magical Hair-Ball
detailed_summary: Huck recalls that Jim, owned by Miss Watson, possesses a magical hair-ball taken from an ox's stomach, believed to contain an omniscient spirit.
That night, Huck visits Jim, convinced his Pap has returned due to the tracks he found.
Huck wants to know Pap's intentions: what he plans to do and whether he will stay.
Jim attempts to consult the hair-ball by speaking to it and dropping it, but it remains unresponsive.
Jim explains that the hair-ball sometimes requires payment to speak.
Huck offers an old, obviously counterfeit quarter, admitting its poor quality but hoping the hair-ball might not notice, keeping the dollar from Judge Thatcher a secret.
Jim, after inspecting the coin, devises a plan to make it appear legitimate by embedding it in a raw Irish potato overnight, a method Huck recognizes but had forgotten.

events.text_segment: Miss Watson’s nigger, Jim, had a hair-ball as big as your fist, which had been took out of the fourth stomach of an ox, and he used to do magic with it. He said there was a spirit inside of it, and it knowed everything. So I went to him that night and told him pap was here again, for I found his tracks in the snow. What I wanted to know was, what he was going to do, and was he going to stay? Jim got out his hair-ball and said something over it, and then he held it up and dropped it on the floor. It fell pretty solid, and only rolled about an inch. Jim tried it again, and then another time, and it acted just the same. Jim got down on his knees, and put his ear against it and listened. But it warn’t no use; he said it wouldn’t talk. He said sometimes it wouldn’t talk without money. I told him I had an old slick counterfeit quarter that warn’t no good because the brass showed through the silver a little, and it wouldn’t pass nohow, even if the brass didn’t show, because it was so slick it felt greasy, and so that would tell on it every time. (I reckoned I wouldn’t say nothing about the dollar I got from the judge.) I said it was pretty bad money, but maybe the hair-ball would take it, because maybe it wouldn’t know the difference. Jim smelt it and bit it and rubbed it, and said he would manage so the hair-ball would think it was good. He said he would split open a raw Irish potato and stick the quarter in between and keep it there all night, and next morning you couldn’t see no brass, and it wouldn’t feel greasy no more, and so anybody in town would take it in a minute, let alone a hair-ball. Well, I knowed a potato would do that before, but I had forgot it.

events.title: The Hair-Ball's Prophecy and Pap's Ominous Return
detailed_summary: After placing the counterfeit quarter under the hair-ball, Jim listens again and reports that the hair-ball is now willing to speak.
Jim relays the hair-ball's prophecy to Huck.
Regarding Pap, the hair-ball reveals he is undecided about staying or leaving, influenced by two opposing "angels," one white and one black, making his ultimate actions unpredictable.
For Huck, the hair-ball predicts a life with considerable trouble and joy, periods of sickness and injury followed by recovery.
It also foresees two significant women in Huck's life, one light-haired and one dark-haired, one rich and one poor, with Huck marrying the poor one first and then the rich one.
Crucially, the hair-ball warns Huck to avoid water and risks, as it foresees he is destined to be hanged.
Later that night, upon entering his room, Huck finds his father, Pap, waiting for him.

events.text_segment:
Jim put the quarter under the hair-ball, and got down and listened again. This time he said the hair-ball was all right. He said it would tell my whole fortune if I wanted it to. I says, go on. So the hair-ball talked to Jim, and Jim told it to me. He says:
“Yo’ ole father doan’ know yit what he’s a-gwyne to do. Sometimes he spec he’ll go ’way, en den agin he spec he’ll stay. De bes’ way is to res’ easy en let de ole man take his own way. Dey’s two angels hoverin’ roun’ ’bout him. One uv ’em is white en shiny, en t’other one is black. De white one gits him to go right a little while, den de black one sail in en bust it all up. A body can’t tell yit which one gwyne to fetch him at de las’. But you is all right. You gwyne to have considable trouble in yo’ life, en considable joy. Sometimes you gwyne to git hurt, en sometimes you gwyne to git sick; but every time you’s gwyne to git well agin. Dey’s two gals flyin’ ’bout you in yo’ life. One uv ’em’s light en t’other one is dark. One is rich en t’other is po’. You’s gwyne to marry de po’ one fust en de rich one by en by. You wants to keep ’way fum de water as much as you kin, en don’t run no resk, ’kase it’s down in de bills dat you’s gwyne to git hung.”
When I lit my candle and went up to my room that night there sat pap his own self!

events.title: Pap's Unexpected Return and Wretched Appearance
detailed_summary: Huck encounters his father, Pap, unexpectedly in his room after closing the door.
Despite an initial jolt of surprise, Huck quickly realizes he is no longer as afraid of Pap as he once was.
Pap is depicted as around fifty years old, with long, tangled, greasy black hair that partially obscures his eyes, and equally unkempt black whiskers.
His face is described as having an unnatural, sickly white color, compared to that of a tree-toad or a fish-belly.
His attire consists merely of rags.
He is observed sitting with one ankle on the other knee, revealing a damaged boot through which two of his toes protrude, and which he occasionally moves.
His old black slouch hat, misshapen with a caved-in top, lies on the floor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had shut the door to.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His hat was laying on the floor—an old black slouch with the top caved in, like a lid.

events.text_segment:
I had shut the door to. Then I turned around and there he was. I used to be scared of him all the time, he tanned me so much. I reckoned I was scared now, too; but in a minute I see I was mistaken—that is, after the first jolt, as you may say, when my breath sort of hitched, he being so unexpected; but right away after I see I warn’t scared of him worth bothring about.
He was most fifty, and he looked it. His hair was long and tangled and greasy, and hung down, and you could see his eyes shining through like he was behind vines. It was all black, no gray; so was his long, mixed-up whiskers. There warn’t no color in his face, where his face showed; it was white; not like another man’s white, but a white to make a body sick, a white to make a body’s flesh crawl—a tree-toad white, a fish-belly white. As for his clothes—just rags, that was all. He had one ankle resting on t’other knee; the boot on that foot was busted, and two of his toes stuck through, and he worked them now and then. His hat was laying on the floor—an old black slouch with the top caved in, like a lid.

They look like they’d been in the river a month. That was his natural color. He was all in rags, and dirty and lousy. One of his knees caved in and his rags hung down around it like it was empty; and his hat was laying on the floor—an old black slouch with the top caved in, too. I stood a-looking at him; he set there a-looking at me, with his chair tilted back against the wall, and his arms crossed on his breast, and them long, greasy kind of hair hanging down over his eyes, and he most looked like he was asleep, but he wasn’t; he was only thinking. I stood there a good while, and he never said nothing. But at last he sighed a long sigh and says: “Looky here—ain’t you a sweet-scented dandy, though! A-sailing around in silk clothes, and rings, and that sort of trash; and lording it around over your old father, and never thinking of him.”

events.title: Pap Condemns Huck's Education and 'Frills'
detailed_summary: Huck and Pap observe each other; Huck deduces Pap entered through an open window via the shed.
Pap initiates the conversation by mocking Huck's refined clothing and accusing him of acting superior.
Huck's noncommittal response angers Pap, who criticizes Huck's adopted 'frills' and newfound education.
Pap expresses strong resentment that Huck can read and write while he cannot, and vows to humble him.
He demands to know who permitted Huck to engage in such 'hifalut’n foolishness'.
Huck identifies the Widow Douglas as the one who encouraged his education.
Pap reacts angrily towards the Widow for her interference and orders Huck to cease attending school immediately.
He asserts that he will not tolerate his son acting superior, emphasizing that neither Huck's mother nor other family members possessed literacy.
Pap then commands Huck to demonstrate his reading ability.
Huck reads a passage about General Washington for a short period.
Pap violently knocks the book out of Huck's hand, acknowledging Huck's literacy but reiterating his disapproval of Huck's 'frills' and threatening physical punishment if Huck continues school.
Pap expresses concern that Huck might also 'get religion,' further showing his displeasure.
He discovers a small picture Huck received as a school reward for good lessons.
Upon learning its origin, Pap tears the picture up, sarcastically offering a 'cowhide' as a better reward.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I stood a-looking at him; he set there a-looking at me, with his chair tilted back a little.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He tore it up, and says: “I’ll give you something better—I’ll give you a cowhide.”

events.text_segment:
I stood a-looking at him; he set there a-looking at me, with his chair tilted back a little. I set the candle down. I noticed the window was up; so he had clumb in by the shed. He kept a-looking me all over. By-and-by he says:
“Starchy clothes—very. You think you’re a good deal of a big-bug, don’t you?”
“Maybe I am, maybe I ain’t,” I says.
“Don’t you give me none o’ your lip,” says he. “You’ve put on considerable many frills since I been away. I’ll take you down a peg before I get done with you. You’re educated, too, they say—can read and write. You think you’re better’n your father, now, don’t you, because he can’t? I’ll take it out of you. Who told you you might meddle with such hifalut’n foolishness, hey?—who told you you could?”
“The widow. She told me.”
“The widow, hey?—and who told the widow she could put in her shovel about a thing that ain’t none of her business?”
“Nobody never told her.”
“Well, I’ll learn her how to meddle. And looky here—you drop that school, you hear? I’ll learn people to bring up a boy to put on airs over his own father and let on to be better’n what he is. You lemme catch you fooling around that school again, you hear? Your mother couldn’t read, and she couldn’t write, nuther, before she died. None of the family couldn’t before they died. I can’t; and here you’re a-swelling yourself up like this. I ain’t the man to stand it—you hear? Say, lemme hear you read.”
I took up a book and begun something about General Washington and the wars. When I’d read about a half a minute, he fetched the book a whack with his hand and knocked it across the house. He says:
“It’s so. You can do it. I had my doubts when you told me. Now looky here; you stop that putting on frills. I won’t have it. I’ll lay for you, my smarty; and if I catch you about that school I’ll tan you good. First you know you’ll get religion, too. I never see such a son.”
He took up a little blue and yaller picture of some cows and a boy, and says:
“What’s this?”
“It’s something they give me for learning my lessons good.”
He tore it up, and says:
“I’ll give you something better—I’ll give you a cowhide.”

“Don’t you give me none o’ your lip,” says he. “You’ve put on considerable many frills since I been away. I’ll take you down a peg before I get done with you. You’re educated, too, they say—can read and write. You think you’re better’n your father, now, don’t you? I’ll show you whether you’re better’n your father or not. You bring them books and clothes here, and I’ll soon straighten you up.”
Well, I wouldn’t say nothing. I was feeling pretty comfortable all down one side, since I got money enough to suit me. I says to myself, all right, that’s comfortable enough. I don’t want no more. So I sat there thinking. Pap he waited a while, then he says, kinder mild:
“Looky here, Huck, who wuz it that told you you couldn’t have no money?”
“Nobody told me so, pap, but the judge. He said he reckoned you’d get it sooner or later. I didn’t tell him nothing about the six thousand dollars. I hain’t told nobody.”
“Well,” says he, “that’s lucky, because I’ll take it. I’ll take it all. And I’ll take it now.”
He got up and went to the door and looked out; then he come back and said he hadn’t seen a nigger for two days. He said if he could see one he would borrow ten cents off of him and get drunk. He said he hadn’t had a drink for two days, and it was driving him crazy. He said he didn’t know what he was going to do. He said he reckoned he would have to go and get drunk anyway, and he didn’t care how he got the money. He said he would steal it if he had to. He said he was going to have a drink, and he didn’t care what happened.
He sat down again and looked at me. He says:
“What’s that you got on?”
“It’s new clothes, pap.”
“New clothes! You ain’t got no business to have new clothes. They’re too good for you. You ain’t nothing but a poor, miserable, wuthless boy. You ain’t got no business to be putting on no frills. I’ll take them clothes off of you and sell ’em. I’ll take that six thousand dollars and invest it for you. I’ll invest it in whisky. I’ll invest it in rum. I’ll invest it in beer. I’ll invest it in gin. I’ll invest it in anything that’s wet. I’ll invest it in anything that’ll make me drunk. I’ll invest it in anything that’ll make me forget that I’m a poor, miserable, wuthless boy.”

“The widow, hey? And who told the widow she could tell you?”
“Nobody told her, pap. She told me herself.”

events.title: Pap's Resentment Over Huck's Comfort and Demand for Money
detailed_summary: Pap continues his tirade, contrasting Huck's comfortable living conditions—bed, bedclothes, mirror, carpet—with his own degraded state of sleeping with hogs.
He reiterates his intent to strip Huck of his 'airs' and mentions rumors of Huck possessing wealth.
Huck denies having money, calling the claims false.
Pap warns Huck about his disrespectful tone, stating he has heard extensively about Huck's riches and that this news prompted his return.
He demands Huck provide him with the money by the following day.
Huck insists he has no money and suggests Pap ask Judge Thatcher, who Pap believes holds the money.
Pap declares he will confront Judge Thatcher and compel him to release the funds.
He then demands whatever cash Huck currently has on him.
Huck admits to having only a dollar, which he needs for himself.
Pap dismisses Huck's needs and forces him to surrender the dollar.
After testing the coin's authenticity by biting it, Pap announces his plan to go to town for whiskey, claiming he hasn't had a drink all day.
While leaving through the shed, Pap returns to curse Huck for his perceived pretensions and attempts to be superior.
Just as Huck believes Pap has departed, Pap reappears one last time to sternly warn Huck against attending school, threatening a beating if he disobeys.

events.text_segment:
He set there a-mumbling and a-growling a minute, and then he says:
“Ain’t you a sweet-scented dandy, though? A bed; and bedclothes; and a look’n’-glass; and a piece of carpet on the floor—and your own father got to sleep with the hogs in the tanyard. I never see such a son. I bet I’ll take some o’ these frills out o’ you before I’m done with you. Why, there ain’t no end to your airs—they say you’re rich. Hey?—how’s that?”
“They lie—that’s how.”
“Looky here—mind how you talk to me; I’m a-standing about all I can stand now—so don’t gimme no sass. I’ve been in town two days, and I hain’t heard nothing but about you bein’ rich. I heard about it away down the river, too. That’s why I come. You git me that money to-morrow—I want it.”
“I hain’t got no money.”
“It’s a lie. Judge Thatcher’s got it. You git it. I want it.”
“I hain’t got no money, I tell you. You ask Judge Thatcher; he’ll tell you the same.”
“All right. I’ll ask him; and I’ll make him pungle, too, or I’ll know the reason why. Say, how much you got in your pocket? I want it.”
“I hain’t got only a dollar, and I want that to—”
“It don’t make no difference what you want it for—you just shell it out.”
He took it and bit it to see if it was good, and then he said he was going down town to get some whisky; said he hadn’t had a drink all day. When he had got out on the shed he put his head in again, and cussed me for putting on frills and trying to be better than him; and when I reckoned he was gone he come back and put his head in again, and told me to mind about that school, because he was going to lay for me and lick me if I didn’t drop that.

He set there a-mumbling and a-growling a minute, and then he says: “Ain’t you a sweet-scented dandy, though? A bed; and clothes; and a lookin’-glass; and a piece of carpet on the floor—and your own father got to sleep with the hogs in the tanyard. I’ve a good notion to take and lick you till you swaller it; yes, I will. You’re puttin’ on considerable many frills since I been away. I’ll take you down a peg before I get done with you. You’re educated, too, they say; can read and write. You think you’re better than your father, now, don’t you? I’ll show you whether you are or not. You’ve put on considerable style—considerable—ever since that school started. I know what you’ve been doing—you been getting into low-down crowds and strowing around.”

He got to growling again. Then he says:

“Ain’t you rich?”

“No,” says I, “I ain’t rich.”

“You lie! I know you got six thousand dollars. It’s divvied up amongst ‘em. Pap Sawyer he knows all about it. It’s a put-up thing for you to swaller it whole and kill the snakes. I run across him in the woods, and you can’t come it over me with no frauds. I can spot a fraud when I see one, and I know this ain’t no slouch of a fraud. Well, I’ll learn you grave and serious things. I’ll learn you how to kowtow to your superiors, and be humble with your betters, and clever with your equals, and pleasant with all. Yes, and you’ll live like other people, too, when I get hold of you. You ain’t a-going to school. YOU hear? I’m his father, and I’ll make him come here. They shan’t touch him. He’s my property. events.title: Legal Battles Over Custody and Pap's Continued Misbehavior
detailed_summary: The next day, Pap, intoxicated, confronts Judge Thatcher to demand Huck's money but fails; he then threatens to use the law to get it.
Judge Thatcher and the Widow Douglas initiate legal action to gain guardianship of Huck.
However, a new judge, unfamiliar with Pap's character, rules against separating the family, believing courts should not interfere in such matters if avoidable.
This outcome forces Judge Thatcher and the Widow to abandon their attempt.
Pap is delighted by the ruling and threatens to severely beat Huck if he doesn't provide money.
Huck borrows three dollars from Judge Thatcher, which Pap promptly takes.
Pap gets drunk with the money and causes a public disturbance throughout the town with a tin pan until late at night.
Authorities arrest Pap and jail him; he appears in court the next day and is jailed for another week.
Despite his incarceration, Pap expresses satisfaction, asserting his authority over Huck and his intent to make Huck's life difficult.

events.text_segment:
Next day he was drunk, and he went to Judge Thatcher’s and bullyragged him, and tried to make him give up the money; but he couldn’t, and then he swore he’d make the law force him.
The judge and the widow went to law to get the court to take me away from him and let one of them be my guardian; but it was a new judge that had just come, and he didn’t know the old man; so he said courts mustn’t interfere and separate families if they could help it; said he’d druther not take a child away from its father. So Judge Thatcher and the widow had to quit on the business.
That pleased the old man till he couldn’t rest. He said he’d cowhide me till I was black and blue if I didn’t raise some money for him. I borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher, and pap took it and got drunk, and went a-blowing around and cussing and whooping and carrying on; and he kept it up all over town, with a tin pan, till most midnight; then they jailed him, and next day they had him before court, and jailed him again for a week. But he said he was satisfied; said he was boss of his son, and he’d make it warm for him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Next day he was drunk, and he went to Judge Thatcher’s and bullyragged him, and tried to make him give up the money; but he couldn’t, and then he swore he’d make the law force him. He said he would lay over in town and wait, and if I didn’t get the money according to his idea he’d lick me to death. He said no nigger would come a-prowling around after him, and it wouldn’t do for me to be letting on to be better than what he was. He said he was satisfied I was putting on airs over him and siding with everybody that said he warn’t no account. He said she got at me and kinder worked me. He said he would learn her and me both who was boss. He said he hadn’t see a nigger with a collar on, in his life, and he didn’t believe he ever would. So he rousted me out and says:

“You march straight down to the judge and tell him he’s got to give you that money. Mind. Now you do as I tell you. Go along.”

I went up home and told the Widow about it, and she said the judge done right; said she wouldn’t let no runaway nigger get hold of that money as long as she lived. Then she said, “Set down, Huck, and I’ll read you something.” She read considerable to me out of a book, and I didn’t care for it nohow, and she noticed it, and shut it up and says:

“Don’t you worry, honey. You shall have it all your own way after a while, and you will like it better.”

I judged she would be disappointed, but I didn’t say nothing. I thought till I wore my head sore, but I couldn’t see no way out of the trouble. The judge and the widow they went to law to get the court to appoint them my guardians; but it proved a very troublesome job and slow, and they couldn’t get it done that day. The next day they found they couldn’t get it all done under two or three days. About this time Pap turned up again. The minute he was drunk he was over the river agin. That was always his way. He used to tell me I hadn’t no right to the things which I got off of the river. Said that river all belonged to him. Lots of times he used to lay drunk five days at a time in the woods, back of our house, with his rags on, and his whiskers stuck together with beer froth and tobacco juice, and look the wofullest you ever see. Well, this time he was a good deal soberer. He had been drunk over in Illinois, and had staid there three days in the grand jury room, all by himself, and said he hadn’t ever enjoyed himself so much in his life—but the judge he had to tell him he couldn’t stay there all the time, and Pap said he could so if he wanted to. Said if a man couldn’t get drunk and raise Cain in a free country there was no use for a government. They were going to give him six months, but some new judge come along and didn’t know the old man’s ways, and the new judge he said he reckoned he’d send him over to the poorhouse. And that was what they done. They had him there a couple of days, and then he turned up again. Nobody seemed to want him around, and there warn’t no place for him. So they had to let him go to his own devices.

Once I asked him why he didn’t go to school: he said it warn’t no use, because he knowed as much already as any body could learn out of books, and that he was going to lick me if I didn’t drop that. I see the witches was at him again. “No,” says he, “I’ve seen considerable trouble in my life, but I never see nothing that fetched up as big an uproar and racket and insurrecktion as what a school does. Why, hain’t your grandpap a member of the state legislature? and you a-going to such school, you ought to be ashamed of yourself. It ain’

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He said he’d lay for him, and watch his chance. He said it was his money, and nobody else’s. He said Judge Thatcher was a thief and a robber, and he would make him give it up or he would know the reason why. He went on like that for a while, cussing and swearing, and then he came back to the widow’s. He was madder than ever. He saw me all dressed up in my new clothes, and he just went wild. He grabbed me and cussed me for putting on airs and trying to be better than my own father. He said he wouldn’t have it.

events.title: The New Judge's Attempt to Reform Pap
detailed_summary: Upon Pap's release, the new judge undertakes an effort to reform him.
The judge invites Pap into his home, provides him with clean clothes, and includes him in family meals.
After supper, the judge speaks with Pap about temperance and moral improvement.
Pap feigns remorse, crying and admitting he has been foolish and wasted his life.
He dramatically declares his intention to 'turn over a new leaf' and become a man no one would be ashamed of, seeking the judge's support.
The judge and his wife are visibly moved by Pap's apparent contrition and shed tears.
Pap claims he has always been misunderstood, a statement the judge affirms he believes.
Pap philosophizes that sympathy is what a man in his position needs, and the judge concurs, leading to more emotional displays.
At bedtime, Pap makes a show of holding out his hand, proclaiming its transformation from the 'hand of a hog' to that of a man committed to a new life, vowing to die before regressing.
He implores everyone to witness his change and shake his 'clean' hand.
The attendees, including the judge and his wife, all shake his hand emotionally; the judge's wife even kisses it.
Pap then signs a temperance pledge by making his mark.
The judge remarks that it is the 'holiest time on record' or a similar sentiment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When he got out the new judge said he was a-going to make a man of him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The judge said it was the holiest time on record, or something like that.

events.text_segment:
When he got out the new judge said he was a-going to make a man of him. So he took him to his own house, and dressed him up clean and nice, and had him to breakfast and dinner and supper with the family, and was just old pie to him, so to speak. And after supper he talked to him about temperance and such things till the old man cried, and said he’d been a fool, and fooled away his life; but now he was a-going to turn over a new leaf and be a man nobody wouldn’t be ashamed of, and he hoped the judge would help him and not look down on him. The judge said he could hug him for them words; so he cried, and his wife she cried again; pap said he’d been a man that had always been misunderstood before, and the judge said he believed it. The old man said that what a man wanted that was down was sympathy, and the judge said it was so; so they cried again. And when it was bedtime the old man rose up and held out his hand, and says:
“Look at it, gentlemen and ladies all; take a-hold of it; shake it. There’s a hand that was the hand of a hog; but it ain’t so no more; it’s the hand of a man that’s started in on a new life, and’ll die before he’ll go back. You mark them words—don’t forget I said them. It’s a clean hand now; shake it—don’t be afeard.”
So they shook it, one after the other, all around, and cried. The judge’s wife she kissed it. Then the old man he signed a pledge—made his mark. The judge said it was the holiest time on record, or something like that.

He said he reckoned a body could reform the old man with kindness. That he'd never had no chance before. So he set up with him all night, talking to him and trying to interest him in religion; but he got drunk before he went to bed, and said he wouldn't sober up for no account. events.title: Pap's Swift Relapse and the Judge's Disillusionment
detailed_summary: Pap is settled into the judge's spare room for the night.
Overcome by thirst, he secretly climbs out of his room onto the porch roof, slides down a support post, and trades his new coat for a jug of strong whiskey.
He returns to the room and indulges in the alcohol.
Towards dawn, Pap, severely intoxicated, crawls out again, falls off the porch, and breaks his left arm in two places.
He is discovered after sunrise, nearly frozen to death.
The spare room is left in such a state of utter chaos that it is humorously described as requiring 'soundings' to be navigated.
The judge feels disheartened by this outcome.
He concludes that reforming Pap might only be possible with extreme measures, like a shotgun, admitting he knows of no other way.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then they tucked the old man into a beautiful room, which was the spare room, and in the night some time he got powerful thirsty and clumb out on to the porch-roof and slid down a stanchion and traded his new coat for a jug of forty-rod, and clumb back again and had a good old time; and towards daylight he crawled out again, drunk as a fiddler, and rolled off the porch and broke his left arm in two places, and was most froze to death when somebody found him after sun-up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He said he reckoned a body could reform the old man with a shotgun, maybe, but he didn’t know no other way.

events.text_segment:
Then they tucked the old man into a beautiful room, which was the spare room, and in the night some time he got powerful thirsty and clumb out on to the porch-roof and slid down a stanchion and traded his new coat for a jug of forty-rod, and clumb back again and had a good old time; and towards daylight he crawled out again, drunk as a fiddler, and rolled off the porch and broke his left arm in two places, and was most froze to death when somebody found him after sun-up. And when they come to look at that spare room they had to take soundings before they could navigate it.
The judge he felt kind of sore. He said he reckoned a body could reform the old man with a shotgun, maybe, but he didn’t know no other way.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Then they tucked the old man into a beautiful room, which was the spare room, and in the night some time he got powerful thirsty and clumb out on to the porch-roof and slid down a stanchion and traded his new coat for a jug of forty-rod, and clumb back again and had a good old time; and towards daylight he crawled out again, drunk as a fiddler, and rolled off the porch and broke his left arm in two places, and was most froze to death when somebody found him after sun-up. And when they went in to see, the room it was the fearfulest sight. All the furniture busted up and stove up, and his clothes all on the floor and tore to rags, and flour and meal all over the place, and aquantity of blood. Well, they cleaned him up and took care of him, and he got well pretty soon. But he sold the calico and other things, and got drunk again, and his six dollars was gone. And so his trouble begun again—and mine. The judge he felt kind of discouraged about the old man, said he reckoned a body could reform the old man with a shotgun, maybe, but he didn't know no other way.

events.title: Pap's Return and Huck's Defiance
detailed_summary: Pap, having recovered his health, initiated legal proceedings against Judge Thatcher to gain control of Huck's money and also confronted Huck for his continued school attendance.
Huck persisted in going to school, partly as an act of defiance against Pap, though he endured physical abuse from him on a couple of occasions, managing to evade him most of the time.
Huck's motivation for school shifted from disinterest to a desire to spite his father.
The legal battle over the money was progressing very slowly.
To avoid beatings, Huck would occasionally borrow small sums of money from Judge Thatcher to give to Pap.
Whenever Pap received money, he would invariably get drunk, cause disturbances around town, and subsequently end up in jail, a lifestyle that seemed to fit his character.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, pretty soon the old man was up and around again, and then he went for Judge Thatcher in the courts to make him give up that money, and he went for me, too, for not stopping school.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was just suited—this kind of thing was right in his line.

events.text_segment: Well, pretty soon the old man was up and around again, and then he went for Judge Thatcher in the courts to make him give up that money, and he went for me, too, for not stopping school. He catched me a couple of times and thrashed me, but I went to school just the same, and dodged him or outrun him most of the time. I didn’t want to go to school much before, but I reckoned I’d go now to spite pap. That law trial was a slow business—appeared like they warn’t ever going to get started on it; so every now and then I’d borrow two or three dollars off of the judge for him, to keep from getting a cowhiding. Every time he got money he got drunk; and every time he got drunk he raised Cain around town; and every time he raised Cain he got jailed. He was just suited—this kind of thing was right in his line.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, pretty soon the old man was up and around again, and then he went for Judge Thatcher in the courts to make him give up that money, and he went for me, too, for not stopping school. He said he wouldn't stand it. Said he'd druther see the alligators git me than to see me at school. He said it warn't no use to try to learn me anything; nor work, either. He said he'd lay for me all the time, and whop me. Said he would rot if I ever went to school any more. He was as good as his word. He got to drinking again, and lots of times he came home drunk at night and raised Cain. Sometimes he'd lay whop me all over the place with a hickory stick. He used to lay for me and tanned me most every day. I stood it for a while, but at last I couldn't stand it no more. I used to go to school all the time, and I liked it a good deal. I begun to learn to cipher and some other things. Well, I let Pap alone, and after that I went to school a little through the time when I was getting whupped. He was always grumbling and saying he wouldn't have it so. He said that if I kept on that way he'd take me down to the river and drown me. He said he would if I didn't quit. He was bound to get hold of my money. He got into a lawsuit with Judge Thatcher and did his level best to get it; but he couldn't. The law was against him. He didn't mind the law, and he didn't mind what the people said; but he did mind the Judge. Judge Thatcher he was a man that had a good deal of sense, and he was a good man. He told Pap he'd see him in the poorhouse before he'd let him have any of that money. So Pap he went off mad, and swore he'd get the money yet. He went to drinking worse than ever. He was drunk all the time, and he was abusive. He'd come home and raise Cain, and he'd beat me. I was afraid to stay home with him. I'd sneak out and go up to the widow's. She was good to me. She'd give me supper and a bed. I was getting to like the widow and her ways, and I was getting to like the school and the teacher. I was getting to be a civilized boy. But Pap he hated it. He said he wouldn't have it so. He said he'd take me away. He said he'd take me down the river and make a man of me. He said he'd learn me how to live in the woods and how to hunt and fish. He said he'd learn me how to be a man. He said he wouldn't have me sivilized. He said he'd take me away from the widow and the school and the teacher. He said he'd take me away from everybody and everything. He said he'd take me away and make a man of me. He said he would. Well, I was getting to like the widow and her ways, and I was getting to like the school and the teacher. I was getting to be a civilized boy. But Pap he hated it. He said he wouldn't have it so. He said he'd take me away and make a man of me. He said he would. Well, I was getting to like the widow and her ways, and I was getting to like the school and the teacher. I was getting to be a civilized boy

events.title: Pap Abducts Huck to a Secluded Cabin
detailed_summary: Pap's persistent loitering at the Widow Douglas's residence prompted her to warn him that she would take action if he didn't stop.
Infuriated by this, Pap declared his intention to assert his parental authority over Huck.
One day in spring, Pap found an opportunity to seize Huck.

He then transported Huck approximately three miles upriver by skiff, crossing to the Illinois side where he took him to an isolated, dilapidated log cabin situated in a densely wooded area, difficult to locate without prior knowledge.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He got to hanging around the widow’s too much and so she told him at last that if he didn’t quit using around there she would make trouble for him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So he watched out for me one day in the spring, and catched me, and took me up the river about three mile in a skiff, and crossed over to the Illinois shore where it was woody and there warn’t no houses but an old log hut in a place where the timber was so thick you couldn’t find it if you didn’t know where it was.

events.text_segment: He got to hanging around the widow’s too much and so she told him at last that if he didn’t quit using around there she would make trouble for him. Well, wasn’t he mad? He said he would show who was Huck Finn’s boss. So he watched out for me one day in the spring, and catched me, and took me up the river about three mile in a skiff, and crossed over to the Illinois shore where it was woody and there warn’t no houses but an old log hut in a place where the timber was so thick you couldn’t find it if you didn’t know where it was.

```python
# Simulated output of the generate_literary_segment function
```

```python
He got to hanging around the widow’s too much and so she told him at last that if he didn’t quit using around there she would make trouble for him. Well, that settled him. He was always bragging about what a hard lot he was, and what he’d do when he got hold of me. He said he’d lay for me and lick me if I didn’t drop school. He said he wouldn’t allow no son of his to put on airs.

So the old man he got to hanging around the widow’s back yard and one day he caught me. He took me up the river about three mile, in a skiff, and crossed over to the Illinois shore, and landed in a little open place among the thick woods. We two strolled along, and got to a little old cabin in a clear place that was out of sight from the river, though you could hear the steamboats cough every little while away off there in the day time. This was a deserted cabin, and hadn’t been lived in for many a year.
"""
```

events.title: Life in Captivity and Huck's Adaptation to the Wild
detailed_summary: Pap ensured Huck remained with him constantly, preventing any opportunity for escape by locking the cabin door and keeping the key under his pillow at night.
They sustained themselves through fishing and hunting, using a gun Pap had likely stolen.
Periodically, Pap would lock Huck inside the cabin and travel three miles to a store or ferry, trading their catch for whiskey.
Upon returning with the whiskey, Pap would get drunk, enjoy himself, and physically abuse Huck.
The Widow Douglas eventually discovered Huck's whereabouts and sent a man to retrieve him, but Pap brandished his gun and drove the man away.
Over time, Huck grew accustomed to his captive situation and began to prefer the lifestyle, except for the physical abuse.
He found the lazy, comfortable days of smoking and fishing, free from books and formal education, appealing.

After about two months, with his clothes reduced to rags and covered in dirt, Huck reflected on how he had come to dislike the structured life at the widow's, which involved washing, eating at a table, grooming, regular sleep schedules, constant academic pressure, and the persistent criticism of Miss Watson.
He no longer desired to return to that life and resumed swearing, as Pap had no objections, unlike the widow.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He kept me with him all the time, and I never got a chance to run off.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was pretty good times up in the woods there, take it all around.

events.text_segment:
He kept me with him all the time, and I never got a chance to run off. We lived in that old cabin, and he always locked the door and put the key under his head nights. He had a gun which he had stole, I reckon, and we fished and hunted, and that was what we lived on. Every little while he locked me in and went down to the store, three miles, to the ferry, and traded fish and game for whisky, and fetched it home and got drunk and had a good time, and licked me. The widow she found out where I was by-and-by, and she sent a man over to try to get hold of me; but pap drove him off with the gun, and it warn’t long after that till I was used to being where I was, and liked it—all but the cowhide part.
It was kind of lazy and jolly, laying off comfortable all day, smoking and fishing, and no books nor study. Two months or more run along, and my clothes got to be all rags and dirt, and I didn’t see how I’d ever got to like it so well at the widow’s, where you had to wash, and eat on a plate, and comb up, and go to bed and get up regular, and be forever bothering over a book, and have old Miss Watson pecking at you all the time. I didn’t want to go back no more. I had stopped cussing, because the widow didn’t like it; but now I took to it again because pap hadn’t no objections. It was pretty good times up in the woods there, take it all around.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He kept me with him all the time, and I never got a chance to run off. We lived in that old cabin, and he fetched water from the creek, and good wood from the island. We had bacon, and corn-meal, and molasses—and now and then fish, and game. Pap always took the gun with him when he went over to the store. He always locked the door and fetched the key. It was a comfortable enough life, after a fashion. The only trouble was, when he got drunk—which he did about once in three days, and not long after he got the money he got drunk; and then he was restless, and i'nconvenient. He don't drink near as much, now. He used to when he was younger. Well, he'd rave, and rip, and cuss, and swear, and fetch me around very lively. I'd jump out of the way and dodge him the best I could. In the daytime, he'd sleep. He'd sleep right along, and not stir. We lived in that old cabin, and he fetched water from the creek, and good wood from the island. We had bacon, and corn-meal, and molasses—and now and then fish, and game. events.title: Escalating Abuse and Huck's Escape Plan
detailed_summary: Pap's use of a hickory switch for beatings became excessively frequent, leaving Huck covered in welts and finding the abuse unbearable.
Pap also began leaving Huck locked in the cabin more often and for longer periods.
On one occasion, Pap left Huck locked in for three days, causing Huck immense loneliness and fear, leading him to believe Pap might have drowned and he would never be freed.
This experience solidified Huck's determination to escape.

Despite numerous prior unsuccessful attempts to find a way out of the cabin—the windows were too small, the chimney too narrow, and the door made of thick oak slabs, with Pap carefully removing any potential tools—Huck finally made a discovery.
He found an old, rusty wood-saw without a handle, hidden between a rafter and the roof's clapboards.
Huck lubricated the saw and began to work, concealing his efforts behind an old horse-blanket nailed to the cabin wall to block drafts.
He started sawing through a section of the large bottom log, aiming to create an opening large enough for him to pass through.
He was close to finishing this lengthy task when he heard the sound of Pap's gun in the nearby woods.
Huck quickly concealed all evidence of his work, lowered the blanket, hid the saw, and prepared for Pap's arrival.

events.text_segment: But by-and-by pap got too handy with his hick’ry, and I couldn’t stand it. I was all over welts. He got to going away so much, too, and locking me in. Once he locked me in and was gone three days. It was dreadful lonesome. I judged he had got drownded, and I wasn’t ever going to get out any more. I was scared. I made up my mind I would fix up some way to leave there. I had tried to get out of that cabin many a time, but I couldn’t find no way. There warn’t a window to it big enough for a dog to get through. I couldn’t get up the chimbly; it was too narrow. The door was thick, solid oak slabs. Pap was pretty careful not to leave a knife or anything in the cabin when he was away; I reckon I had hunted the place over as much as a hundred times; well, I was most all the time at it, because it was about the only way to put in the time. But this time I found something at last; I found an old rusty wood-saw without any handle; it was laid in between a rafter and the clapboards of the roof. I greased it up and went to work. There was an old horse-blanket nailed against the logs at the far end of the cabin behind the table, to keep the wind from blowing through the chinks and putting the candle out. I got under the table and raised the blanket, and went to work to saw a section of the big bottom log out—big enough to let me through. Well, it was a good long job, but I was getting towards the end of it when I heard pap’s gun in the woods. I got rid of the signs of my work, and dropped the blanket and hid my saw, and pretty soon pap come in.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But by-and-by pap got too handy with his hick’ry, and I couldn’t stand it. I was all over welts. He got to drinking again, and going to the shanty, and staying all day and part of the night, and coming home drunk, and raising Cain. Sometimes he’d lay whacking at me up stairs for as much as an hour, and I was glad when it was over and I could sleep. Well, then, pretty soon he took to whole days to himself, and me alone. By-and-by he took to three days straight running, and me alone. There was lots of wood, and plenty of meat and meal, and so forth, and he locked the door and went off every time; so he saw I couldn’t get away. There warn’t no windows big enough to get through, and the chimney it was too narrow. So the case got to be pretty desperate. By this time I was all wore out, I was all down-hearted and scared, and pining for the river. I set down a while, crying; then I thought I would try for some way to get out with the saw, but there warn’t no saw; but I struck on a new idee. I took the old creel, and got it full of rocks, and put it behind the door to barricade it, and I got all the traps in the house, and stacked them around the fireplace, and piled them on the bed, and all sorts of things; and then I opened the door and stood ready to whack pap’s head off when he come. But he didn’t come. I waited and waited. I waited an hour, and two hours, it begun to get dark. It rained, and it rained, and it rained; but he didn’t come. I was getting desperate. I was afeard he was drowned; and if he was, I reckoned I was drowned too, for she warn’t going to come back any more, I reckoned. So I laid down on the bed and cried. I cried in my sleep. When I woke up it was dark. I was cold, and hungry, and scared. I got up and felt around in the dark for the saw. I remembered I had seen one back of the rafter when I was up there last. I felt all around, and I found it. It was an old rusty wood-saw, without any handle—just the blade. I was so glad I could a cried. I got it, and went to work. I began to saw the log next to the ground. I sawed and sawed till I was all tired out. I was afeard I would be catched, so I stopped and hid the saw, and went to bed. When I woke up it was day. I was sore all over, and I was hungry. I got up and went to work again. I sawed and sawed till I was all tired out. I was afeard I would be catched, so I stopped and hid the saw, and went to bed. events.title: Pap's Return, Angry Rant Against the Government and a Free Black Man
detailed_summary: Pap returned in his typical ill-tempered state, complaining about the lack of progress in his lawsuit for Huck's money, which his lawyer believed he would win if it ever went to trial, but noted that Judge Thatcher knew how to cause delays.
He also mentioned that people anticipated another trial aimed at removing Huck from his custody and appointing the widow as Huck's guardian, a trial they expected the widow to win this time.
This news greatly disturbed Huck, as he had no desire to return to the widow's restrictive and 'sivilized' lifestyle.

Pap then began an extensive, profanity-filled diatribe, cursing everyone and everything imaginable, repeating his curses to ensure no one was missed, and concluding with a general curse for unnamed individuals.
He defiantly stated he would prevent the widow from getting Huck, threatening to hide him in a remote location if necessary.
This renewed Huck's unease, though only briefly, as he resolved not to be around when Pap might act on this threat.

Pap instructed Huck to retrieve supplies from the skiff, which included a large sack of corn meal, bacon, ammunition, a four-gallon jug of whiskey, an old book, two newspapers for wadding, and some tow.

While resting after carrying a load, Huck solidified his escape plan: he would take the gun and some fishing lines and flee into the woods, constantly moving, mostly at night, hunting and fishing for sustenance, until he was too far for Pap or the widow to find him.
He decided he would try to saw his way out and leave that very night if Pap became sufficiently intoxicated, which he expected.
As Huck cooked supper, Pap took a few drinks, became agitated, and resumed his tirade, appearing disheveled after being drunk in town and sleeping in a gutter.
Pap, typically targeting the government when drunk, began his critique by questioning its legitimacy.
He railed against laws that would allow a man's son to be taken away just when the son was old enough to work and support his father.

He accused the law of siding with Judge Thatcher to keep him from his 'property' (Huck's money), reducing a man supposedly worth six thousand dollars to living in a dilapidated cabin and wearing rags.
He recounted telling Judge Thatcher he would leave the country for a pittance.

Pap's rant intensified as he described encountering a free black man from Ohio, light-skinned, well-dressed with a fine hat, gold watch, and silver-headed cane, who was a college professor, knew multiple languages, and, most offensively to Pap, could vote in his home state.
This revelation led Pap to declare he would never vote again and to express disgust at the man's demeanor, claiming he had to physically push him aside on the road.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Pap warn’t in a good humor—so he was his natural self.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And to see the cool way of that nigger—why, he wouldn’t a give me the road if I hadn’t shoved him out o’ the way.

events.text_segment:
Pap warn’t in a good humor—so he was his natural self. He said he was down town, and everything was going wrong. His lawyer said he reckoned he would win his lawsuit and get the money if they ever got started on the trial; but then there was ways to put it off a long time, and Judge Thatcher knowed how to do it. And he said people allowed there’d be another trial to get me away from him and give me to the widow for my guardian, and they guessed it would win this time. This shook me up considerable, because I didn’t want to go back to the widow’s any more and be so cramped up and sivilized, as they called it. Then the old man got to cussing, and cussed everything and everybody he could think of, and then cussed them all over again to make sure he hadn’t skipped any, and after that he polished off with a kind of a general cuss all round, including a considerable parcel of people which he didn’t know the names of, and so called them what’s-his-name when he got to them, and went right along with his cussing.
He said he would like to see the widow get me. He said he would watch out, and if they tried to come any such game on him he knowed of a place six or seven mile off to stow me in, where they might hunt till they dropped and they couldn’t find me. That made me pretty uneasy again, but only for a minute; I reckoned I wouldn’t stay on hand till he got that chance.
The old man made me go to the skiff and fetch the things he had got. There was a fifty-pound sack of corn meal, and a side of bacon, ammunition, and a four-gallon jug of whisky, and an old book and two newspapers for wadding, besides some tow. I toted up a load, and went back and set down on the bow of the skiff to rest. I thought it all over, and I reckoned I would walk off with the gun and some lines, and take to the woods when I run away. I guessed I wouldn’t stay in one place, but just tramp right across the country, mostly night times, and hunt and fish to keep alive, and so get so far away that the old man nor the widow couldn’t ever find me any more. I judged I would saw out and leave that night if pap got drunk enough, and I reckoned he would. I got so full of it I didn’t notice how long I was staying till the old man hollered and asked me whether I was asleep or drownded.
I got the things all up to the cabin, and then it was about dark. While I was cooking supper the old man took a swig or two and got sort of warmed up, and went to ripping again. He had been drunk over in town, and laid in the gutter all night, and he was a sight to look at. A body would a thought he was Adam—he was just all mud. Whenever his liquor begun to work he most always went for the govment, this time he says:
“Call this a govment! why, just look at it and see what it’s like. Here’s the law a-standing ready to take a man’s son away from him—a man’s own son, which he has had all the trouble and all the anxiety and all the expense of raising. Yes, just as that man has got that son raised at last, and ready to go to work and begin to do suthin’ for him and give him a rest, the law up and goes for him. And they call that govment! That ain’t all, nuther. The law backs that old Judge Thatcher up and helps him to keep me out o’ my property. Here’s what the law does: The law takes a man worth six thousand dollars and up’ards, and jams him into an old trap of a cabin like this, and lets him go round in clothes that ain’t fitten for a hog. They call that govment! A man can’t get his rights in a govment like this. Sometimes I’ve a mighty notion to just leave the country for good and all. Yes, and I told ’em so; I told old Thatcher so to his face. Lots of ’em heard me, and can tell what I said. Says I, for two cents I’d leave the blamed country and never come a-near it agin. Them’s the very words. I says look at my hat—if you call it a hat—but the lid raises up and the rest of it goes down till it’s below my chin, and then it ain’t rightly a hat at all, but more like my head was shoved up through a jint o’ stove-pipe. Look at it, says I—such a hat for me to wear—one of the wealthiest men in this town if I could git my rights.
“Oh, yes, this is a wonderful govment, wonderful. Why, looky here. There was a free nigger there from Ohio—a mulatter, most as white as a white man. He had the whitest shirt on you ever see, too, and the shiniest hat; and there ain’t a man in that town that’s got as fine clothes as what he had; and he had a gold watch and chain, and a silver-headed cane—the awfulest old gray-headed nabob in the State. And what do you think? They said he was a p’fessor in a college, and could talk all kinds of languages, and knowed everything. And that ain’t the wust. They said he could vote when he was at home. Well, that let me out. Thinks I, what is the country a-coming to? It was ’lection day, and I was just about to go and vote myself if I warn’t too drunk to get there; but when they told me there was a State in this country where they’d let that nigger vote, I drawed out. I says I’ll never vote agin. Them’s the very words I said; they all heard me; and the country may rot for all me—I’ll never vote agin as long as I live. And to see the cool way of that nigger—why, he wouldn’t a give me the road if I hadn’t shoved him out o’ the way.

His lawyer said he judged he would win his lawsuit and get the money, if they ever got started on the trial; but then he said the Widow Douglas and Judge Thatcher were going to lay over another one on him, and waltz in and get Huck taken away from him and let her have him to adopt, and then they’d fuss and bother over him till they’d make a man of him, and if they succeeded they would ‘sivilize’ him and it would be so that he couldn’t stand it. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Pap warn’t in a good humor—so he was his natural self. He come a-stomping in, smelling of whiskey and the river, his long hair all tangled and greasy, and his face looking like a thunder-cloud that had been left out in the sun too long. He didn’t say nothing at first, just glared around the cabin like he expected to find somebody hidin’ there. I was settin’ by the fire, trying to look small and busy, mending a fish-line. My heart was thumping against my ribs like a drum. I knew what was coming. It always come when he was like this. He’d been gone for a couple of days, off on one of his sprees, and I’d had a little peace, just me and the woods and the river sounds. But now he was back, and the peace was over. He finally spotted me and his eyes narrowed. “Well, looky here,” he growled, his voice rough as sandpaper. “Settin’ there like a lord, ain’t you? With your fine clothes and your book-learnin’.” My clothes warn’t fine; they was just the ones the Widow Douglas had give me, patched up. And the book-learnin’ was just a little bit I’d got before he snatched me away. But you couldn’t tell him that. He didn’t want to hear it. He wanted to be mad. He staggered over and kicked the stool I was settin’ on right out from under me. I landed on the floor with a thump. “Git up!” he yelled. “Think you’re too good to work, do you? Settin’ there mending fish-lines when there’s wood to chop and water to fetch! You think you’re better’n your old man, don’t you? With your schoolin’ and your clean shirt!” He was working himself up into a real frenzy now. His face was red and his eyes were wild. He started pacing back and forth, waving his arms. “I’ll show you who’s better! I’ll knock the schoolin’ right out of you! What right have you got to be goin’ to school? A boy like you! Your pap never went to school, and he got along just fine! Better’n fine! I’m a man, I am! And you’re just a boy, and you’ll do what I tell you!” He went on like that for a good while, ranting about school and books and how they was all foolishness. He said they just filled your head with nonsense and made you think you was better than honest folks. He said the government was in league with the schools to make people soft and easy to control. He said the only thing a man needed was his own two hands and a bottle of whiskey. Then he got onto the subject of my money. The six thousand dollars Judge Thatcher was keeping for me. That was always a sore spot with him. He couldn’t stand the idea of me having money and him not being able to get his hands on it. “And that money!” he roared, stopping right in front of me and shaking his fist. “Six thousand dollars! Mine, by rights! My boy’s got six thousand dollars, and I ain’t got a cent! It ain’t right! The law’s a fool! Says I can’t have it! Says I ain’t fit to have it! Who says I ain’t fit? I’m his father! I made him! I got a right to that money!” He went on about the law and the courts and how they was all against him. He said they protected folks like the Widow Douglas and Judge Thatcher, who was trying to steal his boy and his money. He said they let free niggers vote, but wouldn’t let an honest white man like him have his own son’s money. That was another thing that always set him off – free black people. He couldn’t stand the idea of them being free and having rights. He’d seen a free black man in town once, dressed in nice clothes and carrying a cane, and it had driven him crazy. He talked about it for days. He said it warn’t natural. He said they ought to be sold back into slavery. He said the government was run by fools and abolitionists. He’d get so worked up about it, his face would turn purple and he’d foam at the mouth. He’d yell and curse and smash things. Sometimes he’d chase me around the cabin, trying to beat me. I’d have to dodge and duck and try to get out the door. He was strong, even when he was drunk, and his blows hurt. He didn’t care where he hit you. He’d just flail away. I learned to be quick on my feet. I learned to read the signs in his face and his voice, to know when he was about to explode. It was a miserable life. I was scared most of the time. Scared of him, scared of the dark, scared of being alone with him in that cabin in the woods. He wouldn’t let me go to school, wouldn’t let me go to church, wouldn’t let me see my friends. He just kept me there, locked up, so he could have me all to himself and beat me and yell at me whenever he felt like it. He’d go off sometimes for days, leaving me with just enough food to get by. Those were the good times, even though I was lonely. But then he’d come back, and the nightmare would start all over again. He’d drink and rant and rave, and I’d just have to sit there and take it, or try to get out of his way. He’d talk about how he was going to get my money, how he was going to make me work for him, how he was going to show the world that he was somebody. But mostly he just drank and got meaner and meaner. He was the worst kind of human being I ever met. He was ignorant and violent and full of hate. And he was my father. It made me sick to think about it. I wished he would just disappear and never come back. I wished I was dead sometimes, just to be free of him. But mostly I just wished I could get away. Get away from the cabin, get away from him, get away from the whole miserable business. I didn’t know how I was going to do it, but I knew I had to. I couldn’t live like that forever. Nobody could. It was worse than being dead. It was like being buried alive, with a madman for company. And he was just getting started tonight. I could see it in his eyes. It was going to be a long night.

events.title: Pap's Racist Tirade Intensifies Leading to Self-Injury
detailed_summary: Pap continued his racist tirade, questioning why the free black man wasn't immediately auctioned and sold, and expressed outrage that the government would require a six-month residency before such an action could be taken against a 'prowling, thieving, infernal, white-shirted free nigger.'
Distracted by his own passionate speech, Pap failed to watch his step and tripped headfirst over a tub of salt pork, injuring both his shins.
The accident prompted an outburst of even more heated profanity, primarily aimed at the black man and the government, though the tub also received some of his ire.
He hopped around the cabin in pain, first on one leg, then the other, clutching his shins.
In a fit of rage, he suddenly kicked the tub with his left foot.
This proved to be a poor decision, as that boot had holes exposing a couple of his toes, causing him excruciating pain.

Pap let out a howl that Huck described as hair-raising, then collapsed to the ground, rolling and clutching his injured toes, while unleashing a barrage of curses that Huck believed surpassed any of Pap's previous efforts, and even those of the renowned cusser Sowberry Hagan, though Huck suspected Pap might be exaggerating his own prowess.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I says to the people, why ain’t this nigger put up at auction and sold?—that’s what I want to know.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had heard old Sowberry Hagan in his best days, and he said it laid over him, too; but I reckon that was sort of piling it on, maybe.

events.text_segment:
I says to the people, why ain’t this nigger put up at auction and sold?—that’s what I want to know. And what do you reckon they said? Why, they said he couldn’t be sold till he’d been in the State six months, and he hadn’t been there that long yet. There, now—that’s a specimen. They call that a govment that can’t sell a free nigger till he’s been in the State six months. Here’s a govment that calls itself a govment, and lets on to be a govment, and thinks it is a govment, and yet’s got to set stock-still for six whole months before it can take a hold of a prowling, thieving, infernal, white-shirted free nigger, and—”
Pap was agoing on so he never noticed where his old limber legs was taking him to, so he went head over heels over the tub of salt pork and barked both shins, and the rest of his speech was all the hottest kind of language—mostly hove at the nigger and the govment, though he give the tub some, too, all along, here and there. He hopped around the cabin considerable, first on one leg and then on the other, holding first one shin and then the other one, and at last he let out with his left foot all of a sudden and fetched the tub a rattling kick. But it warn’t good judgment, because that was the boot that had a couple of his toes leaking out of the front end of it; so now he raised a howl that fairly made a body’s hair raise, and down he went in the dirt, and rolled there, and held his toes; and the cussing he done then laid over anything he had ever done previous. He said so his own self afterwards. He had heard old Sowberry Hagan in his best days, and he said it laid over him, too; but I reckon that was sort of piling it on, maybe.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I says to the people, why ain’t this nigger put up at auction and sold?—that’s what I want to know. And as for the law, and the government, I’ve put that at defiance for forty year. I’ll be dod-derned if I hain’t. I’ll learn people to bring money with ’em when they come to co’t. Oh, yes—this is a wonderful govment, wonderful. Why, looky here. There was a free nigger there, from Ohio; a mulatter, most as white as a white man. He had the whitest shirt on you ever see, too, and the shiniest hat; and there ain’t no hat like it in the State of Illinois. He was a professor in a college, and could talk all kinds of languages, and knowed everything. And that ain’t the wust. They said he could vote, when he was at home. Well, that let me out. Thinks I, what is the country a-coming to? It was ‘lection day, and I was just about to go and vote, myself. Well, I dasn’t just fetch up and vote, not without I was drunk. Well, then, what is the use of being a govment? Collection day comes, and I can’t vote. This ain’t no country for a poor man. The govment flopped down on a settee, with his head in his hands, and moaned out: “I says to the people, why ain’t this nigger put up at auction and sold?—that’s what I want to know.” He got to roaring and cussing at the government and the free niggers and there ain’t no end to it. Says I, “All right, Pap, all right. Go it alone; it’s your row; you’re boss; I’ll stand by and look on.” Well, that didn’t satisfy him. He kept a-raging right along, hitting the table with his fist, and his eyes flashing, and his face as red as fire, and the froth flying from his mouth, and his hair up and his nostrils spread and he grinding his teeth. He had his knife out and was trying to open it with his teeth, and all the time he was a-cussing. He got to cussing so loud, that I was afraid he would wake up the neighbors.
