LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Every night now I used to slip ashore towards ten o’clock at some little village, and buy ten or fifteen cents’ worth of meal or bacon or other stuff to eat; and sometimes I lifted a chicken that warn’t roosting comfortable, and took him along. We didn’t have no trouble about grub, mostly. The river was generous. We’d catch catfish big as a man, sometimes, and fry ‘em up. Or we’d find a watermelon patch ashore and borrow a few. Jim was mighty particular about not stealing, but borrowing was different, he said, if you meant to pay it back sometime. I reckon we borrowed a heap. Mostly, though, we just drifted. Daytimes, we’d tie up in some thick timber where the current warn’t strong, and lay low. It was peaceful there, just the sound of the water lapping and the birds singing. Jim would maybe sleep, or we’d talk a little, quiet-like. He was always thinking about his family, wishing he was free so he could buy ‘em. That made me feel a bit mean, being free myself and him not. Nights was the best. We’d shove out into the middle of the river, where it was wide and dark. The stars was something else out there, thick as sand on a bar. You could lay on your back on the raft and just look up, and it felt like you was floating in the sky too. The river sounds was different at night – more mysterious, maybe. Sometimes you’d hear a steamboat way off, its lights like eyes in the dark, or the hoot of an owl. It was lonesome, but a good lonesome. We didn’t see many people, and that suited us fine. We was just us, the raft, and the big river, heading south into the unknown. It felt like we was the only two folks in the whole world sometimes, just drifting along, free and easy, with nothing to bother us but the next meal and keeping out of sight.

events.title: Discovery of the Wrecked Steamboat and Huck's Insistence on Exploring
detailed_summary: Huck and Jim occasionally supplemented their provisions by shooting waterfowl, contributing to their relatively comfortable existence on the raft.
Five nights after passing St. Louis, they encountered a violent thunderstorm after midnight, characterized by powerful thunder, lightning, and torrential rain.
They took refuge in their wigwam, allowing the raft to drift at the mercy of the storm.
During flashes of lightning, they observed that they were on a broad, straight section of the river, flanked by high, rocky bluffs.
Huck suddenly spotted a steamboat that had wrecked on a rock, lying directly in their path.

The lightning illuminated the wreck distinctly, revealing it leaning over with part of its upper deck above water, and details such as its chimney supports and a chair by the main bell with an old hat hanging on it.
The eerie and solitary sight of the wreck in the stormy darkness stirred Huck's adventurous instincts, making him eager to board and explore it.
He proposed to Jim that they land on the steamboat.
Jim was initially strongly against the idea, citing fear, biblical caution against tempting fate, and the potential presence of a watchman.

Huck dismissed Jim's concerns, arguing that no one would risk their life guarding a wreck on such a perilous night, and highlighted the possibility of finding valuable items like cigars in the captain's quarters.
He invoked Tom Sawyer, asserting that Tom would view it as an adventure and seize the opportunity to explore, and would do so with characteristic flair and style.
Huck expressed a wish for Tom Sawyer's presence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We shot a water-fowl, now and then, that got up too early in the morning or didn’t go to bed early enough in the evening.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I wish Tom Sawyer was here.”

events.text_segment:
We shot a water-fowl, now and then, that got up too early in the morning or didn’t go to bed early enough in the evening. Take it all round, we lived pretty high.
The fifth night below St. Louis we had a big storm after midnight, with a power of thunder and lightning, and the rain poured down in a solid sheet. We stayed in the wigwam and let the raft take care of itself. When the lightning glared out we could see a big straight river ahead, and high, rocky bluffs on both sides. By-and-by says I, “Hel-lo, Jim, looky yonder!” It was a steamboat that had killed herself on a rock. We was drifting straight down for her. The lightning showed her very distinct. She was leaning over, with part of her upper deck above water, and you could see every little chimbly-guy clean and clear, and a chair by the big bell, with an old slouch hat hanging on the back of it, when the flashes come.
Well, it being away in the night and stormy, and all so mysterious-like, I felt just the way any other boy would a felt when I see that wreck laying there so mournful and lonesome in the middle of the river. I wanted to get aboard of her and slink around a little, and see what there was there. So I says:
“Le’s land on her, Jim.”
But Jim was dead against it at first. He says:
“I doan’ want to go fool’n ’long er no wrack. We’s doin’ blame’ well, en we better let blame’ well alone, as de good book says. Like as not dey’s a watchman on dat wrack.”
“Watchman your grandmother,” I says; “there ain’t nothing to watch but the texas and the pilot-house; and do you reckon anybody’s going to resk his life for a texas and a pilot-house such a night as this, when it’s likely to break up and wash off down the river any minute?” Jim couldn’t say nothing to that, so he didn’t try. “And besides,” I says, “we might borrow something worth having out of the captain’s stateroom. Seegars, I bet you—and cost five cents apiece, solid cash. Steamboat captains is always rich, and get sixty dollars a month, and they don’t care a cent what a thing costs, you know, long as they want it. Stick a candle in your pocket; I can’t rest, Jim, till we give her a rummaging. Do you reckon Tom Sawyer would ever go by this thing? Not for pie, he wouldn’t. He’d call it an adventure—that’s what he’d call it; and he’d land on that wreck if it was his last act. And wouldn’t he throw style into it?—wouldn’t he spread himself, nor nothing? Why, you’d think it was Christopher C’lumbus discovering Kingdom-Come. I wish Tom Sawyer was here.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We shot a water-fowl, now and then, that got up too early in the morning or didn’t go to bed early enough in the evening. Now and then we picked up driftwood that had got away from the tow-heads, and wet lumber that got away from rafts. Sometimes, when we couldn’t do anything else, we fished. We kept a lookout for dead cottonwood trees, too, that had got hung up on some snag or other, and pulled them off for firewood. In this way we got along pretty comfortably. The river was getting wider and wider, and about the middle of the afternoon we judged we had got to the widest place in the river now where it was a mile and a half across. We kept away from the shore all day and all night the next night. The fifth night we passed St. Louis, just a vast range of lights that spread for miles and miles. By the time I was ready to turn in, the storm was abating, and the moon came out and not a cloud left about as big as your hat, and the stars shone, and the leaves of the trees stopped rustling. It was the stillest night you ever see. The next night was the fifth night after we passed St. Louis, and the weather was mighty fine and pleasant, and the stars big, and the moon slim, and away up forrard in the sky, and the trees along the shore was going by so quiet and soft and sweet that you wouldn’t hardly notice them. We slid along, and had a good time talking, till about midnight, when everything got quiet, and the stars begun to blink and look sleepy. Pretty soon the moon she begin to look sleepy, too, and pale and she warn’t far from setting. All at once, right against the sharp line of the horizon—she just glinted on the edge of it, she didn’t rise over it—a streak of light showed the tops of the trees standing solid black against the sky, for a second, and the stars blazed out like diamonds that had been wiped clean. Then the streak went out, and it was dark as pitch, and so still that you could hear the bugs crawling. By-and-by, next streak, away off to the left, away down the river, about twenty mile, as near as I could judge, but it seemed mighty close, because it was so dark; and this time it showed a black wall of wood, like a forest, along the river, away down that side. Then pretty soon up over our heads there was a boom, a far-off rumbling, that died away and after that another streak and another boom, and then closer and closer, till next I knowed the stars and the moon were gone, and over everything a black sky and a black river, and away off a streak of lightning hit the water, and you could see it go sizzling along for a second, and then was dark again. Well, I reckon it warn’t a minute hardly till the wind begun to blow right here in our faces, and the rain begun to drop and I could see the wigwam begin to shiver and flap, and I says to Jim, “Here she comes! Pitch in, Jim!” and we grabbed the tow-lines and shoved for the bank. But we warn’t going to land; we couldn’t, of course, with that wind blowing and the rain coming down like buckets, and the lightning and thunder a-going the way it was. So we just shoved the raft in under the lee of a tow-head, and got into the wigwam, and waited. The lightning was squirting around every now and then and whenever it did we could see a big straight river ahead, and high rocky bluffs on both sides. By-and-by, along comes a steamboat up the river, and she was a beauty, too; she was a big one, and she was coming along swift, but silent, and she warn’t lit up. She was a wreck. She was laying over, with part of her upper deck above water, and you could see her chimney supports and a chair by the main bell, with an old hat hanging on it. The lightning showed her up just as clear as day, and I says to Jim, “I wish Tom Sawyer was here.” Jim says, “Why?” “Because,” I says, “he’d know what to do. He’d take a look at that wreck, and he’d say, ‘Here’s a chance for an adventure!’ and he’d be right. We could land on her, and see what’s in her. There might be something valuable.” Jim says, “No, sah, we ain’t gwine to land on no wreck. Dat ain’t no place for us. Dat’s de place for dead folks. Dat ain’t no place for live folks.” I says, “But Jim, there might be something in her. We could get some cigars, maybe, or some clothes, or something.” Jim says, “No, sah, we ain’t gwine to land on no wreck. Dat ain’t no place for us. Dat’s de place for dead folks. Dat ain’t no place for live folks.” I says, “But Jim, there might be something in her. We could get some cigars, maybe, or some clothes, or something. Let’s land on her, Jim.” “No, sah. I ain’t gwine to do it. I ain’t gwine to tempt de Lord. Dat ain’t no place for a nigger to go. And besides, dere might be somebody on her, a watchman, maybe.” “A watchman?” I says. “Why, Jim, nobody wouldn’t watch a wreck on a night like this. They wouldn’t be allowed to. They’d be drowned. And besides, what is there to watch? It’s a wreck.” “Yes, sah, but dere might be a watchman, and he might be asleep, and we could slip in and get something and slip out again. But I ain’t gwine to do it. I ain’t gwine to tempt de Lord.” “Well,” I says, “this is the dandiest opportunity that ever offered. I wish Tom Sawyer was here. I bet he’d take a look at that wreck, and he’d say, ‘Here’s a chance for an adventure!’ He’d land on her, and he’d find out what was in her, and he’d do it in style, too. He wouldn’t be afraid. He’d be right there, and he’d be the first one.” I says, “Jim, I’m going to land on her. Are you coming?” “No, sah. I ain’t gwine to do it. I ain’t gwine to tempt de Lord.” “Well,” I says, “then I’ll go by myself.”

events.title: Boarding the Wreck and Eavesdropping on a Confrontation
detailed_summary: Jim, though grumbling, conceded to Huck's plan to explore the wreck, on the condition that they minimize their conversation and speak very softly.
A fortunate lightning flash illuminated their path, allowing them to reach the starboard derrick of the wreck and secure their raft.
The steamboat's deck was considerably higher than their raft.
They moved cautiously in the darkness along the sloping deck towards the texas (officers' cabins), using their feet to feel the way and their hands to avoid obstructions.
Upon reaching the forward end of the skylight, they climbed onto it, which brought them near the captain's open cabin door.
Unexpectedly, they saw a light emanating from further down the texas hall and, at the same moment, heard low voices.
Jim whispered to Huck that he felt very ill and urged him to return to the raft.
Huck agreed and was about to leave, but then he heard a voice desperately pleading not to be harmed and promising never to reveal anything.

A second, louder voice responded, accusing the first speaker, identified as Jim Turner, of being a liar who consistently manipulated situations to get more than his share by threatening to inform on others, declaring that Turner had finally overplayed his hand and was the most despicable and treacherous person in the region.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Jim he grumbled a little, but give in.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence:

“It’s a lie, Jim Turner. You’ve acted this way before. You always want more’n your share of the truck, and you’ve always got it, too, because you’ve swore ’t if you didn’t you’d tell. But this time you’ve said it jest one time too many. You’re the meanest, treacherousest hound in this country.”

events.text_segment:
Jim he grumbled a little, but give in. He said we mustn’t talk any more than we could help, and then talk mighty low. The lightning showed us the wreck again just in time, and we fetched the stabboard derrick, and made fast there.
The deck was high out here. We went sneaking down the slope of it to labboard, in the dark, towards the texas, feeling our way slow with our feet, and spreading our hands out to fend off the guys, for it was so dark we couldn’t see no sign of them. Pretty soon we struck the forward end of the skylight, and clumb on to it; and the next step fetched us in front of the captain’s door, which was open, and by Jimminy, away down through the texas-hall we see a light! and all in the same second we seem to hear low voices in yonder!
Jim whispered and said he was feeling powerful sick, and told me to come along. I says, all right, and was going to start for the raft; but just then I heard a voice wail out and say:
“Oh, please don’t, boys; I swear I won’t ever tell!”
Another voice said, pretty loud:
“It’s a lie, Jim Turner. You’ve acted this way before. You always want more’n your share of the truck, and you’ve always got it, too, because you’ve swore ’t if you didn’t you’d tell. But this time you’ve said it jest one time too many. You’re the meanest, treacherousest hound in this country.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Jim he grumbled a little, but give in. He said we ought to keep still, and not talk at all, because if we was to run across any robbers they would make all the noise they could, and we would hear them. He said if we could see the light enough we would run to the raft with noise enough to wake the dead, and after that we didn't need to listen for them. So we was pretty near the wreck, and everything was dark, and still, and we hauled her to and fastened her. It warn't a difficult job to clamber up the side. The only trouble was, the deck was that slanting that you couldn't stand up straight. We stooped along in the dark, on our hands and knees, towards the forward end of the skylight, that the robbers was in. We didn't know that yet, but we was feeling kind of spooky. We got to the skylight, and crawled on to it, and stood up. We could look up the texas-deck, now, and towards the pilot-house, but couldn't see anybody. The lightning begun to flare up now and then, and we'd see a low stack of stove-pipe, or a black smoke-stack, or some parts of the machinery, and feel it was all very lonesome and mysterious. Then, pretty soon, we made out a light away off in the texas, and Jim whispered and said he didn't know what it was, but he allowed it was ghosts. I said no, ghosts didn't have to have lights to see with. He said, "Well, spy-lights, anyway;" and says "le's get out o' here, en go som'ers else." But I says -- "It ain't anything but robbers. We'll go and watch the robbers a little while." So I started, and he scrabbled after. We crept along towards the light, and got to the texas door, and stood there, peeking. Presently we could see two men stretched on the floor with their hands and feet tied. They had been gagged, too, but one of the gags had got loose. This was the one that was doing the talking -- he was so pale, and his eyes was so wild, he looked scary. We heard a voice say: "O, please don't, Bill; I hain't ever going to tell." The other voice said: "I reckon not! You hain't got no time to tell, and no place to tell in. We'd a killed you before now, if we hadn't wanted to get your hands on that money first. events.title: Overhearing a Murderous Plot
detailed_summary: While Huck listened intently, Jim had already retreated towards their raft.
Huck, consumed by curiosity and inspired by what he imagined Tom Sawyer would do, resolved to investigate the situation further.
He crept quietly on his hands and knees through the dark passage until only one stateroom was between him and the cross-hall of the texas.
Peeking in, he saw a man, Jim Turner, tied hand and foot on the floor. Two other men, Bill and Jake Packard, stood over him; Packard held a dim lantern, while Bill brandished a pistol.
Bill repeatedly aimed the pistol at Turner's head, calling him a vile person.
The bound man, Turner, pleaded with Bill not to shoot, promising he would never tell.

Each time Turner begged, Jake Packard, holding the lantern, would laugh derisively, sarcastically agreeing that Turner indeed wouldn't tell, and remarked that Turner would have killed both of them if they hadn't overpowered him, merely for asserting their rights. Packard then instructed Bill to lower the pistol.
Bill expressed his reluctance, stating his intent to kill Turner, referencing Turner's past actions, like killing an 'old Hatfield,' and arguing Turner deserved death.
Packard responded that he did not want Turner killed and had his own reasons for this.
This statement elicited a tearful expression of gratitude from the man on the floor.

Ignoring Turner's outburst, Packard hung his lantern on a nail and began moving towards Huck's hiding spot, signaling Bill to accompany him. Huck quickly crawled backward but, hindered by the boat's slant, ducked into an empty stateroom and concealed himself in an upper berth.

Packard and Bill entered the stateroom where Huck was hidden; he could smell the whisky they had been drinking. Terrified, Huck held his breath, barely able to listen to their hushed, serious conversation.
Bill argued that Turner would certainly inform on them if given the chance and insisted on killing him to ensure their safety.
To Bill's initial surprise, Packard quietly agreed with the sentiment.

However, Packard then elaborated, suggesting a 'quieter' method: they would first search the staterooms for any remaining valuables, take the loot ashore, and hide it. He predicted the wreck would break apart and be washed downriver within two hours, which would result in Turner drowning.
Packard presented this as a preferable alternative to actively killing Turner, framing it as more sensible and morally superior, as it avoided direct responsibility for Turner's death.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By this time Jim was gone for the raft.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ain’t I right?”

events.text_segment:
By this time Jim was gone for the raft. I was just a-biling with curiosity; and I says to myself, Tom Sawyer wouldn’t back out now, and so I won’t either; I’m a-going to see what’s going on here. So I dropped on my hands and knees in the little passage, and crept aft in the dark till there warn’t but one stateroom betwixt me and the cross-hall of the texas. Then in there I see a man stretched on the floor and tied hand and foot, and two men standing over him, and one of them had a dim lantern in his hand, and the other one had a pistol. This one kept pointing the pistol at the man’s head on the floor, and saying:
“I’d like to! And I orter, too—a mean skunk!”
The man on the floor would shrivel up and say, “Oh, please don’t, Bill; I hain’t ever goin’ to tell.”
And every time he said that the man with the lantern would laugh and say:
“’Deed you ain’t! You never said no truer thing ’n that, you bet you.” And once he said: “Hear him beg! and yit if we hadn’t got the best of him and tied him he’d a killed us both. And what for? Jist for noth’n. Jist because we stood on our rights—that’s what for. But I lay you ain’t a-goin’ to threaten nobody any more, Jim Turner. Put up that pistol, Bill.”
Bill says:
“I don’t want to, Jake Packard. I’m for killin’ him—and didn’t he kill old Hatfield jist the same way—and don’t he deserve it?”
“But I don’t want him killed, and I’ve got my reasons for it.”
“Bless yo’ heart for them words, Jake Packard! I’ll never forgit you long’s I live!” says the man on the floor, sort of blubbering.
Packard didn’t take no notice of that, but hung up his lantern on a nail and started towards where I was there in the dark, and motioned Bill to come. I crawfished as fast as I could about two yards, but the boat slanted so that I couldn’t make very good time; so to keep from getting run over and catched I crawled into a stateroom on the upper side. The man came a-pawing along in the dark, and when Packard got to my stateroom, he says:
“Here—come in here.”
And in he come, and Bill after him. But before they got in I was up in the upper berth, cornered, and sorry I come. Then they stood there, with their hands on the ledge of the berth, and talked. I couldn’t see them, but I could tell where they was by the whisky they’d been having. I was glad I didn’t drink whisky; but it wouldn’t made much difference anyway, because most of the time they couldn’t a treed me because I didn’t breathe. I was too scared. And, besides, a body couldn’t breathe and hear such talk. They talked low and earnest. Bill wanted to kill Turner. He says:
“He’s said he’ll tell, and he will. If we was to give both our shares to him now it wouldn’t make no difference after the row and the way we’ve served him. Shore’s you’re born, he’ll turn State’s evidence; now you hear me. I’m for putting him out of his troubles.”
“So’m I,” says Packard, very quiet.
“Blame it, I’d sorter begun to think you wasn’t. Well, then, that’s all right. Le’s go and do it.”
“Hold on a minute; I hain’t had my say yit. You listen to me. Shooting’s good, but there’s quieter ways if the thing’s got to be done. But what I say is this: it ain’t good sense to go court’n around after a halter if you can git at what you’re up to in some way that’s jist as good and at the same time don’t bring you into no resks. Ain’t that so?”
“You bet it is. But how you goin’ to manage it this time?”
“Well, my idea is this: we’ll rustle around and gather up whatever pickins we’ve overlooked in the staterooms, and shove for shore and hide the truck. Then we’ll wait. Now I say it ain’t a-goin’ to be more’n two hours befo’ this wrack breaks up and washes off down the river. See? He’ll be drownded, and won’t have nobody to blame for it but his own self. I reckon that’s a considerble sight better ’n killin’ of him. I’m unfavorable to killin’ a man as long as you can git aroun’ it; it ain’t good sense, it ain’t good morals. Ain’t I right?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: By this time Jim was gone for the raft. I set up there and waited, studying how to act. I was feeling pretty shaky, but I knowed I had to do something. I set there a good while, till I got a little steadier; then I crept down the ladder and slid into the pilot-house, and crouched down on the floor, and listened. Everybody was stone still; nobody was stirring; it was as dark as pitch. Pretty soon I got up again and felt my way back to the skylight, got my head in and listened. All the sounds came from the middle of the boat—the sounds of men talking. I crept along the roof, and got down and begun to explore; and I found a crack under the door, and I got my eye to it and looked in. There was two men, and I knowed they was the murderers by the voice, and they was talking low and earnest. I couldn’t make out but little of what they said. Pretty soon I slid away and got under the skiff, scrouched down, and got my ear agin the head of the barrel and listened again. The first thing came out was: “Let’s lighten the boat a little, gentlemen, and throw this truck overboard.” It was the Dutchman that said it—him that I had seen standing on the river-bank all alone the day before. He was the captain. The other two was Bill and Jake Packard. Bill says: “I don’t care what you do with the truck, but I’m for putting this man ashore and leaving him.” “No,” says the captain, “that won’t do. He might tell.” “Well,” says Bill, “then we’ll kill him.” “No,” says the captain, “that won’t do either. He’s a good man, and I don’t want to kill him. I’ve got my reasons.” “Well,” says Bill, “then what are we going to do with him?” “I’ll tell you,” says the captain. “We’ll tie him hand and foot, and leave him here. The wreck will break up and wash down the river in two hours, and he’ll drown. That’s the best way.” “Well,” says Bill, “that’s a good idea. I’m agreed.” “All right,” says the captain. “Now, then, we’ll go through the boat and see if there’s anything left.” They went off and I didn’t hear no more for a while. Then I heard them coming back. I got under the skiff again. They come and stood right over me, and I could hear them talking. “Well,” says Bill, “there ain’t nothing left but this here skiff. We’ll take that.” “No,” says the captain, “we won’t take that. We’ll leave it here. It might be wanted.” “Well,” says Bill, “what are we going to do with this here man?” “I told you,” says the captain. “We’ll leave him here. He’ll drown.” “Well,” says Bill, “I don’t like it. I’d rather kill him myself.” “No,” says the captain, “you won’t kill him. I’ve got my reasons.” “Well,” says Bill, “all right. Have it your own way.” They went off again. I laid there a good while, and then I begun to think. I says to myself, I says, “Here’s a chance to do a noble act. I’ll get this man loose and I’ll get him ashore.” I got out from under the skiff and crept to the door and listened. They was still talking, but they was further off now. I crept to the crack and looked in again. There was the man tied hand and foot on the floor. Two men stood over him. One of them had a pistol in his hand and was pointing it at the man’s head. The other one had a lantern. “I’d kill him myself,” says the one with the pistol. “No,” says the one with the lantern, “you won’t kill him. I’ve got my reasons.” “Well,” says the one with the pistol, “all right. Have it your own way.” Then he lowered the pistol. The man on the floor begun to beg. “Oh, don’t kill me, gentlemen,” he says. “I won’t ever tell.” “You won’t tell!” says the one with the lantern, laughing. “Of course you won’t tell. I was plumb wore out and sick at my stomach. I laid there and waited, and after a while I heard a little rustle amongst the bushes, and Jim come a-crawling out, all wet and streaky with mud. He was the gladdest man I ever see. He just grabbed me and hugged me, and says:

I told him the whole story, right from the start, about how I got separated from him in the fog, and how I got ashore, and about the dogs and the house and the Grangerfords and the Shepherdsons, and Buck and the beautiful Miss Sophia and Harney Shepherdson, and the church and the sermon, and the poetry and the pictures, and the dead girl, and the feud, and how Buck got killed, and all the rest of it. I didn’t leave out a thing. Jim listened with his eyes bugging out, and every now and then he’d fetch a groan or a sigh, and when I told about Buck and the others getting shot, he just shivered and says:

“Lord, Lord, po’ Buck! En’ de oders. Hit’s awful, Huck, awful!”

He was mighty sorry for me, and for Buck, and for everybody that got mixed up in that mess. He said he’d been hiding in the swamp, and he’d seen the raft float by, and he’d been mighty scared I was drowned or captured. He’d been living on berries and roots, and he was powerful hungry. He said he’d found the canoe I’d used to get ashore, and he’d been paddling around the edge of the swamp, looking for me, and he’d heard the shooting and the yelling, and he’d been scared out of his wits.

After a while, he says:

“Well, we better git de raft.”

So we went down to where he’d hid it. It was tucked away in a little cove, all safe and sound. We got aboard, and Jim pushed off. The current caught us, and we begun to drift downstream. It was night by then, and the stars was out, and the river was dark and quiet. It felt like we was the only two people in the world, floating along on that big, silent river.

We didn’t talk much at first. We just laid there on the raft, looking up at the stars, and listening to the sounds of the river. It was the peacefulest thing I ever knowed. After all that fuss and trouble ashore, it was like coming home. The raft was home. It was free and easy and natural, and there warn’t no rules or no fighting or no dead people. events.title: Huck's Desperate Plan and a Shocking Discovery
detailed_summary: Bill questioned Jake Packard's plan, asking what they would do if the steamboat wreck didn't break apart and wash away as Packard anticipated.
Packard suggested they could simply wait the two hours to see what happened, and Bill agreed to this course of action.
As Packard and Bill departed, Huck, drenched in a cold sweat from fear, quickly scrambled from his hiding place and hurried forward in the pitch-dark conditions.
He whispered for Jim, and Jim responded with a moan from close by.

Huck urgently informed Jim that there was no time for moaning, as a group of murderers was on the wreck. He proposed they find the murderers' boat and set it adrift down the river. This would prevent the gang from escaping the wreck, thereby ensuring that one of them (Jim Turner) would be in grave danger.
Huck elaborated that if they successfully set the criminals' boat adrift, all of them would be in a dire situation, as the Sheriff would then be able to apprehend them.
He directed Jim to search one side of the wreck for the boat while he searched the other, starting their search from where their own raft was moored.
Jim, in great distress, cried out that their raft was no longer there; it had broken loose and drifted away, leaving them stranded on the wrecked steamboat.

events.text_segment:
“Yes, I reck’n you are. But s’pose she don’t break up and wash off?”
“Well, we can wait the two hours anyway and see, can’t we?”
“All right, then; come along.”
So they started, and I lit out, all in a cold sweat, and scrambled forward. It was dark as pitch there; but I said, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “Jim!” and he answered up, right at my elbow, with a sort of a moan, and I says:
“Quick, Jim, it ain’t no time for fooling around and moaning; there’s a gang of murderers in yonder, and if we don’t hunt up their boat and set her drifting down the river so these fellows can’t get away from the wreck there’s one of ’em going to be in a bad fix. But if we find their boat we can put all of ’em in a bad fix—for the Sheriff ’ll get ’em. Quick—hurry! I’ll hunt the labboard side, you hunt the stabboard. You start at the raft, and—”
“Oh, my lordy, lordy! Raf’? Dey ain’ no raf’ no mo’; she done broke loose en gone I—en here we is!”

Yes, I reck’n you are. But s’pose she don’t break up and wash off?”
“Well, we can wait the two hours anyway, and see.”
“Yes, I reck’n you can, but what are you going to do after that? Course you can’t see how she lays yet, much any more than you can tell how big a cow’s going to be by the size of the calf she’s going to have. But get up the river a little ways, and all the boats that come along AFTER the two hours is up can see her good, and they’ll come and take him off. His friends’ll be moving heaven and earth to find him. And besides, by that time, good daylight will be coming, too. You might hope to think she’d break up and wash off, but you can’t KNOW it. And if she don’t, we are in a fix. Growler’s only a cub, you know, and they’ll all be raging to have a whack at him. We better kill him now.”
“No, not now. I don’t like the idea of us killing him. We’ll leave him to drown. If she don’t break up in two hours, she ain’t going to.”
“Well, then, we’d better go.”
“All right; come along.”
They got up and started. It was pitch-dark, so I couldn’t see them. Huck, I was in a cold sweat, and shaking like a leaf. I didn’t know hardly what to do. I was so scared. But I made up my mind I would try to find the raft and get Jim away from there. I scrambled out from my place and went creeping toward where I had seen them go. I felt my way along, and pretty soon I got to a place where I could stand up. I was in the middle of the wreck, and I could hear the water rushing and roaring around me. I was afraid to move, for fear I would fall in. I stood there for a minute, and then I heard a noise. It sounded like some one groaning. I listened, and it came again. It was Jim. I whispered, “Jim!” And he answered, “Huck! Oh, Huck, I’s so glad to see you!”
“Quick, Jim, there ain’t no time to lose. There’s a gang of murderers in here, and we got to get out of here quick. They’re going to kill one of the men. We got to find their boat and cut her loose, and then they can’t get away. They’ll be trapped in here, and the sheriff will get them.”
“Oh, Huck, Huck, I’s so scared! What we gwyne to do?”
“We got to find their boat, Jim. You go one way and I’ll go the other. We’ll start from where the raft was.”
“Oh, Huck, de raft! De raft done gone! It broke loose and floated away!”
He was moaning and crying, but I didn’t have time to listen. I was so scared I didn’t know what to do. I stood there for a minute, and then I heard them coming back. I didn’t know where to hide. I looked around, and I saw a little hole in the deck. I crawled into it, and it was just big enough for me. I lay there and listened. They came right by me, and I could hear them talking. They were talking about the man they were going to kill. I was so scared I could hardly breathe. They went on, and I lay there for a long time. I didn’t know how long it was, but it seemed like hours. At last, I heard them go away again. I waited a little while, and then I crawled out of the hole. I was shaking all over. I didn’t know what to do. I was afraid to stay there, and I was afraid to go away. I stood there for a minute, and then I heard Jim call my name. I went toward the sound, and pretty soon I found him. He was still moaning and crying. I told him to hush, and I would try to think of something. I didn’t know what to do. I was so scared I couldn’t think. I stood there for a minute, and then I heard them coming back again. I didn’t know where to hide. I looked around, and I saw a little hole in the deck.

events.title: Perilous Escape from the Wreck
detailed_summary: Huck is initially overcome with fear at being trapped on a wrecked steamboat with a dangerous gang, but recognizes the urgent need to acquire their boat for his and Jim's survival.
He and Jim, who is extremely frightened and weak, nervously make their way along the steamboat's side towards the stern in search of the boat.
They eventually locate the skiff near the cross-hall door, filling Huck with immense gratitude.
Just as Huck is about to board the skiff, one of the gang members, Packard, emerges and instructs his accomplice, Bill, to conceal their lantern.
Packard and Bill then board the skiff themselves.
Bill inquires if Packard has searched their captive, Jim Turner, for his share of money.
Discovering that neither of them has secured Turner's cash, they decide it's essential to retrieve it before leaving, deeming it foolish to abandon the money.
The two men re-enter the cabin on the wreck.
The door slams shut due to the boat's tilted position, providing Huck and Jim with a critical opportunity.
Huck immediately jumps into the skiff, followed by Jim, and Huck quickly cuts the rope, allowing them to drift away silently.

Once they are a safe distance from the wreck, they observe a lantern light briefly appear at the texas door, signaling that the robbers have discovered their boat is missing and are now in a dire situation themselves.

events.text_segment:
Well, I catched my breath and most fainted. Shut up on a wreck with such a gang as that! But it warn’t no time to be sentimentering. We’d got to find that boat now—had to have it for ourselves. So we went a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was, too—seemed a week before we got to the stern. No sign of a boat. Jim said he didn’t believe he could go any further—so scared he hadn’t hardly any strength left, he said. But I said, come on, if we get left on this wreck we are in a fix, sure. So on we prowled again. We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water. When we got pretty close to the cross-hall door, there was the skiff, sure enough! I could just barely see her. I felt ever so thankful. In another second I would a been aboard of her, but just then the door opened. One of the men stuck his head out only about a couple of foot from me, and I thought I was gone; but he jerked it in again, and says:
“Heave that blame lantern out o’ sight, Bill!”
He flung a bag of something into the boat, and then got in himself and set down. It was Packard. Then Bill he come out and got in. Packard says, in a low voice:
“All ready—shove off!”
I couldn’t hardly hang on to the shutters, I was so weak. But Bill says:
“Hold on—’d you go through him?”
“No. Didn’t you?”
“No. So he’s got his share o’ the cash yet.”
“Well, then, come along; no use to take truck and leave money.”
“Say, won’t he suspicion what we’re up to?”
“Maybe he won’t. But we got to have it anyway. Come along.”
So they got out and went in.
The door slammed to because it was on the careened side; and in a half second I was in the boat, and Jim come tumbling after me. I out with my knife and cut the rope, and away we went!
We didn’t touch an oar, and we didn’t speak nor whisper, nor hardly even breathe. We went gliding swift along, dead silent, past the tip of the paddle-box, and past the stern; then in a second or two more we was a hundred yards below the wreck, and the darkness soaked her up, every last sign of her, and we was safe, and knowed it.
When we was three or four hundred yards down-stream we see the lantern show like a little spark at the texas door for a second, and we knowed by that that the rascals had missed their boat, and was beginning to understand that they was in just as much trouble now as Jim Turner was.

My eyes felt like they was glued wide open, and I couldn't swallow if I'd a-tried. It was Pap. Standing right there, not ten foot away, looking like he'd come straight out of the bad place. His face was all pale and raggedy, and his eyes had that wild, crazy look in 'em that always made my blood run cold. He had his old slouch hat pulled down low, but you could see the sweat streaks on his face and neck. He was leaning against a tree, just watching the river, and he hadn't seen me yet. I was hid good behind a thick bush, but I felt like he could smell me out, like a hound dog. All the stories about ghosts and hants and dead folks walking come a-swarming into my head, and I reckon for a minute I truly believed he was a spirit come back to torment me. My legs felt like water, and I couldn't move a muscle. I just stayed there, frozen, watching him, waiting for him to turn his head and see me. What would he do? Would he grab me and take me back to that cabin? Would he beat me again? The thought of it made me feel sick to my stomach. I wished I was dead myself, or back in Widow Douglas's house, sivilized and safe, even if it was awful tiresome. Anything was better than this. I watched him for what felt like an hour, though I reckon it warn't more'n a few minutes. He didn't move much, just shifted his weight now and then and scratched his beard. He looked powerful miserable, even for him. It was a strange thing to see. Pap, who was always raising Cain and making a fuss, just standing there quiet like, staring at the water. It made him seem almost... human, in a way that was scarier than when he was drunk and raving. Because when he was drunk, you knew what to expect. But this quietness, this stillness, it was something new and unknown, and it filled me with a dread I hadn't felt before. I started to think maybe he warn't a ghost after all, but just Pap, come back for some reason. And that thought was almost worse than the ghost one. Because if he was real, he could catch me. And if he catched me, my life on the river, my freedom, everything I'd worked for, would be over. I had to get away. I had to get away right now, before he saw me. But my body wouldn't listen. It just stayed there, trembling, watching the man who was my father and my worst nightmare, standing there by the side of the big river, looking like he belonged to the shadows.

events.title: Huck's Conscience and Foiled Rescue Plan
detailed_summary: As Jim rows them away from the wreck and towards their own raft, Huck begins to feel uneasy about the fate of the men left behind, even though they are murderers.
He reflects on the dreadful predicament of the robbers and considers that he himself might one day commit a similar crime, prompting empathy.

Huck devises a plan and explains it to Jim: they will land near the first light they spot, find a hiding place for Jim and the skiff, and then Huck will invent a story to persuade someone to rescue the gang from the wreck, with the ultimate intention that they can be properly arrested and hanged.
This plan is quickly thwarted as a severe storm erupts, making it impossible to see any lights, as everyone is presumed to be indoors.
They continue their journey downriver, keeping a lookout for any signs of light or their raft.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft.

events.text_segment:
Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft. Now was the first time that I begun to worry about the men—I reckon I hadn’t had time to before. I begun to think how dreadful it was, even for murderers, to be in such a fix. I says to myself, there ain’t no telling but I might come to be a murderer myself yet, and then how would I like it? So says I to Jim:
“The first light we see we’ll land a hundred yards below it or above it, in a place where it’s a good hiding-place for you and the skiff, and then I’ll go and fix up some kind of a yarn, and get somebody to go for that gang and get them out of their scrape, so they can be hung when their time comes.”
But that idea was a failure; for pretty soon it begun to storm again, and this time worse than ever. The rain poured down, and never a light showed; everybody in bed, I reckon. We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft.

events.title: Reclaiming the Raft and New Objective
detailed_summary: After a prolonged period, the rain subsides, and intermittent lightning flashes reveal their raft floating ahead, which they quickly head towards.
They are overjoyed to be back aboard their raft.
Shortly thereafter, they observe a light on the shore to their right.
Huck decides he will investigate the light, using the skiff which is laden with plunder the gang had stolen from the wreck.
They hastily transfer the stolen goods from the skiff to a pile on the raft.
Huck instructs Jim to continue floating downstream, to show a light when he estimates he has traveled about two miles, and to keep it burning until Huck's return.
As Huck rows towards the initial light, three or four more lights become visible on a hillside, indicating the presence of a village.
He maneuvers the skiff above the shore light, then stops rowing and allows the current to carry him as he assesses the situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I closed in above the shore light, and laid on my oars and floated.

events.text_segment:
After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.
It was the raft, and mighty glad was we to get aboard of it again. We seen a light now away down to the right, on shore. So I said I would go for it. The skiff was half full of plunder which that gang had stole there on the wreck. We hustled it on to the raft in a pile, and I told Jim to float along down, and show a light when he judged he had gone about two mile, and keep it burning till I come; then I manned my oars and shoved for the light. As I got down towards it, three or four more showed—up on a hillside. It was a village. I closed in above the shore light, and laid on my oars and floated.

events.title: Encountering the Sleeping Watchman
detailed_summary: Huck observes that the light emanates from a lantern on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat.
He searches for the ferry's watchman and finds him asleep, curled up on the bitts at the front of the vessel.
To rouse the watchman, Huck gives his shoulder a couple of gentle shoves and begins to feign crying.
The watchman awakens with a start, but upon seeing it is only Huck, he relaxes, stretches, and inquires about the cause of Huck's supposed distress, advising him not to cry.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I went by, I see it was a lantern hanging on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What’s the matter with ’em?”

events.text_segment:
As I went by, I see it was a lantern hanging on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat. I skimmed around for the watchman, a-wondering whereabouts he slept; and by-and-by I found him roosting on the bitts, forward, with his head down between his knees. I gave his shoulder two or three little shoves, and begun to cry.
He stirred up, in a kind of a startlish way; but when he see it was only me, he took a good gap and stretch, and then he says:
“Hello, what’s up? Don’t cry, bub. What’s the trouble?”

events.title: Huck Weaves a Tale of Distress
detailed_summary: Huck begins his fabricated story by tearfully mentioning his 'Pap, and mam, and sis,' then breaks off as if overcome by emotion.
The watchman attempts to console him, remarking that troubles are a common part of life and that this situation will likely resolve itself.
Huck confirms that the man is indeed the watchman of the boat.

The watchman proudly elaborates on his multiple roles aboard the ferry, including captain, owner, and pilot, and expresses contentment with his life compared to that of a wealthy local man named Jim Hornback.
Huck interrupts to declare that his family and a 'Miss Hooker' are in grave danger.
He specifies they are on the 'Walter Scott' wreck, shocking the watchman, who asks how they ended up there.

Huck launches into an elaborate, fictional account: Miss Hooker was visiting Booth's Landing and, while attempting to cross the river by horse-ferry with her servant to visit a friend, they lost their steering-oar.
He claims their ferry then drifted, collided with the wreck, and resulted in the loss of the ferryman, the servant, and the horses, with only Miss Hooker managing to scramble aboard the wreck.
Huck continues that his family's trading-scow later struck the same wreck in the darkness; all were saved except for a beloved crewman named Bill Whipple.

He explains that their cries for help went unheard due to the river's width, so he, being the only swimmer, was dispatched to seek aid, with Miss Hooker instructing him to find her uncle if other help failed.
Huck claims he has been trying to get assistance but has been unsuccessful due to the bad weather and strong current, and now he is pleading with the watchman.

events.text_segment:
I says:
“Pap, and mam, and sis, and—”
Then I broke down. He says:
“Oh, dang it now, don’t take on so; we all has to have our troubles, and this’n ’ll come out all right. What’s the matter with ’em?”
“They’re—they’re—are you the watchman of the boat?”
“Yes,” he says, kind of pretty-well-satisfied like. “I’m the captain and the owner and the mate and the pilot and watchman and head deck-hand; and sometimes I’m the freight and passengers. I ain’t as rich as old Jim Hornback, and I can’t be so blame’ generous and good to Tom, Dick and Harry as what he is, and slam around money the way he does; but I’ve told him a many a time ’t I wouldn’t trade places with him; for, says I, a sailor’s life’s the life for me, and I’m derned if I’d live two mile out o’ town, where there ain’t nothing ever goin’ on, not for all his spondulicks and as much more on top of it. Says I—”
I broke in and says:
“They’re in an awful peck of trouble, and—”
“Who is?”
“Why, pap and mam and sis and Miss Hooker; and if you’d take your ferry-boat and go up there—”
“Up where? Where are they?”
“On the wreck.”
“What wreck?”
“Why, there ain’t but one.”
“What, you don’t mean the Walter Scott?”
“Yes.”
“Good land! what are they doin’ there, for gracious sakes?”
“Well, they didn’t go there a-purpose.”
“I bet they didn’t! Why, great goodness, there ain’t no chance for ’em if they don’t git off mighty quick! Why, how in the nation did they ever git into such a scrape?”
“Easy enough. Miss Hooker was a-visiting up there to the town—”
“Yes, Booth’s Landing—go on.”
“She was a-visiting there at Booth’s Landing, and just in the edge of the evening she started over with her nigger woman in the horse-ferry to stay all night at her friend’s house, Miss What-you-may-call-her I disremember her name—and they lost their steering-oar, and swung around and went a-floating down, stern first, about two mile, and saddle-baggsed on the wreck, and the ferryman and the nigger woman and the horses was all lost, but Miss Hooker she made a grab and got aboard the wreck. Well, about an hour after dark we come along down in our trading-scow, and it was so dark we didn’t notice the wreck till we was right on it; and so we saddle-baggsed; but all of us was saved but Bill Whipple—and oh, he was the best cretur!—I most wish’t it had been me, I do.”
“My George! It’s the beatenest thing I ever struck. And then what did you all do?”
“Well, we hollered and took on, but it’s so wide there we couldn’t make nobody hear. So pap said somebody got to get ashore and get help somehow. I was the only one that could swim, so I made a dash for it, and Miss Hooker she said if I didn’t strike help sooner, come here and hunt up her uncle, and he’d fix the thing. I made the land about a mile below, and been fooling along ever since, trying to get people to do something, but they said, ‘What, in such a night and such a current? There ain’t no sense in it; go for the steam ferry.’ Now if you’ll go and—”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I says:
“Pap, and mam, and sis, and—”
Then I broke down. I couldn’t seem to stand it any longer, and begun to cry.
“Good friend,” says the man, kind of soothing up to me, “don’t you take on so—there’s troubles enough in life without borrowing more; here—take a hunk of this; it’s good, and it’ll comfort you.”
So he shoved the bottle to me. I took a drink, and now I felt better according to what you might say, but still I didn’t feel good enough to stop crying, so I kept on. The man said:
“Come now, set right down and tell me all about it, and don’t hold nothing back. I know what you’ve been through; you feel distressed and discouraged, and you ain’t got no resort but me. (Well, his eyes lit up when he said that; and I knowed what was the reason, too. He thought he was going to get some praise, and maybe money, you know.) I started in to tell him, and told him the plain truth, and I didn’t leave nothing out. I told him all about pap, and what he done, and how he shut me up, and what a dreadful time I had till I got away. I finished up with telling about him and Mary Jane two year ago, and he fetched up a sigh that you could hear a mile off, and says:
“Ain’t your pap pretty hard upon you?”
“He ain’t no harder than what he used to be, and ain’t a mite better.”

“Johnny.”

events.title: Securing the "Rescue" through Deception
detailed_summary: The watchman expresses a desire to help but voices concern over who will compensate him for using the ferry.
Huck quickly assures him that 'Miss Hooker' specifically mentioned her uncle, Hornback, who is known to be wealthy, would cover all expenses.
The mention of Jim Hornback as Miss Hooker's uncle dramatically shifts the watchman's attitude from hesitant to enthusiastic.
The watchman excitedly instructs Huck to go to a nearby light, find a tavern a quarter-mile west of it, and tell them to take him to Jim Hornback's residence, stating Hornback will 'foot the bill.'
He urges Huck to hurry, emphasizing that Hornback will be anxious for news, and promises to ensure the niece's safety even before Hornback can arrive in town.
The watchman then departs to find his engineer, telling Huck to be quick.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “By Jackson, I’d	like	to, and, blame it, I don’t know but I will; but who in the dingnation’s a-going’ to	pay	for it?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Hump yourself, now; I’m a-going up around the corner here to roust out my engineer.”

events.text_segment:
“By Jackson, I’d like to, and, blame it, I don’t know but I will; but who in the dingnation’s a-going’ to pay for it? Do you reckon your pap—”
“Why that’s all right. Miss Hooker she tole me, particular, that her uncle Hornback—”
“Great guns! is he her uncle? Looky here, you break for that light over yonder-way, and turn out west when you git there, and about a quarter of a mile out you’ll come to the tavern; tell ’em to dart you out to Jim Hornback’s, and he’ll foot the bill. And don’t you fool around any, because he’ll want to know the news. Tell him I’ll have his niece all safe before he can get to town. Hump yourself, now; I’m a-going up around the corner here to roust out my engineer.”

events.title: Huck's Solitary Vigil and Grim Realization
detailed_summary: Instead of following the watchman's directions to find Jim Hornback, Huck quietly returns to his skiff, bails out the water, and conceals himself among some woodboats about six hundred yards upshore, wanting to witness the ferry-boat's departure.

He experiences a sense of satisfaction for having gone to such trouble for the gang of robbers, believing that the Widow Douglas would be proud of his efforts to help 'rapscallions,' a type of person she and other good people often showed interest in.
Before long, the wreck itself appears, drifting down the river, looking dim, dusky, and very low in the water.
A cold shiver passes through Huck as he rows out towards it; he quickly assesses that there is little chance anyone could still be alive on the deeply submerged vessel.
He circles the wreck, calling out, but receives no response, confirming that all aboard have perished.
Huck feels a brief sense of sorrow for the gang's fate but quickly rationalizes that if they could endure their situation, he could endure knowing about it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I struck for the light, but as soon as he turned the corner I went back and got into my skiff and bailed her out, and then pulled up shore in the easy water about six hundred yards, and tucked myself in among some woodboats; for I couldn’t rest easy till I could see the ferry-boat start.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I felt a little bit heavy-hearted about the gang, but not much, for I reckoned if they could stand it, I could.

events.text_segment:
I struck for the light, but as soon as he turned the corner I went back and got into my skiff and bailed her out, and then pulled up shore in the easy water about six hundred yards, and tucked myself in among some woodboats; for I couldn’t rest easy till I could see the ferry-boat start. But take it all around, I was feeling ruther comfortable on accounts of taking all this trouble for that gang, for not many would a done it. I wished the widow knowed about it. I judged she would be proud of me for helping these rapscallions, because rapscallions and dead beats is the kind the widow and good people takes the most interest in.
Well, before long, here comes the wreck, dim and dusky, sliding along down! A kind of cold shiver went through me, and then I struck out for her. She was very deep, and I see in a minute there warn’t much chance for anybody being alive in her. I pulled all around her and hollered a little, but there wasn’t any answer; all dead still. I felt a little bit heavy-hearted about the gang, but not much, for I reckoned if they could stand it, I could.

events.title: The Futile Search and Huck's Renewed Journey
detailed_summary: The ferry-boat arrives on the scene, prompting Huck to row his skiff towards the middle of the river on a downstream angle until he believes he is out of sight.
He then stops rowing and observes the ferry-boat as it circles and investigates the wreck, presuming the captain is searching for 'Miss Hooker's remainders' to satisfy her uncle, Jim Hornback.
After some time, the ferry-boat abandons its search and heads back towards the shore.
Seeing this, Huck vigorously resumes rowing, heading swiftly downriver to find Jim.
The journey to locate Jim's signal light feels extraordinarily long, and when it finally becomes visible, it appears to be a vast distance away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then here comes the ferry-boat; so I shoved for the middle of the river on a long down-stream slant; and when I judged I was out of eye-reach, I laid on my oars, and looked back and see her go and smell around the wreck for Miss Hooker’s remainders, because the captain would know her uncle Hornback would want them; and then pretty soon the ferry-boat give it up and went for the shore, and I laid into my work and went a-booming down the river.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It did seem a powerful long time before Jim’s light showed up; and when it did show, it looked like it was a thousand mile off.

events.text_segment:
Then here comes the ferry-boat; so I shoved for the middle of the river on a long down-stream slant; and when I judged I was out of eye-reach, I laid on my oars, and looked back and see her go and smell around the wreck for Miss Hooker’s remainders, because the captain would know her uncle Hornback would want them; and then pretty soon the ferry-boat give it up and went for the shore, and I laid into my work and went a-booming down the river.
It did seem a powerful long time before Jim’s light showed up; and when it did show, it looked like it was a thousand mile off.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Then here comes the ferry-boat; so I shoved for the middle of the river on a long down-stream slant; and when I judged I was out of eye-reach, I laid on my oars, and looked back and see her go and smell around the wreck for Miss Hooker’s remainders, because the captain would know her uncle Hornback would want them; and then pretty soon the ferry-boat give it up and went for the shore, and I laid into my work and went a-booming down the river. It was a most awful long time I judge before I see the light. The sky was clear; and I run it mought be three mile, and then laid to and floated. I done this three or four times, and then I see a light at a big long island which I judged was the upper end of the island where we camped, and I come in there towards the lower end, which was in a cove that you could hardly see from the river. I begun to be afraid he hadn’t got here yet; so I looked all about, but couldn’t see nothing. Then I begun to shout! and pretty soon I heard a ‘Whoo-oop!’ away down the island. And then I sung out, ‘Halloa!’ and got the ‘Whoo-oop!’ again. So I judged I was all right, and sung out, ‘Come along, Jim.’ And he sung out, ‘Huck? Is dat you?’ ‘It’s me, Jim,’ I sung back. ‘Dah you is, den! Thank God we’s alive. I ben a-holtich my bref till I mos’ lose my wind. Huck, set down and listen to me.’

I done this three or four times, and then I see a light at a big long island which I judged was the upper end of the island where we camped, and I come in there towards the lower end, which was in a cove that you could hardly see from the river. I begun to be afraid he hadn’t got here yet; so I looked all about, but couldn’t see nothing. Then I begun to shout! and pretty soon I heard a ‘Whoo-oop!’ away down the island. And then I sung out, ‘Halloa!’ and got the ‘Whoo-oop!’ again. So I judged I was all right, and sung out, ‘Come along, Jim.’ And he sung out, ‘Huck? Is dat you?’ ‘It’s me, Jim,’ I sung back. ‘Dah you is, den! Thank God we’s alive. I ben a-holtich my bref till I mos’ lose my wind. Huck, set down and listen to me.’

events.title: Reunion and Rest
detailed_summary: Huck finally reaches Jim's location as the eastern sky begins to show the first signs of dawn.
Together, they navigate towards a nearby island to seek refuge.
Upon reaching the island, they carefully conceal their raft from view.
They then deliberately sink their skiff to further ensure they remain undiscovered.
Utterly exhausted by the night's events, both Huck and Jim fall into a profound sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By the time I got there the sky was beginning to get a little gray in the east; so we struck for an island, and hid the raft, and sunk the skiff, and turned in and slept like dead people.

events.title: Discovery of Riches and Jim's Fear of Further Adventures
detailed_summary: Huck and Jim discover a trove of valuable items including boots, blankets, clothes, books, a spyglass, and cigars from the truck stolen by the gang from the wrecked steamboat.
They feel exceptionally wealthy, a novel experience for both, and spend a relaxing afternoon in the woods, with Jim smoking cigars and Huck reading.
Huck recounts his experiences inside the steamboat wreck and at the ferry-boat, portraying these dangerous encounters as adventures.
Jim vehemently states he desires no more such adventures, expressing the profound terror he felt when he returned to the raft to find it, and Huck, gone.

He explains his grim predicament: if he hadn't been saved from the river, he would have drowned; conversely, if rescued by someone else, he would inevitably be returned to Miss Watson for the reward, leading to being sold further South.
Huck concedes that Jim's assessment was correct, acknowledging Jim's consistently sound judgment and remarkable level-headedness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By-and-by, when we got up, we turned over the truck the gang had stole off of the wreck, and found boots, and blankets, and clothes, and all sorts of other things, and a lot of books, and a spyglass, and three boxes of seegars.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Well, he was right; he was most always right; he had an uncommon level head, for a nigger.

events.text_segment: By-and-by, when we got up, we turned over the truck the gang had stole off of the wreck, and found boots, and blankets, and clothes, and all sorts of other things, and a lot of books, and a spyglass, and three boxes of seegars. We hadn’t ever been this rich before in neither of our lives. The seegars was prime. We laid off all the afternoon in the woods talking, and me reading the books, and having a general good time. I told Jim all about what happened inside the wreck and at the ferry-boat, and I said these kinds of things was adventures; but he said he didn’t want no more adventures. He said that when I went in the texas and he crawled back to get on the raft and found her gone, he nearly died; because he judged it was all up with him, anyway it could be fixed; for if he didn’t get saved he would get drownded; and if he did get saved, whoever saved him would send him back home so as to get the reward, and then Miss Watson would sell him South, sure. Well, he was right; he was most always right; he had an uncommon level head, for a nigger.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
CHAPTER XIV.

By-and-by, when we got up, we turned over the truck the gang had stole off of the wreck, and found boots, and blankets, and clothes, and all sorts of other things, and a lot of books, and a spyglass, and three boxes of seegars. We hadn't ever been this rich before, in neither of our lives. The seegars was prime. We laid off all the afternoon in the woods, talking, and Huck reading the books, and having a general good time. I told Jim all about what happened inside the wreck, and at the ferry-boat, and I said you couldn't hardly see a body but you could see just how awful still and solemn they was on the raft, and how you didn't dare to say a word, or stir. Jim said it made him all over trembly and feverish to be so close to danger. Wasnt't ever a sounder man than what he was, he said, and hadn't no more right to see less trouble than anybody else. He said that that was the trouble about raftin'. You couldn't keep from seeing things, and knowing things. He said he reckoned a body that was bound to get into trouble anyway, couldn't help it, and that he didn't see no sense in trying to dodge it. But he said he reckoned the best way to get along was to let it alone, and not meddle with it. He said he didn't want no more adventures. He said that when I went off to the ferry-boat, he begun to think he was dead. He said that if I hadn't come back he'd never have felt safe again. He said that if I'd got drowned, he wouldn't have cared for himself, because he couldn't have got out of the river, and if he had, nobody would have helped him, and he would have been caught and sold down the river. He said that he reckoned I was the best friend he ever had, and that he didn't know what he would have done without me. He said that he reckoned I was the best friend he ever had, and that he didn't know what he would have done without me. I said that I reckoned he was the best friend I ever had, and that I didn't know what I would have done without him. We laid there and talked, and smoked, and read, and had a general good time. By-and-by, we got up and went to the raft, and had supper. Then we laid down and went to sleep. It was a mighty nice day.

events.title: Huck Educates Jim on Royalty and Harems
detailed_summary: Huck reads to Jim about the lives of kings, dukes, and earls, detailing their elaborate clothing, formal titles like 'your majesty,' and the grand style they maintained.
Jim is visibly captivated and expresses surprise at the sheer number of such individuals, having only vaguely heard of King Solomon and kings from playing cards.
He inquires about a king's income, to which Huck explains they receive a thousand dollars a month or essentially anything they want, as everything belongs to them.
Jim marvels at this and asks about the duties and responsibilities of a king.
Huck clarifies that kings mostly 'just set around,' unless there's a war, or they 'fuss with the parlyment,' and can even order executions.
He also adds that kings often spend time in their harems, a concept Jim doesn't initially understand.
Huck explains a harem as the place where a king keeps his numerous wives, citing King Solomon as an example who supposedly had millions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I read considerable to Jim about kings and dukes and earls and such, and how gaudy they dressed, and how much style they put on, and called each other your majesty, and your grace, and your lordship, and so on, ’stead of mister; and Jim’s eyes bugged out, and he was interested.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Solomon had one; he had about a million wives.”

events.text_segment:
I read considerable to Jim about kings and dukes and earls and such, and how gaudy they dressed, and how much style they put on, and called each other your majesty, and your grace, and your lordship, and so on, ’stead of mister; and Jim’s eyes bugged out, and he was interested. He says:
“I didn’ know dey was so many un um. I hain’t hearn ’bout none un um, skasely, but ole King Sollermun, onless you counts dem kings dat’s in a pack er k’yards. How much do a king git?”
“Get?” I says; “why, they get a thousand dollars a month if they want it; they can have just as much as they want; everything belongs to them.”
“Ain’ dat gay? En what dey got to do, Huck?”
“They don’t do nothing! Why, how you talk! They just set around.”
“No; is dat so?”
“Of course it is. They just set around—except, maybe, when there’s a war; then they go to the war. But other times they just lazy around; or go hawking—just hawking and sp— Sh!—d’ you hear a noise?”
We skipped out and looked; but it warn’t nothing but the flutter of a steamboat’s wheel away down, coming around the point; so we come back.
“Yes,” says I, “and other times, when things is dull, they fuss with the parlyment; and if everybody don’t go just so he whacks their heads off. But mostly they hang round the harem.”
“Roun’ de which?”
“Harem.”
“What’s de harem?”
“The place where he keeps his wives. Don’t you know about the harem? Solomon had one; he had about a million wives.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I read considerable to Jim about kings and dukes and earls and such, and how gaudy they dressed, and how much style they put on, and called each other your majesty, and your grace, and your lordship, and so on, ’stead of mister; and Jim’s eyes bugged out, and he was interested. He says:
“I didn’ know dey was so many un um. I only hearn ’bout ole King Sollermun, on account er his wisdom. But I s’pose dey was kings in dem days, too.”
“Yes,” I says; “but not so many; not near so many. D’you know about King Sollermun?”
“Yes, sah, I do know ’bout King Sollermun, leastways I heard bout him; en I take it he wuz boun’ to be de wises’ man dat ever live. Case why? It says in de Bible he warn’t no slouch. He kep’ on a-buildin’ de temple for sev’n year, en I bet you it wuz a super-grand affair, too. En mo’ dan dat, he had fo’ hundred wives, en about fifteen hundred chillen. En besides dat, he was into all kinds o’ diggin’s—dat king was.”
“All right,” I says; “then I reckon we better not talk about him any more, but talk about kings in general.”
“All right,” he says; “but hang it, I do wish you would git him to tell me what he charged them wives for boardin’. Some of ’em was boun’ to been right pertickler, bout eatin’, en dat would make it come pretty high. You see, I hain’t got no patience wid people dat don’t know dis en dat.”
“Well, Jim, you see it warn’t no use to ask him; it’s all in the books.”
“Well, dey ain’t no sense in a king not having patience with people dat don’t know dis en dat. Why, I couldn’t get along wid ’em myself.”
“Well, Jim, you see he was a king, and kings don’t have to have no patience; they can do what they please.”
“But dey can’t do what dey please! Dey got to do what dey please! En dat’s de trouble. I knowed a king once, en he warn’t no slouch, nuther. He allowed they was powerful rich, and he couldn’t understand why they didn’t have to work. I told him they didn’t do nothing but set around and boss, and everybody had to mind them. He said it didn’t seem right, a man not doing no work and having everything. I told him that was just the way kings was. I read him about old King Solomon and how he was the wisest man, but Jim couldn’t see no wisdom in a man that had a houseful of wives and was always chopping babies in two. He said that wasn’t wise, that was just plain foolishness. He reckoned if he was a king, he’d do things different. He’d get him a whole raft of money and buy his family out of slavery and live free. He couldn’t get over the idea of folks being so rich and lazy. It beat him. He said he wouldn’t trade places with no king he ever heard tell of, not if he had to wear them fancy clothes and talk like that. He liked being Jim, and being free, or aiming to be.

events.title: Jim's Pragmatic Critique of King Solomon's Wisdom
detailed_summary: Jim, upon understanding the concept of a harem, likens it to a constantly noisy boarding house, filled with quarreling wives and children, and questions King Solomon's reputed wisdom for choosing to live in such chaos.
He humorously suggests a truly wise man would build a boiler factory, which could at least be shut down for peace and quiet.
Huck attempts to defend Solomon's wisdom by stating that the Widow Douglas affirmed it.
Jim dismisses the widow's opinion and proceeds to criticize Solomon's famous judgment regarding the child to be cut in two.
He uses a dollar bill as an analogy, tearing it in half to illustrate that half a child, like half a dollar bill, is useless and cannot resolve a dispute about a whole child.

Jim argues that Solomon's willingness to consider such an action stems from having an overabundance of children ('bout five million'), which desensitized him to their value, unlike a man with only one or two children who would cherish them.
He concludes that Solomon's problem was not a lack of general intelligence but a specific inability to appreciate the worth of individual children due to his vast number of offspring.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Why, yes, dat’s so; I—I’d done forgot it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A chile er two, mo’ er less, warn’t no consekens to Sollermun, dad fatch him!”

events.text_segment:
“Why, yes, dat’s so; I—I’d done forgot it. A harem’s a bo’d’n-house, I reck’n. Mos’ likely dey has rackety times in de nussery. En I reck’n de wives quarrels considable; en dat ’crease de racket. Yit dey say Sollermun de wises’ man dat ever live’. I doan’ take no stock in dat. Bekase why: would a wise man want to live in de mids’ er sich a blim-blammin’ all de time? No—’deed he wouldn’t. A wise man ’ud take en buil’ a biler-factry; en den he could shet down de biler-factry when he want to res’.”
“Well, but he was the wisest man, anyway; because the widow she told me so, her own self.”
“I doan k’yer what de widder say, he warn’t no wise man nuther. He had some er de dad-fetchedes’ ways I ever see. Does you know ’bout dat chile dat he ’uz gwyne to chop in two?”
“Yes, the widow told me all about it.”
“Well, den! Warn’ dat de beatenes’ notion in de worl’? You jes’ take en look at it a minute. Dah’s de stump, dah—dat’s one er de women; heah’s you—dat’s de yuther one; I’s Sollermun; en dish yer dollar bill’s de chile. Bofe un you claims it. What does I do? Does I shin aroun’ mongs’ de neighbors en fine out which un you de bill do b’long to, en han’ it over to de right one, all safe en soun’, de way dat anybody dat had any gumption would? No; I take en whack de bill in two, en give half un it to you, en de yuther half to de yuther woman. Dat’s de way Sollermun was gwyne to do wid de chile. Now I want to ast you: what’s de use er dat half a bill?—can’t buy noth’n wid it. En what use is a half a chile? I wouldn’ give a dern for a million un um.”
“But hang it, Jim, you’ve clean missed the point—blame it, you’ve missed it a thousand mile.”
“Who? Me? Go ’long. Doan’ talk to me ’bout yo’ pints. I reck’n I knows sense when I sees it; en dey ain’ no sense in sich doin’s as dat. De ’spute warn’t ’bout a half a chile, de ’spute was ’bout a whole chile; en de man dat think he kin settle a ’spute ’bout a whole chile wid a half a chile doan’ know enough to come in out’n de rain. Doan’ talk to me ’bout Sollermun, Huck, I knows him by de back.”
“But I tell you you don’t get the point.”
“Blame de point! I reck’n I knows what I knows. En mine you, de real pint is down furder—it’s down deeper. It lays in de way Sollermun was raised. You take a man dat’s got on’y one or two chillen; is dat man gwyne to be waseful o’ chillen? No, he ain’t; he can’t ’ford it. He know how to value ’em. But you take a man dat’s got ’bout five million chillen runnin’ roun’ de house, en it’s diffunt. He as soon chop a chile in two as a cat. Dey’s plenty mo’. A chile er two, mo’ er less, warn’t no consekens to Sollermun, dad fatch him!”

“Why, yes, dat’s so; I—I’d done forgot it. Dat’s what I’s a-gwyne to say; dey’s some things dat ain’t so for a man to have. Take dat King Sollermun, he had five million wives. Now, I say, dat ain’t no sense. A man can’t have five million wives and be happy. It’s jes’ like a boardin’-house; dey’s always a-quarrelin’ and a-fussin’ and a-makin’ a racket. A wise man wouldn’t live in no sich place. No, sah, a wise man he’d build a biler-factory; and den, when he want peace and quiet, he jes’ shut down de biler-factory.”

“Well, the Widow she told me he was the wisest man that ever lived.”

You can’t do nuffin wid half a chile. It’s jes’ like a dollar bill; you can’t spend half a dollar bill. It ain’t no good to nobody.”
