events.title: Huck Eavesdrops on the Conmen's Scheme
detailed_summary: Resolved to act, Huck decides to search the King's and Duke's rooms for the hidden money.
He creeps upstairs into the dark hall, first checking the Duke's room, but then reasons that the King would be the one to keep control of the gold.
Entering the King's room, he realizes he cannot search effectively in the darkness without a candle, which he dares not light.
He then decides his best course of action is to hide and eavesdrop on the conmen.

Just as he hears their footsteps approaching, he intends to slip under the bed but cannot locate it immediately; instead, he touches the calico curtain shielding Mary Jane's dresses and quickly hides behind it.
The King and Duke enter the room and shut the door; the Duke's first action is to look under the bed, making Huck glad he hadn't hidden there.
They sit down, and the King, impatient to rejoin the 'mourners' downstairs to maintain their facade, asks the Duke to be brief.

The Duke expresses his unease, particularly his worry about Dr. Robinson, and reveals his plan: he thinks they should leave quietly before three in the morning with the gold they've acquired, especially since it was returned to them so easily.
This news causes Huck some distress, as his recent decision to help the Wilks sisters had made him hope the conmen would stay longer, giving him more time to act.
The King vehemently rejects the Duke's idea, aghast at the thought of leaving without selling the remaining property, which he estimates is worth eight or nine thousand dollars.
The Duke grumbles, stating the bag of gold is sufficient and expresses reluctance to rob the orphans of everything they possess.

The King callously dismisses the Duke's concerns, arguing they are only taking the money and that the future buyers of the property will be the ones to suffer, as the sales will be invalidated once the fraud is discovered. He claims the orphans will get their house back and, being young, can easily earn a living and have nothing to complain about.
The King's arguments eventually sway the Duke, who reluctantly agrees to stay, though he still believes it foolish, especially with Dr. Robinson posing a threat.
The King confidently dismisses the doctor, boasting that they have all the 'fools in town' on their side, which constitutes a sufficient majority.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And ain’t that a big enough majority in any town?”

events.text_segment:
So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms. Upstairs the hall was dark, but I found the duke’s room, and started to paw around it with my hands; but I recollected it wouldn’t be much like the king to let anybody else take care of that money but his own self; so then I went to his room and begun to paw around there. But I see I couldn’t do nothing without a candle, and I dasn’t light one, of course. So I judged I’d got to do the other thing—lay for them and eavesdrop. About that time I hears their footsteps coming, and was going to skip under the bed; I reached for it, but it wasn’t where I thought it would be; but I touched the curtain that hid Mary Jane’s frocks, so I jumped in behind that and snuggled in amongst the gowns, and stood there perfectly still.
They come in and shut the door; and the first thing the duke done was to get down and look under the bed. Then I was glad I hadn’t found the bed when I wanted it. And yet, you know, it’s kind of natural to hide under the bed when you are up to anything private. They sets down then, and the king says:
“Well, what is it? And cut it middlin’ short, because it’s better for us to be down there a-whoopin’ up the mournin’ than up here givin’ ’em a chance to talk us over.”
“Well, this is it, Capet. I ain’t easy; I ain’t comfortable. That doctor lays on my mind. I wanted to know your plans. I’ve got a notion, and I think it’s a sound one.”
“What is it, duke?”
“That we better glide out of this before three in the morning, and clip it down the river with what we’ve got. Specially, seeing we got it so easy—given back to us, flung at our heads, as you may say, when of course we allowed to have to steal it back. I’m for knocking off and lighting out.”
That made me feel pretty bad. About an hour or two ago it would a been a little different, but now it made me feel bad and disappointed, The king rips out and says:
“What! And not sell out the rest o’ the property? March off like a passel of fools and leave eight or nine thous’n’ dollars’ worth o’ property layin’ around jest sufferin’ to be scooped in?—and all good, salable stuff, too.”
The duke he grumbled; said the bag of gold was enough, and he didn’t want to go no deeper—didn’t want to rob a lot of orphans of everything they had.
“Why, how you talk!” says the king. “We sha’n’t rob ’em of nothing at all but jest this money. The people that buys the property is the suff’rers; because as soon ’s it’s found out ’at we didn’t own it—which won’t be long after we’ve slid—the sale won’t be valid, and it’ll all go back to the estate. These yer orphans ’ll git their house back agin, and that’s enough for them; they’re young and spry, and k’n easy earn a livin’. They ain’t a-goin to suffer. Why, jest think—there’s thous’n’s and thous’n’s that ain’t nigh so well off. Bless you, they ain’t got noth’n’ to complain of.”
Well, the king he talked him blind; so at last he give in, and said all right, but said he believed it was blamed foolishness to stay, and that doctor hanging over them. But the king says:
“Cuss the doctor! What do we k’yer for him? Hain’t we got all the fools in town on our side? And ain’t that a big enough majority in any town?”

```text
So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms. I felt kind of ornery and humble, because I knowed very well I warn’t rightly doing a Christian act; but I just said to myself, I’ve gone in for it now, and it’ll be a considerable sight better to go through with it and get some use out of it than to stop and back out and wince and sweat and feel silly. So I slid out and shinned up the lightning-rod. Pretty soon I was in the garret, and I slid along the ridge-pole till I got over the right place, and then I scrabbled down the roof. There was an old stove-pipe sticking up through the roof, and I took that for a hint to find the room with; but it warn’t nothin’ to what I expected, but I got to the window and clumb in and shut it soft.

I was in the dark, but I knew where I was. I felt around and found the door, and slipped out and down the hall to the front stairs. I crept up them, and stopped and listened; not a sound. I crep’ along the upper hall, too, feeling my way, and found the Duke’s door and stood there a minute to see if I could hear anything. Well, no, I couldn’t; so I reckoned he was asleep. I passed on, and stopped at the King’s door. I was awful glad to find it open, and I slid in and shut it after me. I stood in the dark and listened. The house was perfectly still. I felt around for the bed, but I couldn’t find it. I couldn’t see a thing, and I dasn’t strike a match, because the minute a match was touched the light would streak out under the door. So I reckoned I’d better not search till I’d got a light. I was just about to give it up and go down again when I heard a noise. It was the King and the Duke coming up the stairs.

I was in a fix now. I didn’t know where to hide. I felt around for the bed again, but I couldn’t find it. I was getting desperate. I heard them coming nearer and nearer. I touched something soft and calico-like – it was the curtain that hung in front of Mary Jane’s dresses. I slipped behind it quick as a cat, and just as I got hid they came in and shut the door.

The first thing the Duke done was to look under the bed. That made me feel pretty comfortable, because I was glad I hadn’t hid there. They sat down, and the King says:

“Well, what is it? Hurry up, because I want to get back amongst the mourners and do a little more consoling.”

“Oh, you do, do you?” says the Duke. “Well, I’ll tell you what I think. I think we’re in a mighty tight place. I don’t like the looks of things at all. That Dr. Robinson is a sharp one. I wish we was out of this.”

“Out of it? What do you mean?”

“I mean,” says the Duke, “that we’ve got the money, and I think we ought to slide out with it before three o’clock this morning. It was mighty easy come, and I think it’s best to take it and leave the rest.”

This was a stinger. I had made up my mind to steal the money and hide it, and then tell Mary Jane about these frauds. I had reckoned on them staying a day or two longer, so I could get it done. Now they were talking about leaving right away. It made me feel sick.

The King says, “What! Leave eight or nine thousand dollars’ worth of property behind? Are you crazy? We ain’t going to leave till we’ve sold off everything.”

“But,” says the Duke, “we’ve got six thousand dollars here in this bag. Ain’t that enough? I don’t like the idea of stripping these poor orphans clean.”

“Stripping them clean!” says the King. “Why, we ain’t stripping them clean. We’re only taking the money. The people that buy the property will be the ones that get stripped when the fraud is found out. These orphans will get their house back, and they’re young and can earn a living. They ain’t got nothing to complain about.”

The Duke grumbled a little more, but the King talked him over. He agreed to stay, but he still looked worried.

“I don’t like that doctor,” he says.

“Pshaw!” says the King. “We’ve got all the fools in town on our side, and that’s a big enough majority.”
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms. It was a big house, quiet as a graveyard at midnight, and the moon was shining in through the windows, making long, spooky shadows that danced around like ghosts whenever a cloud went over. My heart was thumping like a drum, but I reckoned I had to do it. Pap always said you got to face things, even if they make your knees knock together like castanets. I slipped off my shoes so I wouldn't make no noise, and started with the parlor. It was all fancy, with stiff-backed chairs and a big fireplace that looked like it hadn't had a fire in it for a hundred years. There was a big picture on the wall of a woman with eyes that seemed to follow you, and I didn't much like that. I peeked behind the curtains, under the table, and even in a big china cabinet, careful not to rattle none of the dishes. Nothing. Just dust and the smell of old furniture. Next was the dining room. A long table covered with a white cloth, and more stiff chairs. A big sideboard with silver things that gleamed in the moonlight. I opened the drawers slow and quiet. Just napkins and forks and spoons. Nothing hidden, nothing secret. I felt a bit disappointed, and a bit relieved too. It's a funny feeling, wanting to find something but being scared of what it might be. I moved on to a room that looked like a study. Books everywhere, piled high on shelves and even on the floor. A big desk in the middle. I went through the drawers of the desk. Papers, pens, ink bottles, but nothing that looked like money or anything valuable. One drawer was stuck, and I had to wiggle it a bit, making a little squeak that sounded like a cannon shot in the quiet house. I froze, listening, but nobody stirred. I finally got it open, and it was just full of old letters tied up with ribbon. I didn't bother reading them. Letters ain't never told me nothing useful. There was a big armchair by the window, and I even felt under the cushion, just in case. Still nothing. I was starting to think this was a fool's errand. Maybe there wasn't nothing to find. But I had come this far, so I reckoned I might as well finish. There were a couple more rooms upstairs, and I figured I'd tackle them next. The stairs creaked a little, no matter how careful I was, and I held my breath with every step. Up there, it was darker, and the shadows seemed thicker. The first room was a bedroom. A big bed with a quilt, a dresser, and a washstand. I looked under the bed, in the dresser drawers, and in the closet. Just clothes and blankets. The air felt cold in there, and I shivered, though it wasn't really cold. It was just the quiet and the dark getting to me. The last room was smaller, maybe a child's room once. A little bed, a small chest. I checked them all. Nothing. I stood in the middle of the room, feeling the silence press in on me. I hadn't found a single thing. No treasure, no secrets, nothing hidden away. Just empty rooms and old furniture. I reckoned it was time to get out of there before the moon went down and left me in total darkness. My search hadn't turned up nothing, but at least I knew for sure. Sometimes knowing there's nothing is just as important as finding something, I s'pose. I crept back down the stairs, just as quiet as I could, and slipped out the way I came in, leaving the spooky old house to the moon and the shadows.

events.title: The Gold is Re-hidden and Immediately Stolen by Huck
detailed_summary: As the King and Duke prepare to go back downstairs, the Duke voices his opinion that they haven't hidden the money in a secure location.
This comment encourages Huck, who had been hoping for a clue to the money's whereabouts.

The Duke elaborates on his concern: Mary Jane will be in mourning, and the servant who tends to the rooms might be instructed to pack away Mary Jane's dresses and could stumble upon the money if it's among them, potentially 'borrowing' some.
The King concedes the Duke's point and approaches the curtain where Huck is concealed, fumbling nearby.
Huck remains pressed against the wall, motionless despite his trepidation, briefly contemplating his options if discovered.
Before Huck can fully form a plan, the King retrieves the bag of gold without suspecting Huck's presence.

The conmen then tear a hole in the straw tick mattress beneath the feather bed, stuff the bag of gold deep inside the straw, and declare it safe, reasoning that servants only make up the feather bed and rarely disturb the straw tick.
However, Huck, having witnessed their actions, knows better.
He seizes the opportunity and removes the money from the straw tick before the King and Duke are even halfway down the stairs.

He quickly takes the gold to his own cubby and hides it there temporarily, planning to find a more secure hiding spot outside the house later to prevent its discovery should the conmen realize it's missing and search the premises.
Still fully clothed and too agitated by the night's events to sleep, Huck waits tensely.
He hears the King and Duke return and go to their rooms; he positions himself at the top of his ladder to observe, but nothing further happens.
Huck waits patiently until the house is completely quiet, between the cessation of late-night sounds and the onset of early morning ones, before finally slipping down his ladder.

events.text_segment:
So they got ready to go down stairs again. The duke says:
“I don’t think we put that money in a good place.”
That cheered me up. I’d begun to think I warn’t going to get a hint of no kind to help me. The king says:
“Why?”
“Because Mary Jane ’ll be in mourning from this out; and first you know the nigger that does up the rooms will get an order to box these duds up and put ’em away; and do you reckon a nigger can run across money and not borrow some of it?”
“Your head’s level agin, duke,” says the king; and he comes a-fumbling under the curtain two or three foot from where I was. I stuck tight to the wall and kept mighty still, though quivery; and I wondered what them fellows would say to me if they catched me; and I tried to think what I’d better do if they did catch me. But the king he got the bag before I could think more than about a half a thought, and he never suspicioned I was around. They took and shoved the bag through a rip in the straw tick that was under the feather-bed, and crammed it in a foot or two amongst the straw and said it was all right now, because a nigger only makes up the feather-bed, and don’t turn over the straw tick only about twice a year, and so it warn’t in no danger of getting stole now.
But I knowed better. I had it out of there before they was half-way down stairs. I groped along up to my cubby, and hid it there till I could get a chance to do better. I judged I better hide it outside of the house somewheres, because if they missed it they would give the house a good ransacking: I knowed that very well. Then I turned in, with my clothes all on; but I couldn’t a gone to sleep if I’d a wanted to, I was in such a sweat to get through with the business. By-and-by I heard the king and the duke come up; so I rolled off my pallet and laid with my chin at the top of my ladder, and waited to see if anything was going to happen. But nothing did.
So I held on till all the late sounds had quit and the early ones hadn’t begun yet; and then I slipped down the ladder.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
```python
# Simulated output of the generate_literary_segment function

"""
So they got ready to go down stairs again. And the Duke said:

"Hold on a minute; I hain't had time to think. Lemme see."

So he stood there a-studying, and all of a sudden he says:

"Looky here, King; the case is this. We got to leave this town early in the morning, you see."

"That's so," says the King.

"Well, then, we got to slide out quiet, and quick. The thing was, to slide out all of a sudden, before anybody would miss us. But we can't do that. We got to leave in the night, because Mary Jane'll be in mourning, and she'll be up and around early in the morning, and don't you know the nigger wench 'll be getting up too? Well, the nigger wench 'll be getting up, and she'll be going through them rooms, and she'll be packing up Mary Jane's things, and she'll run across that money, and then—"

"Hold on," says the King. "What's the matter with that?"

"Matter? Why, she'll borrow some of it, sure."

"Oh," says the King, "is that it? Well, then—"

He stood a second or two, thinking. Then he says, and walks to the curtain where I was:

"Well, you're right; it's risky. I'll take it and put it somewhere else."

So he come feeling along in the dark, and got it, and went out of the room with it. I couldn't see where he went, but I could hear him. He went into the next room, and I heard him a-fumbling around there. I was in a sweat, but I couldn't do nothing. I was pressed up against the wall, and I was afraid to breathe. I was thinking, if he finds me, what'll I do? But I couldn't think of nothing.

Then I heard him come back, and he come in and went to the bed, and I heard him a-tearing the straw tick. Then I heard him a-stuffing something in it. Then he says:

"There. Now she's all right. They'll hunt for it in the feather bed, but they won't think of the straw tick."

Then they went out of the room, and I heard them a-going down stairs.

- There is a lack of transition between the actions of the other characters and Huck's response, making the narrative unclear and disconnected from the original structure.

events.title: Huck Hides the Money in the Coffin
detailed_summary: The narrator, Huck, stealthily navigates the house at night, finding the men watching Peter Wilks's corpse asleep.
He observes the corpse in the parlor.
Upon hearing someone, later identified as Mary Jane, descending the stairs, Huck quickly decides to hide the bag of money inside Peter Wilks's coffin.
He places the bag under the coffin lid, near the deceased's cold hands.
Mary Jane enters the parlor, kneels by the coffin, and begins to cry.
Huck manages to slip out of the room unnoticed, confirming the watchers in the dining room remain asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I crept to their doors and listened; they was snoring.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They hadn’t stirred.

events.text_segment:
I crept to their doors and listened; they was snoring. So I tiptoed along, and got down stairs all right. There warn’t a sound anywheres. I peeped through a crack of the dining-room door, and see the men that was watching the corpse all sound asleep on their chairs. The door was open into the parlor, where the corpse was laying, and there was a candle in both rooms. I passed along, and the parlor door was open; but I see there warn’t nobody in there but the remainders of Peter; so I shoved on by; but the front door was locked, and the key wasn’t there. Just then I heard somebody coming down the stairs, back behind me. I run in the parlor and took a swift look around, and the only place I see to hide the bag was in the coffin. The lid was shoved along about a foot, showing the dead man’s face down in there, with a wet cloth over it, and his shroud on. I tucked the money-bag in under the lid, just down beyond where his hands was crossed, which made me creep, they was so cold, and then I run back across the room and in behind the door.
The person coming was Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, very soft, and kneeled down and looked in; then she put up her handkerchief, and I see she begun to cry, though I couldn’t hear her, and her back was to me. I slid out, and as I passed the dining-room I thought I’d make sure them watchers hadn’t seen me; so I looked through the crack, and everything was all right. They hadn’t stirred.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I crept to their doors and listened; they was snoring. So I went and got the bag of gold, and fetched it down stairs, and stood it in a corner by the wall. Then I felt my way to the parlor, and got right behind the dead man’s head, and waited. I didn’t do it the least noise, and they slept right along. Plenty soon enough the dead man’s spirit fetched a groan, and then another groan, and pretty soon he begun a-talking. But I didn’t take no notice, because I knowed he was only groaning and talking in his sleep. My conscience says, it’s death if you get caught; your conscience says, it’s death if you don’t get the money there. Oh, WHICH way ought I to go? Pity a poor miserable boy! It ain’t no use to talk to me; I know what is what, and it ain’t going to work. I’ll put it in the coffin. It will be safe there, and nobody will think of looking for it but me. So I got a candle, and crept to the coffin, and got it up, and put the bag of gold in under the lid, and then shoved it back. I didn’t look at him, but I felt his hands, and they were cold. I got a scare, and a shiver, and then I heard somebody coming down stairs. I slid back and hid myself behind the door, and waited. The steps came nearer and nearer, and pretty soon I could see a light through the crack under the door. It was Mary Jane, and she had a candle in her hand. She came in and set the candle down on the table, and then she went to the coffin and kneeled down beside it. She put her face down close to the dead man’s, and she begun to cry, and she cried and cried, till I couldn’t stand it no longer. I was going to slip out, but I heard her say, “Poor dear Peter!” and then she got up and went out of the room. I waited till I heard her shut the door, and then I slipped out and went up stairs. I crept to the watchers’ door and listened; they was snoring. I crept to the dining-room door and listened; they was snoring. I crept to the parlor door and listened; they was snoring. events.title: Huck's Midnight Regret and Dilemma
detailed_summary: Huck feels disheartened about how his plan to secure the money has turned out, despite his efforts and risks.
He considers the possibility of writing to Mary Jane later to retrieve the money, but dismisses it as unlikely to succeed.
He anticipates the money will be discovered when the coffin lid is screwed on, leading to the King regaining possession of it.
Huck acknowledges his desire to retrieve the money from the coffin but recognizes the increasing risk of being caught as morning approaches and the watchers might awaken.
He resolves not to attempt it, fearing being implicated in the theft of the six thousand dollars.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I don’t wish to be mixed up in no such business as that, I says to myself.

events.text_segment: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it. Says I, if it could stay where it is, all right; because when we get down the river a hundred mile or two I could write back to Mary Jane, and she could dig him up again and get it; but that ain’t the thing that’s going to happen; the thing that’s going to happen is, the money ’ll be found when they come to screw on the lid. Then the king ’ll get it again, and it ’ll be a long day before he gives anybody another chance to smouch it from him. Of course I wanted to slide down and get it out of there, but I dasn’t try it. Every minute it was getting earlier now, and pretty soon some of them watchers would begin to stir, and I might get catched—catched with six thousand dollars in my hands that nobody hadn’t hired me to take care of. I don’t wish to be mixed up in no such business as that, I says to myself.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it. I got to thinking over my troubles, and so I went off to sleep. I don't know how long I was asleep, but I know that when I waked up it was dark, and all quiet; and the first thing I done I crept out and listened. Not a sound anywheres—perfect stillness. I waited a while; next I got up and groped my way out to the little room, and held my breath and listened—no noise. I was going to open the door of the room where the coffin was, but I daren't. I daren't go into the cold room. I couldn't stand it. So I went back to bed. I laid there in the dark, thinking the thing all over. I says to myself, it's yet dark, they won't come here all early yet; they won't come till daylight. It's well I waited till dark, 'cause if I hadn't that fixing of the candles would a stood against us that much, anyway. I were a fool not to snatch that money this morning. But I couldn't see how with them all at my heels. It makes no difference, it's all the same; they'll get it now, certain. Slap it in the coffin now, and it's all right. It'll be buried, and nobody can get it but them. They'll trap me; they ain't no doubt about it. They'll think it was me. I could a got away, but I couldn't stand it to leave that money there, after all I'd been through. It's no use, I've got to stand it. I can't get away. I've got to see the thing out. events.title: The Funeral Service and the Undertaker's Efficiency
detailed_summary: In the morning, Huck observes the family and the con men, trying to discern if anything unusual has occurred, but finds no clues.
The undertaker arrives and prepares the house for the funeral service, arranging chairs.
Huck notices the coffin lid is undisturbed but dares not check for the money with people around.
Mourners arrive and file past the coffin, with the Wilks girls (referred to as 'beats' and 'girls' by Huck) showing their grief.
The undertaker is described as exceptionally stealthy and efficient, managing the crowd and arrangements silently with nods and gestures.
A poorly performing melodeon is played, and a hymn is sung, which Huck finds unimpressive.
Reverend Hobson begins his sermon, but it's abruptly interrupted by a loud commotion caused by a dog in the cellar.
The undertaker calmly and discreetly slips away to the cellar.
A thwack is heard, followed by silence, and the dog's barking ceases.
The undertaker reappears and whispers to the preacher that the dog had caught a rat, much to the satisfaction and curiosity of the attendees.
This incident elevates the undertaker's reputation among the townspeople.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There warn’t no more popular man in town than what that undertaker was.

events.text_segment:
When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. There warn’t nobody around but the family and the widow Bartley and our tribe. I watched their faces to see if anything had been happening, but I couldn’t tell.
Towards the middle of the day the undertaker come with his man, and they set the coffin in the middle of the room on a couple of chairs, and then set all our chairs in rows, and borrowed more from the neighbors till the hall and the parlor and the dining-room was full. I see the coffin lid was the way it was before, but I dasn’t go to look in under it, with folks around.
Then the people begun to flock in, and the beats and the girls took seats in the front row at the head of the coffin, and for a half an hour the people filed around slow, in single rank, and looked down at the dead man’s face a minute, and some dropped in a tear, and it was all very still and solemn, only the girls and the beats holding handkerchiefs to their eyes and keeping their heads bent, and sobbing a little. There warn’t no other sound but the scraping of the feet on the floor and blowing noses—because people always blows them more at a funeral than they do at other places except church.
When the place was packed full the undertaker he slid around in his black gloves with his softy soothering ways, putting on the last touches, and getting people and things all ship-shape and comfortable, and making no more sound than a cat. He never spoke; he moved people around, he squeezed in late ones, he opened up passageways, and done it with nods, and signs with his hands. Then he took his place over against the wall. He was the softest, glidingest, stealthiest man I ever see; and there warn’t no more smile to him than there is to a ham.
They had borrowed a melodeum—a sick one; and when everything was ready a young woman set down and worked it, and it was pretty skreeky and colicky, and everybody joined in and sung, and Peter was the only one that had a good thing, according to my notion. Then the Reverend Hobson opened up, slow and solemn, and begun to talk; and straight off the most outrageous row busted out in the cellar a body ever heard; it was only one dog, but he made a most powerful racket, and he kept it up right along; the parson he had to stand there, over the coffin, and wait—you couldn’t hear yourself think. It was right down awkward, and nobody didn’t seem to know what to do. But pretty soon they see that long-legged undertaker make a sign to the preacher as much as to say, “Don’t you worry—just depend on me.” Then he stooped down and begun to glide along the wall, just his shoulders showing over the people’s heads. So he glided along, and the powwow and racket getting more and more outrageous all the time; and at last, when he had gone around two sides of the room, he disappears down cellar. Then in about two seconds we heard a whack, and the dog he finished up with a most amazing howl or two, and then everything was dead still, and the parson begun his solemn talk where he left off. In a minute or two here comes this undertaker’s back and shoulders gliding along the wall again; and so he glided and glided around three sides of the room, and then rose up, and shaded his mouth with his hands, and stretched his neck out towards the preacher, over the people’s heads, and says, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “He had a rat!” Then he drooped down and glided along the wall again to his place. You could see it was a great satisfaction to the people, because naturally they wanted to know. A little thing like that don’t cost nothing, and it’s just the little things that makes a man to be looked up to and liked. There warn’t no more popular man in town than what that undertaker was.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. I noticed a good many sickly plants in the baskets setting around. It come to me that I hadn’t had any breakfast yet. So I slipped out to the kitchen and stole a bite of bread and a cold potato, and ate it behind the cellar door. It was very dark down there and spooky, and it was good to see the daylight again. For a while I set on the steps sorting out what was what. There was a nigger woman going around doing up the house, and she was where I could see her all the time; she was setting near the open door, sewing. She was tall and awkward, and seemed gentle and kindly. She was about forty, I judged. She said, ‘Good morning, honey. Has you had yo’ breakfast?’ I said, ‘No, ma’am.’ ‘Well, den, yo’ ma’ll fix you some. She’s up stairs yet, I reckon.’ ‘No, she ain’t. She’s gone to the country.’ ‘Laws sakes! I didn’t know dat. Well, den, honey, you set down right thar by de do’, and I’ll git you some breakfast.’ She was a slave. She didn’t seem to know anything about the money. I judged she hadn’t been told. I ate my breakfast, and then I went out in the yard and sat around and felt bad. I was sorry for them poor girls, and I wished I hadn’t come. I couldn’t see how they was ever going to stand it. They was so young and pretty and sweet, and they didn’t know nothing about the world. They was going to be sold down the river, and I couldn’t help them. I felt so mean and low and ornery. I wished I was dead. I couldn’t stand it no longer. I got up and went away. I went down to the river and got in the canoe and paddled up stream. I didn’t know where I was going, but I had to go somewhere. I paddled for about an hour, and then I landed and tied the canoe to a tree. I went up the bank and sat down in the woods. I was all alone, and I felt better. I stayed there for a long time, and then I went back to the house. It was about noon. The funeral was going to be at two o’clock. I went in the back way and up stairs. I went in the room where the coffin was. The girls was there, and the King and the Duke and the undertaker. The undertaker was a little, pale, soft-nigh man, with a long, sad face. He was fixing the flowers around the coffin. The girls was crying. The King and the Duke was standing by the window, talking low. I went over and looked in the coffin. It was old Mr. Wilks. He looked peaceful. I was glad I hadn’t seen him before. I went out and sat on the steps again. The nigger woman was still sewing. She looked up and smiled. I didn’t smile back. I couldn’t. I felt too bad. Pretty soon the people began to come. They came in carriages and wagons and on foot. They all looked sad. They went in the parlor and sat down. The undertaker went around and whispered to them. They all nodded. He was a slick one. He could make a body feel comfortable in a minute. He had a way of doing it. He was the most mournfulest man I ever saw. He could cry easier than anybody. He could cry at a funeral, and he could cry at a wedding. He could cry at anything. He was a professional mourner. He made a good living at it. He was a good man, though. He was kind to the poor. He was a member of the church. He was a good citizen. He was a good husband and father. He was a good neighbor. He was a good friend. He was a good man. He was a good man. He was a good man. Well, den, honey, you set down right thar by de do’, and I’ll git you some breakfast.’ She was a slave. She didn’t seem to know anything about the money. I judged she hadn’t been told. I ate my breakfast, and then I went out in the yard and sat around and felt bad. I was sorry for them poor girls, and I wished I hadn’t come. I couldn’t see how they was ever going to stand it. They was so young and pretty and sweet, and they didn’t know nothing about the world. They was going to be sold down the river, and I couldn’t help them. I felt so mean and low and ornery. I wished I was dead. I couldn’t stand it no longer. I got up and went away. I went down to the river and got in the canoe and paddled up stream. I didn’t know where I was going, but I had to go somewhere. I paddled for about an hour, and then I landed and tied the canoe to a tree. I went up the bank and sat down in the woods. I was all alone, and I felt better. I stayed there for a long time, and then I went back to the house. It was about noon. The funeral was going to be at two o’clock. I went in the back way and up stairs. I went in the room where the coffin was. The girls was there, and the King and the Duke and the undertaker. The undertaker was a little, pale, soft-nigh man, with a long, sad face. He was fixing the flowers around the coffin. The girls was crying. The King and the Duke was standing by the window, talking low. I went over and looked in the coffin. It was old Mr. Wilks. He looked peaceful. I was glad I hadn’t seen him before. I went out and sat on the steps again. The nigger woman was still sewing. She looked up and smiled. I didn’t smile back. I couldn’t. I felt too bad. Pretty soon the people began to come. They came in carriages and wagons and on foot. They all looked sad. They went in the parlor and sat down. The undertaker went around and whispered to them. They all nodded. He was a slick one. He could make a body feel comfortable in a minute. He had a way of doing it. He was the most mournfulest man I ever saw. He could cry easier than anybody. He could cry at a funeral, and he could cry at a wedding. He could cry at anything. He was a professional mourner. He made a good living at it. He was a good man, though. He was kind to the poor. He was a member of the church. He was a good citizen. He was a good husband and father. He was a good neighbor. He was a good friend. He was a good man. He was a good man. He was a good man. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. The house felt dead and empty, like the life had been sucked right out of it. It was awful quiet, not a sound but the wind sighing through the trees outside, which sounded like it was crying too. I felt sick inside, thinking about Buck and the others. It didn't seem right, all that fuss and pride and then just... gone. Laid out cold. I couldn't stand being in that house another minute. It felt haunted by all the trouble and the blood. I slipped out the back way, quiet as a mouse, and headed for the woods. My heart was heavy as lead. All that fine living and fancy clothes and poetry and then this. It made me feel like the river was the only place for me, the only place that made any sense. Up on the river, you didn't have people killing each other over things they couldn't even remember the start of. You just had the river, and the sky, and the stars, and the raft, and Jim. And that was enough. More than enough. I wandered through the woods, calling for Jim low down, not wanting to make no noise that might bring somebody after me. I didn't know where he'd gone, or if he was safe. That was the worst part, not knowing about Jim. He was the only friend I had in the world that wasn't trying to sivilize me or make me something I wasn't. I kept going, pushing through the bushes and the vines, my clothes getting snagged and torn. I didn't care. I just had to find him. I called his name again, a little louder this time, 'Jim! Oh, Jim!' And then, faint like, I heard a sound back. It was him! My heart jumped into my throat. I pushed on harder, crashing through the underbrush, not caring about the noise now. And there he was, crouched down in the thickest part of the swamp, looking scared but whole. And there, tied up to a tree root, was the raft! It was like seeing home after being lost in a strange, terrible place. Jim was mighty glad to see me, and I was mighty glad to see him. We didn't waste no time talking. We just got the raft loose and shoved off into the current. It felt so good to be back on the river, with the water slipping by and the trees on the banks going past like a dream. The silence out there on the water wasn't like the silence in the house; it was a peaceful silence, a healing silence. We didn't talk much for a long time, just drifted. I told Jim about everything that had happened, about Buck and the feud and all the killing. He listened quiet, his face looking sad. He said he'd been hiding in the swamp ever since the shooting started, scared to death somebody would find him and take him back. He'd seen some of it from a distance, heard the guns, and knew it was bad trouble. He'd managed to get the raft hidden away good. We both felt the same way about it. That whole business was awful and senseless. It made you feel small and dirty just thinking about it. But out on the river, under the big sky, it felt like we could wash it all away. The river was our friend. It carried us away from the trouble, away from the dead people and the crying and the hate. It was just us and the river again, heading south, towards freedom. It felt like we'd been given a second chance. We lay on the raft, looking up at the stars coming out, and it was the most beautiful sight in the world. No houses, no parlors, no watchers, no feuds. Just the river and the stars and the quiet. It was home.

events.title: Coffin Sealed and Huck's Renewed Anxiety
detailed_summary: The funeral sermon is lengthy, followed by some typical insincere pronouncements from the King.
Huck becomes anxious as the undertaker approaches the coffin with a screwdriver.
The undertaker seals the coffin lid without incident, leaving Huck uncertain whether the money is still inside or if someone else has taken it.
Huck contemplates the predicament: if he writes to Mary Jane and the money isn't there, she'll think poorly of him.
He concludes it's best to remain silent and not contact Mary Jane, feeling he has only made the situation worse with his attempts to help.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Blame it, I says, I might get hunted up and jailed; I’d better lay low and keep dark, and not write at all; the thing’s awful mixed now; trying to better it, I’ve worsened it a hundred times, and I wish to goodness I’d just let it alone, dad fetch the whole business!

events.text_segment: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. I was in a sweat then, and watched him pretty keen. But he never meddled at all; just slid the lid along as soft as mush, and screwed it down tight and fast. So there I was! I didn’t know whether the money was in there or not. So, says I, s’pose somebody has hogged that bag on the sly?—now how do I know whether to write to Mary Jane or not? S’pose she dug him up and didn’t find nothing, what would she think of me? Blame it, I says, I might get hunted up and jailed; I’d better lay low and keep dark, and not write at all; the thing’s awful mixed now; trying to better it, I’ve worsened it a hundred times, and I wish to goodness I’d just let it alone, dad fetch the whole business!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. I was feeling ever so comfortable, resting easy and just letting the day slide along. The sun was shining, and pleasant kind of weather, and if I was ever to feel down and disappointed about anything, it seemed like this warn't the time to do it. Well, just then the undertaker he fetched a sigh, not a loud one, but just a kind of gentle living sigh, and then he picked up the screw-driver and went to work. Well, I thought, here's a go. If anybody has got that money, it's him. And then I thought, well, if it ain't him it's somebody else; anyway, they've got it, and that's the end of the row. And then I thought, well, maybe it ain't gone, after all. I'll wait and see. So I waited. He worked a good while, and pretty soon he got the lid fastened down, and they carried the coffin out and put it in the hearse. Then they all got in their carriages and started. I didn't feel disposed to take in the funeral, but I felt very much disposed to drift into the graveyard and loaf around, so I done it. They buried him, and then all the strangers begun to go away, and pretty soon there warn't nobody left but me and the grave-diggers. They was filling it up, and I stood by till they was done. Then I struck out for the house; but I kept my weather eye open, and I took my time and I looked around everywheres, but I didn't see nothing. I got to the house and I went up to my room and I set down on the bed and I got to thinking. And I got to thinking about Mary Jane, and what a fix I was in. I had done everything I could to help her, and here I was, in a worse fix than ever. I had got the money, and I had hid it, and I had told her about it, and she had gone and told the truth, and now the money was gone, and I didn't know where it was, and I didn't know who had got it, and I didn't know what to do. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. He was a long, lanky man with a face like a wet week. He moved quiet and solemn, like he was afraid of waking the dead. He got the lid off the box and was just about to screw it down when old Colonel Grangerford stepped up, looking grim as judgment. He didn't say a word, just stood there, and then Buck's mother let out a terrible cry and fell on the coffin. Everybody was crying and moaning, and it was awful. Then, all of a sudden, there was a big commotion outside. Shots rang out! The feud had busted loose right there at the funeral. Men grabbed their guns, women screamed, and it was a stampede. I didn't wait to see who was shooting who. I just lit out for the woods as fast as my legs could carry me, my heart pounding like a drum. The peace was shattered, and death was everywhere again.

events.title: The King's Deceptive Plans for the Estate and the Girls
detailed_summary: After Peter Wilks's burial, Huck continues to scrutinize faces for any sign of the money's discovery, but learns nothing.
The King charmingly interacts with everyone, announcing his supposed need to quickly settle the estate and return to his congregation in England.
He proposes taking the Wilks girls with him and his companion, William (the Duke in disguise), to live among their English relatives.
This news delights everyone, especially the girls, who are so pleased they forget their recent sorrow and readily agree to a swift sale of the property.
Huck feels a deep sense of pity for the girls, knowing they are being deceived, but sees no way to intervene without endangering himself.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didn’t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.

events.text_segment:
They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy. But nothing come of it; the faces didn’t tell me nothing.
The king he visited around in the evening, and sweetened everybody up, and made himself ever so friendly; and he give out the idea that his congregation over in England would be in a sweat about him, so he must hurry and settle up the estate right away and leave for home. He was very sorry he was so pushed, and so was everybody; they wished he could stay longer, but they said they could see it couldn’t be done. And he said of course him and William would take the girls home with them; and that pleased everybody too, because then the girls would be well fixed and amongst their own relations; and it pleased the girls, too—tickled them so they clean forgot they ever had a trouble in the world; and told him to sell out as quick as he wanted to, they would be ready. Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didn’t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.

The house was full of men, women, and children, talking, and laughing, and carrying on, and Cullen Granger was drunk. The King he was standing around, seeing that the widow and the girls didn’t want for nothing, and hushing up Cullen when he got too lively. But them big funerals always makes me feel mighty lonesome. I wish I had a country home I could go to and be quiet. But what’s the use of wishing? It ain’t no use. I see the widow’s face come a-glimmering through the trees and bushes alongside the fence, and I knowed she was coming to the grave. She got there, and she kneeled down, and I see her lips a-moving; and then I see her rise up and go away. I wished I hadn’t seen her, because it made me feel more lonesome than ever. And so the funeral sermon went on, and they sung hymns, and prayed, and I got a-thinking about my own funeral, and how it would be, and who would be there, and what they would say; and a shiver come over me, and I wished I was dead and done with. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy. The house was full of mourners, all putting on a show, specially the King and the Duke. They was the worst. They’d groan and sigh and wipe their eyes with big handkerchiefs, looking as sorrowful as if they’d lost their own kin, but I could see the greedy look in their eyes when they thought nobody was watching. They was just waiting to get their hands on that money. It made me sick. I watched the poor girls, Mary Jane and Susan and Joanna, crying real tears, and it just didn’t seem right. Here they was, grieving for their uncle, and these two frauds was just playing a part to rob them blind. Every time I looked at the King’s smirking face or the Duke’s shifty eyes, my stomach would turn over. I kept thinking about the real heirs, the ones that ought to have the money, and how these villains was cheating them out of it. It wasn’t just the money, though; it was the meanness of it, the way they was fooling everybody and making a mockery of grief. I couldn’t stand it no more. I knew I had to do something. It was a terrible risk, and I didn’t know how I was going to manage it, but I couldn’t just stand by and watch them ruin these innocent people. My conscience was bothering me something awful, worse than it ever had about Jim. This was different. This was pure wickedness, and I felt like I was part of it just by being there and knowing about it. I had to stop them, somehow.

events.title: The Heartbreaking Sale and Separation of the Enslaved Family
characters: enslaved people (two sons and their mother)
detailed_summary: The King promptly arranges for the auction of the Wilks estate, including the house and the enslaved people, just two days after the funeral.
The day after the funeral, slave traders arrive, and the King sells the enslaved family—two sons are sent upriver to Memphis, and their mother downriver to New Orleans.
The separation causes immense grief for both the Wilks girls and the enslaved family, who cry and lament their parting.
The girls express their shock, never having imagined the enslaved family would be sold or separated.
Huck is profoundly moved by the scene, stating he could hardly bear it if he didn't know the sale was fraudulent and the enslaved individuals would likely be back in a short time.
The townspeople are also stirred by this event, with many openly condemning the separation of the mother and her children as scandalous.
This public outcry damages the reputation of the King and Duke, making the Duke particularly anxious, though the King stubbornly proceeds with his plans.

events.text_segment:
Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to.
So the next day after the funeral, along about noon-time, the girls’ joy got the first jolt. A couple of nigger traders come along, and the king sold them the niggers reasonable, for three-day drafts as they called it, and away they went, the two sons up the river to Memphis, and their mother down the river to Orleans. I thought them poor girls and them niggers would break their hearts for grief; they cried around each other, and took on so it most made me down sick to see it. The girls said they hadn’t ever dreamed of seeing the family separated or sold away from the town. I can’t ever get it out of my memory, the sight of them poor miserable girls and niggers hanging around each other’s necks and crying; and I reckon I couldn’t a stood it all, but would a had to bust out and tell on our gang if I hadn’t knowed the sale warn’t no account and the niggers would be back home in a week or two.
The thing made a big stir in the town, too, and a good many come out flatfooted and said it was scandalous to separate the mother and the children that way. It injured the frauds some; but the old fool he bulled right along, spite of all the duke could say or do, and I tell you the duke was powerful uneasy.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to. So the next day after the funeral, along comes the slave-traders, and they wanted to buy the niggers first, to save the trouble of waiting till auction-day. So he told the traders to go right ahead and look ’em over, and say what they’d give. So they swore they wouldn’t buy them private, because they hadn’t any license, and wouldn’t be allowed to sell them in that State. So they said they’d give a hundred dollars apiece for the two boys, and fifty for the mother. So the king told the girls these things, and said, now the country was broke, again, and that the best thing a person could do was to sell the niggers, and then all the rest of the property could go to the bad, and nobody wouldn’t ever blame them, but would blame the country. So they agreed to it, and cried, and said they couldn’t help it; but that if they had it to do over again, they wouldn’t ever let no country break them, but they’d break the country first. The traders paid eighty dollars apiece for the boys, and forty for the mother. The girls cried a bit, and then got out the money and counted it over, and locked it up in the bureau. All that day and the next they kept on crying and taking on, and when the time come to say good-bye the niggers they fetched a howl that you could hear a mile; it come so sudden and unexpected that it scared me. None of us was prepared for it. The girls cried, and the mother cried, and the boys cried. But all of them kept on kissing the hands of the girls and calling them blessed divinities. And so they went out of the door and down the street, and was gone. It was a dreadful thing to see. I couldn’t ever feel right about it after this. I couldn’t bear to think they got eighty dollars for them, and forty for the mother. It was an awful thing to see. I couldn’t stand it. events.title: The King and Duke Confront Huck About the Missing Money
detailed_summary: On the morning of the auction, the King and Duke awaken Huck, their expressions indicating trouble.
They interrogate Huck about whether he was in their room or saw anyone else enter it, suspecting the money is missing.
Huck denies being near their room since Mary Jane first showed it to them.
When pressed, Huck cleverly suggests he saw the enslaved individuals (referred to as 'niggers' by the characters) coming out of their room on the morning of the funeral, acting secretively.
The King and Duke are initially surprised, then seemingly convinced by Huck's implication that the enslaved people stole the money before being sold.
The Duke laments selling them so cheaply, believing they possessed significant 'histrionic talent' for feigning sorrow at their departure.
The King dismisses Huck sharply when he asks if something is wrong, telling him to mind his own business.
As they leave, the Duke makes a sarcastic comment about 'quick sales and small profits,' leading to an argument with the King about whose fault the supposed loss is.
The King then berates Huck for not informing him sooner about seeing the enslaved people in his room.
Huck feels relieved that he successfully diverted suspicion onto the enslaved people, especially since he believes they are safe and will not be harmed by his accusation, given their fraudulent sale.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Next day was auction day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.

events.text_segment:
Next day was auction day. About broad day in the morning the king and the duke come up in the garret and woke me up, and I see by their look that there was trouble. The king says:
“Was you in my room night before last?”
“No, your majesty”—which was the way I always called him when nobody but our gang warn’t around.
“Was you in there yisterday er last night?”
“No, your majesty.”
“Honor bright, now—no lies.”
“Honor bright, your majesty, I’m telling you the truth. I hain’t been a-near your room since Miss Mary Jane took you and the duke and showed it to you.”
The duke says:
“Have you seen anybody else go in there?”
“No, your grace, not as I remember, I believe.”
“Stop and think.”
I studied awhile and see my chance; then I says:
“Well, I see the niggers go in there several times.”
Both of them gave a little jump, and looked like they hadn’t ever expected it, and then like they had. Then the duke says:
“What, all of them?”
“No—leastways, not all at once—that is, I don’t think I ever see them all come out at once but just one time.”
“Hello! When was that?”
“It was the day we had the funeral. In the morning. It warn’t early, because I overslept. I was just starting down the ladder, and I see them.”
“Well, go on, go on! What did they do? How’d they act?”
“They didn’t do nothing. And they didn’t act anyway much, as fur as I see. They tiptoed away; so I seen, easy enough, that they’d shoved in there to do up your majesty’s room, or something, s’posing you was up; and found you warn’t up, and so they was hoping to slide out of the way of trouble without waking you up, if they hadn’t already waked you up.”
“Great guns, this is a go!” says the king; and both of them looked pretty sick and tolerable silly. They stood there a-thinking and scratching their heads a minute, and the duke he bust into a kind of a little raspy chuckle, and says:
“It does beat all how neat the niggers played their hand. They let on to be sorry they was going out of this region! And I believed they was sorry, and so did you, and so did everybody. Don’t ever tell me any more that a nigger ain’t got any histrionic talent. Why, the way they played that thing it would fool anybody. In my opinion, there’s a fortune in ’em. If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn’t want a better lay-out than that—and here we’ve gone and sold ’em for a song. Yes, and ain’t privileged to sing the song yet. Say, where is that song—that draft?”
“In the bank for to be collected. Where would it be?”
“Well, that’s all right then, thank goodness.”
Says I, kind of timid-like:
“Is something gone wrong?”
The king whirls on me and rips out:
“None o’ your business! You keep your head shet, and mind y’r own affairs—if you got any. Long as you’re in this town don’t you forgit that—you hear?” Then he says to the duke, “We got to jest swaller it and say noth’n’: mum’s the word for us.”
As they was starting down the ladder the duke he chuckles again, and says:
“Quick sales and small profits! It’s a good business—yes.”
The king snarls around on him and says:
“I was trying to do for the best in sellin’ ’em out so quick. If the profits has turned out to be none, lackin’ considable, and none to carry, is it my fault any more’n it’s yourn?”
“Well, they’d be in this house yet and we wouldn’t if I could a got my advice listened to.”
The king sassed back as much as was safe for him, and then swapped around and lit into me again. He give me down the banks for not coming and telling him I see the niggers come out of his room acting that way—said any fool would a knowed something was up. And then waltzed in and cussed himself awhile, and said it all come of him not laying late and taking his natural rest that morning, and he’d be blamed if he’d ever do it again. So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Next day was auction day. We had breakfast early, and they started the auction. All day long the house was full of people, coming and going, standing around, talking, smoking, spitting on the floor, and quarreling. By the middle of the afternoon the biggest part of the truck was sold, and the late afternoon was taken up by the niggers. There was sixteen of them. They sold them separately, and in families, just as they fetched the best price. It was pretty hard to hear the breaking up of families, just a-going on and on, and no end to it. If a mother was shut up in two or three lots with her children, she would beg the people to buy her all together, but they only laughed at it, and said that wasn’t the way to do. It made me so sick I most wished I hadn’t stole the king’s gold to give the niggers, because a body couldn’t get it into the right hands anyway. It would always get into the wrong ones. And I was sorry, because I thought those poor wretches was going to be sold away from their friends and leave everything they was used to, and go amongst strangers, and be sold to people they didn’t know nothing about. Well, with the day’s business him and the duke had me and the niggers and Mary Jane all packed into a steamboat inside of two days, and gone down the river a hundred and fifty mile to sell the niggers, but we didn’t go. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Next day was auction day. About the middle of the forenoon the king and the duke come up in the garret and woke me up, and I see by their look that there was trouble. The king says:
“Easy now, easy. Don’t rise. What’s the matter is, we’ve had an accident. You didn’t see anybody from when you come up here last night till you went to sleep, did you?”
“No, sir,” says I.
“Well, it’s a rough instance. You didn’t hear anybody stirring around?”
“No, sir.”
“Well, consound it, you didn’t see anybody come up the stairs or down the stairs?”
“No, sir. Why? What’s the matter?”
They studied awhile, and then the king says:
“Well, you see, we stored a little money away for a rainy day, and it ain’t there; and we are pretty uneasy about it.”
“Why, king, what do you think—”
“Hello, I think the niggers done it! See the way they acted when they was told they was to be sold? That’s the way they always do. They’re awful deep—layin’.”
“That’s the idea,” says the duke, cutting in; “and they’ve stole that money, sure. Didn’t you see the signs of it, Huck? You lived in the house with them when they was here.”
“No,” says I, “I didn’t see no signs of it before they went away; but after they was gone I notic’d that a nigger was missing—one that you didn’t get tally of, and he was gone when—”
“Well, for the land’s sake! What did you let that nigger off for?” says the king.
“I didn’t hinder him. I couldn’t hinder him. He slipped out and—”
“Well, why didn’t you tell us before?” says the king.
“Well, I didn’t see the use. It was only one nigger, and—”
“But you see the use now, don’t you? We’ve lost a cool nine hundred—come mighty near it. And here we’ve been fools enough to sell them niggers for next to nothing, when they’re worth twelve hundred apiece, if they’re worth a cent. Runaway niggers ain’t worth a cent on the river, but these hadn’t no idea of runnin’. They were too deep. They were laying for a chance. And they got it. Confound ’em, they got it!”
They was so mad they couldn’t get a word out for a spell. Then the duke says:
“Well, it’s all my fault. I ought to have kept them niggers till we got the money. I might have knowed they was up to some devilment.”
“No, it ain’t your fault,” says the king. “It’s his. He ought to have told us he seen that nigger slipping out. What did you see him do, Huck?”
“Well, I see him come out of your room, and he had a bundle under his arm, and he was looking kind of scared, and he slipped down the stairs and—”
“Well, why didn’t you tell us before?” says the king, hotter than ever.
“Well, I didn’t see the use. It was only one nigger, and—”
“You didn’t see the use! Well, you see it now, don’t you? We’ve lost a cool nine hundred—come mighty near it. And here we’ve been fools enough to sell them niggers for next to nothing, when they’re worth twelve hundred apiece, if they’re worth a cent. Runaway niggers ain’t worth a cent on the river, but these hadn’t no idea of runnin’. They were too deep. They were laying for a chance. And they got it. Confound ’em, they got it!”

“No, it ain’t your fault,” says the king. “It’s his. He ought to have told us he seen that nigger slipping out. What did you see him do, Huck?”
“Well, I see him come out of your room, and he had a bundle under his arm, and he was looking kind of scared, and he slipped down the stairs and—”

“You didn’t see the use! Well, you see it now, don’t you? We’ve lost a cool nine hundred—come mighty near it. And here we’ve been fools enough to sell them niggers for next to nothing, when they’re worth twelve hundred apiece, if they’re worth a cent. Runaway niggers ain’t worth a cent on the river, but these hadn’t no idea of runnin’. They were too deep. They were laying for a chance. And they got it. Confound ’em, they got it!”
They was so mad they couldn’t get a word out for a spell. Then the duke says:
“Well, it’s all my fault. I ought to have kept them niggers till we got the money. I might have knowed they was up to some devilment.”
“No, it ain’t your fault,” says the king. “It’s his. He ought to have told us he seen that nigger slipping out. What did you see him

IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion invents an extended auction scene with detailed descriptions of the auction process, the sale of enslaved people, and emotional reflections on the breaking up of families. This entire section is not present in the original passage.
- The completion omits the original's central scene: the confrontation in the garret between the narrator, the king, and the duke, including their dialogue and the discussion about who entered the king's room.
- The completion introduces a lengthy, repetitive internal monologue about guilt and regret, which is not part of the original passage at this point.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The initial morning encounter in the garret, where the king and duke wake the narrator and question him, is missing.
- The sequence of questioning about who entered the king's room, the narrator's responses, and the mention of the servants is absent.
- The reactions of the king and duke to the narrator's answers, including their surprise and subsequent discussion, are not included.
- The conversation about the draft and the bank, as well as the king's admonishment to the narrator, is missing.
- The closing exchange between the king and duke as they leave, and the narrator's relief at having shifted suspicion, is not present.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion provides an inaccurate sequence of events, focusing on the auction and its aftermath rather than the original's interrogation scene.
- It attributes invented actions and reflections to the narrator, such as detailed remorse and repeated wishes, which do not occur in the original passage at this point.
- The completion misplaces the focus, centering on the auction and personal regret rather than the original's dialogue-driven tension and plot development.
- There is an inaccurate portrayal of the timeline, with invented events and reflections replacing the original's specific morning confrontation and its immediate aftermath.

events.title: Huck Comforts Mary Jane and Reveals a Shocking Truth
detailed_summary: Huck, upon waking, finds Mary Jane crying in her room while packing for England, distressed about the separation of the enslaved family sold by the con men.
Feeling sympathy, Huck enters her room and tries to comfort her.
Mary Jane expresses her deep sorrow that the enslaved mother and children will never see each other again.
Impulsively, Huck blurts out that they will indeed be reunited within two weeks, a statement he knows to be true.

Taken aback by his own sudden revelation, Huck pauses to consider whether telling the full truth is wiser than concocting a lie in this difficult situation, ultimately deciding that the truth, though risky, seems safer.
He asks Mary Jane if she can go to a place out of town, Mr. Lothrop's, and stay for three or four days.
Huck strikes a deal with Mary Jane: if he proves how he knows the enslaved family will be reunited, she must go to Mr. Lothrop's and stay for the agreed time, to which she readily consents.
After securing her promise and bolting the door for privacy, Huck gravely informs Mary Jane that her supposed uncles are, in fact, frauds and 'dead-beats.'
Mary Jane is, of course, deeply shaken but then quickly consumed by rage, exclaiming that the impostors should be immediately tarred, feathered, and thrown into the river.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The brute! Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”

events.text_segment:
By-and-by it was getting-up time. So I come down the ladder and started for down-stairs; but as I come to the girls’ room the door was open, and I see Mary Jane setting by her old hair trunk, which was open and she’d been packing things in it—getting ready to go to England. But she had stopped now with a folded gown in her lap, and had her face in her hands, crying. I felt awful bad to see it; of course anybody would. I went in there and says:
“Miss Mary Jane, you can’t a-bear to see people in trouble, and I can’t—most always. Tell me about it.”
So she done it. And it was the niggers—I just expected it. She said the beautiful trip to England was most about spoiled for her; she didn’t know how she was ever going to be happy there, knowing the mother and the children warn’t ever going to see each other no more—and then busted out bitterer than ever, and flung up her hands, and says:
“Oh, dear, dear, to think they ain’t ever going to see each other any more!”
“But they will—and inside of two weeks—and I know it!” says I.
Laws, it was out before I could think! And before I could budge she throws her arms around my neck and told me to say it again, say it again, say it again!
I see I had spoke too sudden and said too much, and was in a close place. I asked her to let me think a minute; and she set there, very impatient and excited and handsome, but looking kind of happy and eased-up, like a person that’s had a tooth pulled out. So I went to studying it out. I says to myself, I reckon a body that ups and tells the truth when he is in a tight place is taking considerable many resks, though I ain’t had no experience, and can’t say for certain; but it looks so to me, anyway; and yet here’s a case where I’m blest if it don’t look to me like the truth is better and actuly safer than a lie. I must lay it by in my mind, and think it over some time or other, it’s so kind of strange and unregular. I never see nothing like it. Well, I says to myself at last, I’m a-going to chance it; I’ll up and tell the truth this time, though it does seem most like setting down on a kag of powder and touching it off just to see where you’ll go to. Then I says:
“Miss Mary Jane, is there any place out of town a little ways where you could go and stay three or four days?”
“Yes; Mr. Lothrop’s. Why?”
“Never mind why yet. If I’ll tell you how I know the niggers will see each other again inside of two weeks—here in this house—and prove how I know it—will you go to Mr. Lothrop’s and stay four days?”
“Four days!” she says; “I’ll stay a year!”
“All right,” I says, “I don’t want nothing more out of you than just your word—I druther have it than another man’s kiss-the-Bible.” She smiled and reddened up very sweet, and I says, “If you don’t mind it, I’ll shut the door—and bolt it.”
Then I come back and set down again, and says:
“Don’t you holler. Just set still and take it like a man. I got to tell the truth, and you want to brace up, Miss Mary, because it’s a bad kind, and going to be hard to take, but there ain’t no help for it. These uncles of yourn ain’t no uncles at all; they’re a couple of frauds—regular dead-beats. There, now we’re over the worst of it, you can stand the rest middling easy.”
It jolted her up like everything, of course; but I was over the shoal water now, so I went right along, her eyes a-blazing higher and higher all the time, and told her every blame thing, from where we first struck that young fool going up to the steamboat, clear through to where she flung herself on to the king’s breast at the front door and he kissed her sixteen or seventeen times—and then up she jumps, with her face afire like sunset, and says:
“The brute! Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”

By-and-by it was getting-up time. I waked up, and slid off the roof of the little lean-to, and got on my clothes and come in at the kitchen door. The doctor and the widow had been up a good while, but Mary Jane was setting by her door in the wood-shed, crying—not just crying, but crying hard. I opened the door easy and stepped in, and says:

“Miss Mary Jane, you can’t a-bear it no longer—you got to tell me. Tell me what it is.”

She hid her face in her hands, and not make a sound. I set down close by her, and says:

“Miss Mary Jane, don’t take on so—I come to tell you.”

She took her hands away and stood up, looking towards me. I knowed what it was about. I judged she was feeling worried about the niggers. She stood awhile, and then says, in a voice that didn’t sound like a natural voice:

“Come in here, Huck.”

She opened the door of her room, and I went in. She shut it very soft, and motioned me to set down on the side of the bed. Then she set down too, and took my hand in hers, and begun to sob, and says:

“Poor things! poor things! Can’t anybody do anything for them, Huck? You feel for them, don’t you?”

“Yes, ma’am, I do.”

She took a breath, and waited, and then says:

“I sha’n’t ever see them again in this world, I don’t believe. And they’ve been good to me. They hain’t ever done me no harm. It’s a cruel business!”

She sobbed some more, and then says:

“Huck, can’t you reckon up something to do for them? I’ve tried, and it hain’t no use. They’ve got two weeks to raise the money in, and sell them down the river. They can’t raise it; of course they can’t. And they’re only going to one place, and they hain’t going there together. And they hain’t got no friends but what’s here; and however friends is going to help them, I don’t know. They declare as how they hain’t got no father, nor mother, nor brothers, nor sisters.”

She sobbed again, and I said:

“Why, bless you, honey, when I was down at the plantation, all the darkies made such a fuss over me, and so did the niggers I hain’t seen before, and I don’t know no more about it then what I knowed before, but all I know is, they said they hadn’t no father, nor mother, nor brothers, nor sisters, and so I couldn’t see no way for them to get together again.”

“Oh, Huck, you know I hain’t got no patience with you. You don’t seem to understand. Can’t you see that they’ll never get together again? that they’re going to be separated forever?”

I see it warn’t no use to try to play it any longer. I had to tell her the truth. I says:

“Why, bless your soul, they ain’t going to be separated at all! They’re going to be together again in two weeks, and they ain’t going to be sold down the river, they’re going to stay right here in this town, and they’re going to be free!”

She looked at me like I was crazy, and says:

“Huck, what are you talking about? Are you out of your mind?”

“No, ma’am, I ain’t out of my mind. I’m telling you the truth. They ain’t going to be sold, and they ain’t going to be separated. They’re going to be free, and they’re going to stay right here.”

“But how do you know that, Huck? How can you be so sure?”

“Why, I know it because I know the people that’s doing it. I know the whole business.”

“Do you mean to say that you know the people that’s going to buy them?”

“No, ma’am, I don’t mean that. I mean I know the people that’s selling them, and I know they ain’t going to sell them.”

“But they’ve already sold them, Huck. The bill of sale is signed.”

“Yes, ma’am, I know that. But that ain’t the whole story. There’s more to it than that.”

“Well, what is it, Huck? Tell me! Don’t keep me in suspense!”

I thought a minute, and then I says:

“Miss Mary Jane, you got to do something for me first.”

“Anything, Huck, anything! Just tell me what it is.”

“Well, you got to go away from here for a little while. You got to go to Mr. Lothrop’s and stay there for three or four days.”

“But why, Huck? Why do I have to go away?”

“Because I can’t tell you the whole story unless you do. It’s a secret, and I can’t tell it to you here.”

“But I don’t understand, Huck. Why can’t you tell me here?”

“Because if I tell you here, it’ll get out, and it’ll spoil everything. You got to go away so I can tell you without anybody else hearing.”

She looked at me for a long time, and then she says:

“Huck, I don’t know what you’re talking about, but I trust you. If you say I have to go away, I’ll go away. But you have to promise me that you
