events.title: Huck Outlines a Plan for Justice and Mary Jane's Role
detailed_summary: Huck tempers Mary Jane's immediate desire for vengeance, reminding her to consider her actions carefully.
He explains that a premature exposure of the frauds would endanger another innocent person (Jim), whom they have a responsibility to protect.
Huck then lays out his plan: Mary Jane is to depart for Mr. Lothrop's place and remain there until nine or half-past nine that night.

If Huck hasn't returned by eleven o'clock, she should place a candle in her window as a signal; if he still hasn't appeared by eleven, it means he has escaped and is safe, at which point she can expose the con men and have them jailed.
He instructs Mary Jane that if he happens to be captured alongside the frauds, she must publicly declare that he had confided everything to her beforehand and offer him her full support.

To provide evidence against the con men, Huck writes 'Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville' on a piece of paper for Mary Jane, telling her to give it to the court so they can summon witnesses from that town who can identify the frauds.

Huck reassures her that the ongoing auction and the sale of the enslaved individuals are invalid and that the enslaved people will be returned, emphasizing that the con men are in a difficult position and won't be able to collect any money.

events.text_segment:
Says I:
“Cert’nly. But do you mean before you go to Mr. Lothrop’s, or—”
“Oh,” she says, “what am I thinking about!” she says, and set right down again. “Don’t mind what I said—please don’t—you won’t, now, will you?” Laying her silky hand on mine in that kind of a way that I said I would die first. “I never thought, I was so stirred up,” she says; “now go on, and I won’t do so any more. You tell me what to do, and whatever you say I’ll do it.”
“Well,” I says, “it’s a rough gang, them two frauds, and I’m fixed so I got to travel with them a while longer, whether I want to or not—I druther not tell you why; and if you was to blow on them this town would get me out of their claws, and I’d be all right; but there’d be another person that you don’t know about who’d be in big trouble. Well, we got to save him, hain’t we? Of course. Well, then, we won’t blow on them.”
Saying them words put a good idea in my head. I see how maybe I could get me and Jim rid of the frauds; get them jailed here, and then leave. But I didn’t want to run the raft in the daytime without anybody aboard to answer questions but me; so I didn’t want the plan to begin working till pretty late to-night. I says:
“Miss Mary Jane, I’ll tell you what we’ll do, and you won’t have to stay at Mr. Lothrop’s so long, nuther. How fur is it?”
“A little short of four miles—right out in the country, back here.”
“Well, that’ll answer. Now you go along out there, and lay low till nine or half-past to-night, and then get them to fetch you home again—tell them you’ve thought of something. If you get here before eleven put a candle in this window, and if I don’t turn up wait till eleven, and then if I don’t turn up it means I’m gone, and out of the way, and safe. Then you come out and spread the news around, and get these beats jailed.”
“Good,” she says, “I’ll do it.”
“And if it just happens so that I don’t get away, but get took up along with them, you must up and say I told you the whole thing beforehand, and you must stand by me all you can.”
“Stand by you! indeed I will. They sha’n’t touch a hair of your head!” she says, and I see her nostrils spread and her eyes snap when she said it, too.
“If I get away I sha’n’t be here,” I says, “to prove these rapscallions ain’t your uncles, and I couldn’t do it if I was here. I could swear they was beats and bummers, that’s all, though that’s worth something. Well, there’s others can do that better than what I can, and they’re people that ain’t going to be doubted as quick as I’d be. I’ll tell you how to find them. Gimme a pencil and a piece of paper. There—‘Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.’ Put it away, and don’t lose it. When the court wants to find out something about these two, let them send up to Bricksville and say they’ve got the men that played the Royal Nonesuch, and ask for some witnesses—why, you’ll have that entire town down here before you can hardly wink, Miss Mary. And they’ll come a-biling, too.”
I judged we had got everything fixed about right now. So I says:
“Just let the auction go right along, and don’t worry. Nobody don’t have to pay for the things they buy till a whole day after the auction on accounts of the short notice, and they ain’t going out of this till they get that money; and the way we’ve fixed it the sale ain’t going to count, and they ain’t going to get no money. It’s just like the way it was with the niggers—it warn’t no sale, and the niggers will be back before long. Why, they can’t collect the money for the niggers yet—they’re in the worst kind of a fix, Miss Mary.”
“Well,” she says, “I’ll run down to breakfast now, and then I’ll start straight for Mr. Lothrop’s.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Says I:
“Cert’nly. But do you mean before you go to Mr. Lothrop’s, or—”
“No,” she says, “after I get there. You tell me what I got to do, and I’ll do it.”
“All right. Now you listen and mind what I say. You go to Mr. Lothrop’s, and tell him all we told you—exactly as we told you. Say we kept it a secret from everybody for fear somebody might tell the frauds; but that if they didn’t get away, and we didn’t get away, nobody else would be hurt. Well, after you’ve told him, he’ll put a candle in his window, and that’ll show that he’s all right. And he’ll keep it there all night, it’s so high up. It’ll be a signal, you see. And then, whilst you and me is a-getting away, in the night, we’ll know it’s all safe, and pap and mam and the girls safe, and everything safe. Yes, and so will Jim, poor old Jim, he’ll know it’s all safe when he sees the candle. It’s a great idea; simple, too, if I do say it.”
“Why, that’s good,” she says. “I’m to go to Mr. Lothrop’s and tell him, and he puts a candle in his window, and that shows—”
“Why, of course it does. It shows that his family ain’t to be hurt. When you tell him the secret, that’s the first thing he’ll think about. You ain’t afraid to go there, are you?”
“No, I ain’t afraid to go anywhere for anybody that’s in trouble. But what about them —the frauds—that way?”
“Why, they won’t know it. They won’t know anything about it. It won’t hurt them.”
“Well,” she says, “I don’t see but what I can do it.”
“All right,” I says; “now you turn this long truck into what you call a short one. What’s the time now?”
“It’s half-past two.”
“Good! You go right along, then; not lallygagging, you understand.”
“What’s that?”
“Never mind what it is—don’t you lallygag. Light out at top speed.”
“I’ll tell Mr. Lothrop to send a man to the steamboat, then, and—”
“Oh, no, no, no! Don’t do that. You mustn’t ever do that. You are to tell him to not let anybody in that house know anything at all about it, till he hears from you again. Not a word!”
“Well, then, I won’t. It’s all right. I’ll run all the way, and get there at four o’clock, and tell him all we told me, and say I got to leave town to-night and they mustn’t ever tell anybody they knowed me, or anything about it. And I will tell him to put a candle in his window, and—”
“Hold on, now. You ain’t to tell him you got to leave town and they mustn’t ever tell anybody they knowed you.”
“Well, what am I to tell him?”
“You are to tell him what we told you; and then say that you are a-going to leave him alone a little while, because I want my family to be there, and Jim’s too, maybe; and I want to see the candle, you understand, before we go.”
“Oh, well, that’s good,” she says. “Then I won’t tell him anything about my leaving, or his not telling anybody he knows me.”
“No,” I says; “I don’t want him to know you are a-leaving, see? Because if he knows you are a-leaving, and me too, he would be afraid of course, and mightn’t put the candle out. See?”
“No, I don’t see. What’s the candle for?”
“Why, I told you. It’s a signal. When we get to the river, we’ll see the candle, and then we’ll know that the family is all right. See?”
“Oh, I see. And you and me are to go to the river and get on the raft, and—”
“No, no, no! You ain’t to go to the river. You are to go right along home and stay there till about nine or half-past nine to-night, and then you are to slip out and go to the river and find the raft, and—”
“Why,” she says, “the raft will be gone then. I tell you it’s half-past two now, and they’ll be gone long before nine.”

Yes, and so will Jim, poor old Jim, he’ll know it’s all safe when he sees the candle. It’s a great idea; simple, too, if I do say it.”
“Why, that’s good,” she says. “I’m to go to Mr. Lothrop’s and tell him, and he puts a candle in his window, and that shows—”
“Why, of course it does. It shows that his family ain’t to be hurt. When you tell him the secret, that’s the first thing he’ll think about. You ain’t afraid to go there, are you?”
“No, I ain’t afraid to go anywhere for anybody that’s in trouble. But what about them —the frauds—that way?”
“Why, they won’t know it. They won’t know anything about it. It won’t hurt them.”
“Well,” she says, “I don’t see but what I can do it.”
“All right,” I says; “now you turn this long truck into what you call a short one. What’s the time now?”
“It’s half-past two.”
“Good! You go right along, then; not lallygagging, you understand.”
“What’s that?”
“Never mind what it is—don’t you lallygag. Light out at top speed.”
“I’ll tell Mr. Lothrop to send a man to the steamboat, then, and—”
“Oh, no, no, no! Don’t do that. You mustn’t ever do that. You are to tell him to not let anybody in that house know anything at all about it, till he hears from you again. Not a word!”
“Well, then, I won’t. It’s all right. I’ll run all the way, and get there at four o’clock, and tell him all we told me, and say I got to leave town to-night and they mustn’t ever tell anybody they knowed me, or anything about it. And I will tell him to put a candle in his window, and—”
“Hold on, now. You ain’t to tell him you got to leave town and they mustn’t ever tell anybody they knowed you.”
“Well, what am I to tell him?”
“You are to tell him what we told you; and then say that you are a-going to leave him alone a little while, because I want my family to be there, and Jim’s too, maybe; and I want to see the candle, you understand, before we go.”
“Oh, well, that’s good,” she says. “Then I won’t tell him anything about my leaving, or his not telling anybody he knows me.”
“No,” I says; “I don’t want him to know you are a-leaving, see? Because if he knows you are a-leaving, and me too, he would be afraid of course, and mightn’t put the candle out. See?”
“No, I don’t see. What’s the candle for?”
“Why, I told you. It’s a signal. When we get to the river, we’ll see the candle, and then we’ll know that the family is all right. See?”
“Oh, I see. And you and me are to go to the river and get on the raft, and—”
“No, no, no! You ain’t to go to the river. You are to go right along home and stay there till about nine or half-past nine to-night, and then you are to slip out and go to the river and find the raft, and—”
“Why,” she says, “the raft will be gone then. I tell you it’s half-past two now, and they’ll be gone long before nine.”
“No,” I says, “they won’t. I’ll tell you why. I’ll go and hide the raft in the woods, and then I’ll come back and tell you where it is. See?”

events.title: Mary Jane's Departure and a Final Revelation About the Money
detailed_summary: Huck advises Mary Jane to leave for Mr. Lothrop's before breakfast, arguing that her expressive face would inadvertently reveal her knowledge of the deception to her 'uncles'.
Mary Jane understands and agrees to go, but firmly states she will not send her love to the frauds, a sentiment Huck respects.
Huck then confesses to Mary Jane that he had stolen the bag of gold from the con men, intending to return it to her.
He explains that he was nearly caught and had to hide the money in the first available spot, expressing his deep regret that it might no longer be there and that the hiding place was not ideal.
Mary Jane consoles Huck, insisting it wasn't his fault.

Unwilling to verbally describe the grim location of the hidden money (Peter Wilks's coffin), Huck writes it down on a piece of paper for her to read on her way to Mr. Lothrop's: 'I put it in the coffin.'
Recalling Mary Jane's sorrow at the coffin, Huck is moved, and as he gives her the note, he sees tears in her eyes as well.
Mary Jane shakes his hand firmly, promises to follow all his instructions, and assures him she will never forget him and will pray for him, then departs.

Huck reflects on Mary Jane's remarkable character, her grit, goodness, and beauty, admitting he has thought of her countless times since her departure and is deeply touched by her promise to pray for him.

events.text_segment:
“’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”
“Why?”
“What did you reckon I wanted you to go at all for, Miss Mary?”
“Well, I never thought—and come to think, I don’t know. What was it?”
“Why, it’s because you ain’t one of these leather-face people. I don’t want no better book than what your face is. A body can set down and read it off like coarse print. Do you reckon you can go and face your uncles when they come to kiss you good-morning, and never—”
“There, there, don’t! Yes, I’ll go before breakfast—I’ll be glad to. And leave my sisters with them?”
“Yes; never mind about them. They’ve got to stand it yet a while. They might suspicion something if all of you was to go. I don’t want you to see them, nor your sisters, nor nobody in this town; if a neighbor was to ask how is your uncles this morning your face would tell something. No, you go right along, Miss Mary Jane, and I’ll fix it with all of them. I’ll tell Miss Susan to give your love to your uncles and say you’ve went away for a few hours for to get a little rest and change, or to see a friend, and you’ll be back to-night or early in the morning.”
“Gone to see a friend is all right, but I won’t have my love given to them.”
“Well, then, it sha’n’t be.” It was well enough to tell her so—no harm in it. It was only a little thing to do, and no trouble; and it’s the little things that smooths people’s roads the most, down here below; it would make Mary Jane comfortable, and it wouldn’t cost nothing. Then I says: “There’s one more thing—that bag of money.”
“Well, they’ve got that; and it makes me feel pretty silly to think how they got it.”
“No, you’re out, there. They hain’t got it.”
“Why, who’s got it?”
“I wish I knowed, but I don’t. I had it, because I stole it from them; and I stole it to give to you; and I know where I hid it, but I’m afraid it ain’t there no more. I’m awful sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I’m just as sorry as I can be; but I done the best I could; I did honest. I come nigh getting caught, and I had to shove it into the first place I come to, and run—and it warn’t a good place.”
“Oh, stop blaming yourself—it’s too bad to do it, and I won’t allow it—you couldn’t help it; it wasn’t your fault. Where did you hide it?”
I didn’t want to set her to thinking about her troubles again; and I couldn’t seem to get my mouth to tell her what would make her see that corpse laying in the coffin with that bag of money on his stomach. So for a minute I didn’t say nothing; then I says:
“I’d ruther not tell you where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, if you don’t mind letting me off; but I’ll write it for you on a piece of paper, and you can read it along the road to Mr. Lothrop’s, if you want to. Do you reckon that’ll do?”
“Oh, yes.”
So I wrote: “I put it in the coffin. It was in there when you was crying there, away in the night. I was behind the door, and I was mighty sorry for you, Miss Mary Jane.”
It made my eyes water a little to remember her crying there all by herself in the night, and them devils laying there right under her own roof, shaming her and robbing her; and when I folded it up and give it to her I see the water come into her eyes, too; and she shook me by the hand, hard, and says:
“Good-bye. I’m going to do everything just as you’ve told me; and if I don’t ever see you again, I sha’n’t ever forget you and I’ll think of you a many and a many a time, and I’ll pray for you, too!”—and she was gone.
Pray for me! I reckoned if she knowed me she’d take a job that was more nearer her size. But I bet she done it, just the same—she was just that kind. She had the grit to pray for Judus if she took the notion—there warn’t no back-down to her, I judge. You may say what you want to, but in my opinion she had more sand in her than any girl I ever see; in my opinion she was just full of sand. It sounds like flattery, but it ain’t no flattery. And when it comes to beauty—and goodness, too—she lays over them all. I hain’t ever seen her since that time that I see her go out of that door; no, I hain’t ever seen her since, but I reckon I’ve thought of her a many and a many a million times, and of her saying she would pray for me; and if ever I’d a thought it would do any good for me to pray for her, blamed if I wouldn’t a done it or bust.

’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”
“Why?”
“You’ll betray everybody with them eyes of yours.”
“Pooh—pooh! I ain’t a-going to betray anybody with them eyes. They couldn’t!”
“By good rights they couldn’t, Miss Mary Jane, but they will. They’re entirely too expressive. People will see them laugh when you tell about this business, and they won’t like it. They’ll mistrust right away. I know what’s what. You ain’t no actress; and besides, them fools can’t help acting themselves, and they’ll fetch somebody that’s shrewd, and then the fat’s in the fire.”
“You are right,” she says. “I never thought of that. My good Huckleberry, I’ll go, though I had rather stay and see it out.”
“You do right. Now look you, that thing has got to be done this day, without fail. It’s all fixed. The seals on the door ain’t any good at all. There’s keys to them seals, and the niggers ain’t being watched, and so it’s all right.”
“Thank you, Huckleberry. You are a good boy. Good-by, dear.”
“You ain’t a-going to send them any word at all?”
“No, not a word.”
“Well, I’ve told them I would, and they’ll be expecting it. I hain’t told them what, though. I’ll write it on a little piece of paper and give it to you to put in the post-office.”
“All right.”
“Then you must ride fifty mile straight off, Miss Mary Jane—no stopping for anything till you get to the square forty-mile town, which is fifty mile from here. And you must go right to the tavern, and inquire for Mr. Lothrop, because he’s the man who you and the girls was going to stay with by and by, wa’n’t you?”
“No. Mr. Lothrop’s in considerable trouble; we are going to rest a while first, at a private house. We only thought of going to see him after that.”
“Well, no matter; you go to the tavern and inquire for Mr. Lothrop. If he ain’t there, go to one of his friends and tell him what I tell you.”
“All right.”
“Yes—and you got to swear that you won’t tell anybody what you see up town till you get to Mr. Lothrop’s and tell him.”
“I swear.”
“And you got to swear that you won’t write a letter or send any message to them niggers, or anybody else, till you get to Mr. Lothrop’s.”
“All right. I swear.”
“Then you got to say your prayers, and promise the Lord no harm shall come to you for it.”
“All right. I promise.”
“And it ain’t no use to tell you it’s an awful risk—going to a body’s house that’s got smallpox.”
“I am willing to risk it,” she says, “and do anything you say, except betraying anybody.”
“Looky here, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “there’s a nigger here that I’ve run off. Huck Finn your name is. That’s all I get for it. I’ve stole the gold back from them, and hid it; and I reckon it’s anywhere between here and yonder piled-up lumber yard. But I hain’t got time to hunt it now. I’m a-going to slip out to-night and hunt it, and get it aboard the flatboat, and then I’ll come here and tell you where it is.”
“Oh, Huckleberry, you are a good boy, and I do thank you for it!”
“You ain’t a-going to tell on me, though, are you, Miss Mary Jane?”
“No, indeed, Huckleberry. I won’t ever tell on you, you poor thing! I won’t ever tell anybody—and I won’t ever forget you, and I’ll pray for you, too!”

“Miss Mary Jane, I don’t want you to do it. I don’t want you to pray for me. It ain’t no use. I’m a bad boy, and I ain’t no use to anybody. I wish I was dead.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”

“Oh, I can’t, Huck. I can’t get ready in the world to go before breakfast.”

“You can and you must. Hurry up, and slip out the back way. Please, Miss Mary Jane, it’s life and death, and you won’t ever regret it, believe me. They’re planning to steal everything and light out. You got to expose them, but you got to do it right, or they’ll get away, and maybe worse.”

She looked at me, her eyes wide and scared, but there was grit coming into them too. She was a good girl, Mary Jane was, and brave when it came to it. “But my sisters, Huck—Joanna and Susan—”

“Don’t you tell them a word!” I says, sharp. “Not a single word till it’s all over. That’s the main thing. If you tell them, they’ll look scared, or they’ll let on some way, and them frauds will smell a rat quicker’n you can wink. You got to go to Mr. Lothrop’s, him that you said was so trustworthy, and you got to stay there till ten o’clock to-night. Don’t you stir out. And when you get there, you write a letter to me—no, not to me, to yourself, but put it in an envelope and seal it, and give it to Mr. Lothrop, and tell him not to open it till he hears from you, or till ten o’clock to-night. And in that letter, you put down the place where you hid the money. You hid it, didn’t you?”

She nodded, her face pale. “Yes, Huck. Under the straw tick in their room.”

“Good! That’s the ticket! Now, you write that down in the letter. And at ten o’clock to-night, you send Mr. Lothrop word to open the letter and read it to the people that’ll be there. And you come home then, and everything will be all right. But mind you, not a word to nobody till ten o’clock—and especially not to your sisters.”

“But why, Huck? Why can’t I tell them?”

“Because,” I says, lowering my voice, “they ain’t got the nerve you have. They’d break down, sure. And besides, the less people that knows, the safer it is. Them villains are sharp. They watch every look, every move. If you tell your sisters, they’ll give it away without meaning to, and then the frauds will be gone with the money before you can say Jack Robinson. This way, you’ll be safe at Mr. Lothrop’s, and they won’t suspect a thing till it’s too late for them to do anything but get caught.”

She thought for a minute, biting her lip. Then she straightened up. “All right, Huck. I’ll do it. It’s dreadful, but I’ll do it. I’ll go right now.”

“That’s the girl!” I says, feeling a load lift off me. “Now, slip out quiet. Don’t let nobody see you. Go out the back way, through the garden, and make for Mr. Lothrop’s. And remember about the letter and ten o’clock.”

She nodded again, her eyes determined now. She turned and went soft-footed out of the room. I waited till I heard her door shut quiet, and then I slipped out myself and went down the stairs. My heart was thumping like a drum. Everything depended on Mary Jane now. If she did it right, them frauds would be exposed, and maybe I could get the money back and

events.title: Huck Deceives Susan and Joanna to Cover Mary Jane's Absence
detailed_summary: After Mary Jane secretly leaves, Huck approaches her sisters, Susan and Joanna (the 'hare-lip'), to explain Mary Jane's absence.
He initially tells them Mary Jane rushed off to visit a sick friend from across the river, named Hanner Proctor.

When pressed for details about Hanner's illness, Huck invents a complex and severe disease, describing it as a new kind of mumps mixed with measles, whooping cough, erysipelas, consumption, yellow jaundice, and brain fever.

He convinces the sisters that this 'pluribus-unum mumps' is highly contagious and that they shouldn't tell their 'uncles' about Mary Jane's exposure, as it would delay their trip to England for at least three months.
The sisters, eager to go to England, agree not to tell anyone, especially their 'uncles'.

Huck then refines the cover story, instructing the sisters to tell their 'uncles' that Mary Jane went to ask the wealthy Apthorp family to attend the auction and buy the house, as Peter Wilks would have wished it.
The sisters accept this explanation and go to inform the King and Duke, giving them Mary Jane's supposed love and kisses.

Huck feels satisfied with his elaborate deception, confident that the girls will remain silent due to their desire to go to England, and that the King and Duke will be content with Mary Jane being away, thus keeping her from encountering Doctor Robinson. He prides himself on handling the situation skillfully.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Everything was all right now. The girls wouldn’t say nothing because they wanted to go to England; and the king and the duke would ruther Mary Jane was off working for the auction than around in reach of Doctor Robinson. I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn’t a done it no neater himself. Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.

events.text_segment:
Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. When I struck Susan and the hare-lip, I says:
“What’s the name of them people over on t’other side of the river that you all goes to see sometimes?”
They says:
“There’s several; but it’s the Proctors, mainly.”
“That’s the name,” I says; “I most forgot it. Well, Miss Mary Jane she told me to tell you she’s gone over there in a dreadful hurry—one of them’s sick.”
“Which one?”
“I don’t know; leastways, I kinder forget; but I thinks it’s—”
“Sakes alive, I hope it ain’t Hanner?”
“I’m sorry to say it,” I says, “but Hanner’s the very one.”
“My goodness, and she so well only last week! Is she took bad?”
“It ain’t no name for it. They set up with her all night, Miss Mary Jane said, and they don’t think she’ll last many hours.”
“Only think of that, now! What’s the matter with her?”
I couldn’t think of anything reasonable, right off that way, so I says:
“Mumps.”
“Mumps your granny! They don’t set up with people that’s got the mumps.”
“They don’t, don’t they? You better bet they do with these mumps. These mumps is different. It’s a new kind, Miss Mary Jane said.”
“How’s it a new kind?”
“Because it’s mixed up with other things.”
“What other things?”
“Well, measles, and whooping-cough, and erysiplas, and consumption, and yaller janders, and brain-fever, and I don’t know what all.”
“My land! And they call it the mumps?”
“That’s what Miss Mary Jane said.”
“Well, what in the nation do they call it the mumps for?”
“Why, because it is the mumps. That’s what it starts with.”
“Well, ther’ ain’t no sense in it. A body might stump his toe, and take pison, and fall down the well, and break his neck, and bust his brains out, and somebody come along and ask what killed him, and some numskull up and say, ‘Why, he stumped his toe.’ Would ther’ be any sense in that? No. And ther’ ain’t no sense in this, nuther. Is it ketching?”
“Is it ketching? Why, how you talk. Is a harrow catching—in the dark? If you don’t hitch on to one tooth, you’re bound to on another, ain’t you? And you can’t get away with that tooth without fetching the whole harrow along, can you? Well, these kind of mumps is a kind of a harrow, as you may say—and it ain’t no slouch of a harrow, nuther, you come to get it hitched on good.”
“Well, it’s awful, I think,” says the hare-lip. “I’ll go to Uncle Harvey and—”
“Oh, yes,” I says, “I would. Of course I would. I wouldn’t lose no time.”
“Well, why wouldn’t you?”
“Just look at it a minute, and maybe you can see. Hain’t your uncles obleegd to get along home to England as fast as they can? And do you reckon they’d be mean enough to go off and leave you to go all that journey by yourselves? You know they’ll wait for you. So fur, so good. Your uncle Harvey’s a preacher, ain’t he? Very well, then; is a preacher going to deceive a steamboat clerk? is he going to deceive a ship clerk?—so as to get them to let Miss Mary Jane go aboard? Now you know he ain’t. What will he do, then? Why, he’ll say, ‘It’s a great pity, but my church matters has got to get along the best way they can; for my niece has been exposed to the dreadful pluribus-unum mumps, and so it’s my bounden duty to set down here and wait the three months it takes to show on her if she’s got it.’ But never mind, if you think it’s best to tell your uncle Harvey—”
“Shucks, and stay fooling around here when we could all be having good times in England whilst we was waiting to find out whether Mary Jane’s got it or not? Why, you talk like a muggins.”
“Well, anyway, maybe you’d better tell some of the neighbors.”
“Listen at that, now. You do beat all for natural stupidness. Can’t you see that they’d go and tell? Ther’ ain’t no way but just to not tell anybody at all.”
“Well, maybe you’re right—yes, I judge you are right.”
“But I reckon we ought to tell Uncle Harvey she’s gone out a while, anyway, so he won’t be uneasy about her?”
“Yes, Miss Mary Jane she wanted you to do that. She says, ‘Tell them to give Uncle Harvey and William my love and a kiss, and say I’ve run over the river to see Mr.’—Mr.—what is the name of that rich family your uncle Peter used to think so much of?—I mean the one that—”
“Why, you must mean the Apthorps, ain’t it?”
“Of course; bother them kind of names, a body can’t ever seem to remember them, half the time, somehow. Yes, she said, say she has run over for to ask the Apthorps to be sure and come to the auction and buy this house, because she allowed her uncle Peter would ruther they had it than anybody else; and she’s going to stick to them till they say they’ll come, and then, if she ain’t too tired, she’s coming home; and if she is, she’ll be home in the morning anyway. She said, don’t say nothing about the Proctors, but only about the Apthorps—which’ll be perfectly true, because she is going there to speak about their buying the house; I know it, because she told me so herself.”
“All right,” they said, and cleared out to lay for their uncles, and give them the love and the kisses, and tell them the message.
Everything was all right now. The girls wouldn’t say nothing because they wanted to go to England; and the king and the duke would ruther Mary Jane was off working for the auction than around in reach of Doctor Robinson. I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn’t a done it no neater himself. Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. It was right smart of her, and I knowed she wouldn't budge till I give the word. I felt powerful lonesome and shaky for a minute, thinking about her being gone and me left there amongst them frauds. But I didn't have no time to stand around shivering. I had to get that money. I slipped out of the room and down the stairs, my heart thumping like a drum. The house was quiet, but it felt like every board creaked just to spite me. I got to the parlor door and peeked in. The King and the Duke was still in there, talking low and serious. I reckon they was figuring out how to skin the rest of the property. I eased on past and went into the little room where the coffin was. It was dark and spooky in there, and the smell of death was heavy. I felt a cold sweat break out on me. I knowed I had to do it quick. I got down on my hands and knees by the coffin. My fingers trembled as I fumbled with the lid. It was heavy, and I had to strain to lift it just a little bit. I shoved my hand in under the edge, feeling around in the dark. It was awful. I expected to touch something cold and clammy any second. But my fingers closed on the bag. It was heavy, all right. I pulled it out slow and careful, trying not to make a sound. I got it out and let the lid down easy. Then I just knelt there for a second, holding the bag, my breath coming in short gasps. I had it. I had the money. Now what? I couldn't just walk out with it. I had to hide it again, somewhere safe, till I could get it to Mary Jane or figure out some other way. I thought about the cellar, but that seemed too risky. Too many places for them to look. I thought about the woods, but it was dark outside, and I didn't want to be stumbling around in the dark with that much money. My eyes fell on the big old clock in the corner of the room. It was one of them tall grandfather clocks. I got an idea. I stood up, still holding the bag tight. I opened the little door at the bottom of the clock. It was empty inside, just the weights and pendulum hanging there. I shoved the bag in amongst the weights. It fit snug. I closed the door and stood back, trying to look natural. My hands were still shaking. I felt a little better knowing the money wasn't in the coffin anymore, but I was still in a heap of trouble. I had to get out of there before they missed Mary Jane or got suspicious. I crept back out of the room and towards the back door. I heard voices in the parlor again, louder this time. I froze. It sounded like they was arguing. I couldn't make out what they was saying, but the tone was ugly. I didn't wait to hear more. I slipped out the back door and into the yard. The night air felt good on my face. I stood there for a minute, trying to decide what to do next. I wanted to get to Mary Jane, but I didn't know if it was safe. What if they had already figured out she was gone? What if they suspected me? I decided the best thing was to lay low for a bit and see what happened. I crept around the side of the house and hid behind some bushes near the parlor window. I could hear them plain now. They was yelling at each other. The King was accusing the Duke of trying to cheat him out of his share. The Duke was yelling back, saying the King was a greedy old fool. They was calling each other names and cussing something awful. It was a real show. I almost forgot I was in danger, watching them go at it. They was so busy fighting, they didn't even notice the steamboat whistle blowing down at the landing. I heard it, though. And then I heard a commotion down the street. Voices getting louder, footsteps hurrying. I peeked through the bushes. A crowd was coming up the street towards the house. And in the middle of the crowd, I saw two men that looked mighty familiar. One of them was tall and thin, with a long face and a kind of stoop. The other was shorter and stouter, with a round face and a bald head. My heart jumped into my mouth. It was the real Wilks brothers! Peter Wilks's actual brothers, Harvey and William, come all the way from England. I knowed it was them the minute I saw them. They looked just like the pictures Mary Jane had showed me. The crowd stopped in front of the house. The King and the Duke came rushing out onto the porch, looking surprised and a little scared. The tall man, Harvey, stepped forward. He looked around at the crowd, then his eyes fell on the King. "Who are you, sir?" he said, his voice clear and strong. The King puffed himself up. "I am your brother, Harvey Wilks, come to claim my inheritance!" he boomed out. Harvey just stared at him for a second, and then he let out a laugh. It wasn't a mean laugh, but it was full of disbelief. "My brother Harvey?" he said. "Why, I am Harvey Wilks! And this," he said, putting a hand on the shorter man's shoulder, "is my brother William." The crowd started murmuring. The King's face went white. The Duke looked like he wanted to sink through the floor. "This is an outrage!" the King sputtered. "These men are impostors! I am Harvey Wilks!" The real Harvey Wilks just shook his head. "We have papers," he said. "Letters from our brother Peter, describing us. And we have friends here in town who know us." He pointed to a couple of men in the crowd. They nodded their heads. The King and the Duke was trapped. They didn't know what to say. The crowd was getting restless. People was starting to look suspicious.

events.title: The Auction's Climax and the Arrival of True Claimants
detailed_summary: The auction of Peter Wilks's property takes place in the public square towards the end of the afternoon, proceeding slowly.
The King (the 'old man') is present next to the auctioneer, maintaining his fraudulent persona by interjecting with pious remarks and bits of Scripture.
The Duke is also active, mingling with the crowd and attempting to evoke sympathy with feigned sorrow.
After a lengthy process, nearly everything is sold, except for a small, insignificant lot in the graveyard which the King is eager to offload.
While they are still trying to sell this last piece of property, a steamboat arrives at the landing.
Within minutes, a noisy crowd disembarks from the steamboat, shouting, laughing, and creating a commotion as they make their way up from the river.
The newcomers dramatically announce their arrival, proclaiming themselves as the 'opposition line' and presenting 'two sets of heirs to old Peter Wilks,' offering the townspeople a choice.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, they held the auction in the public square, along towards the end of the afternoon, and it strung along, and strung along, and the old man he was on hand and looking his level pisonest, up there longside of the auctioneer, and chipping in a little Scripture now and then, or a little goody-goody saying of some kind, and the duke he was around goo-gooing for sympathy all he knowed how, and just spreading himself generly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Here’s your opposition line! here’s your two sets o’ heirs to old Peter Wilks—and you pays your money and you takes your choice!”

events.text_segment:
Well, they held the auction in the public square, along towards the end of the afternoon, and it strung along, and strung along, and the old man he was on hand and looking his level pisonest, up there longside of the auctioneer, and chipping in a little Scripture now and then, or a little goody-goody saying of some kind, and the duke he was around goo-gooing for sympathy all he knowed how, and just spreading himself generly.
But by-and-by the thing dragged through, and everything was sold—everything but a little old trifling lot in the graveyard. So they’d got to work that off—I never see such a girafft as the king was for wanting to swallow everything. Well, whilst they was at it a steamboat landed, and in about two minutes up comes a crowd a-whooping and yelling and laughing and carrying on, and singing out:
“Here’s your opposition line! here’s your two sets o’ heirs to old Peter Wilks—and you pays your money and you takes your choice!”

events.title: Arrival of the True Heirs
detailed_summary: Two new individuals, an older gentleman and a younger man with his arm in a sling, are brought into town, causing amusement among the crowd.
Huck, the narrator, does not find the situation humorous and anticipates that the duke and king will be disconcerted.
Contrary to Huck's expectation, the duke acts innocently pleased, while the king feigns sorrow over the appearance of what he implies are more impostors.
Several prominent townspeople show their allegiance by gathering around the king.
The newly arrived older gentleman appears utterly perplexed by the situation.
He addresses the crowd, revealing an authentic English accent, different from the king's imitation.
He introduces himself as Harvey Wilks and his companion as his brother William, who is deaf, mute, and further hampered by a broken arm.
Harvey explains their recent misfortunes: William's injury and their baggage being mistakenly left at a different town upriver.
He asserts their true identities and declares their intention to prove them upon the arrival of their baggage in a day or two, stating they will wait at the local hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”

events.text_segment:
They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. And, my souls, how the people yelled and laughed, and kept it up. But I didn’t see no joke about it, and I judged it would strain the duke and the king some to see any. I reckoned they’d turn pale. But no, nary a pale did they turn. The duke he never let on he suspicioned what was up, but just went a goo-gooing around, happy and satisfied, like a jug that’s googling out buttermilk; and as for the king, he just gazed and gazed down sorrowful on them new-comers like it give him the stomach-ache in his very heart to think there could be such frauds and rascals in the world. Oh, he done it admirable. Lots of the principal people gethered around the king, to let him see they was on his side. That old gentleman that had just come looked all puzzled to death. Pretty soon he begun to speak, and I see straight off he pronounced like an Englishman—not the king’s way, though the king’s was pretty good for an imitation. I can’t give the old gent’s words, nor I can’t imitate him; but he turned around to the crowd, and says, about like this:
“This is a surprise to me which I wasn’t looking for; and I’ll acknowledge, candid and frank, I ain’t very well fixed to meet it and answer it; for my brother and me has had misfortunes; he’s broke his arm, and our baggage got put off at a town above here last night in the night by a mistake. I am Peter Wilks’ brother Harvey, and this is his brother William, which can’t hear nor speak—and can’t even make signs to amount to much, now’t he’s only got one hand to work them with. We are who we say we are; and in a day or two, when I get the baggage, I can prove it. But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. And they all kind of laughed at the duke and the king, and begun to make fun of them. Well, I see right off it was a very serious thing, and I begun to feel dreadful; but you couldn't ever tell what the duke and the king was thinking, and you couldn't see no signs of trouble in them. They walked right along, and the king he was a-sobbing and a-carrying on, just the same. The crowd he made way for them, and they went up the steps and right into the house and shut the door. I got in as quick as I could, and shut the door, and they was all in the room so thick you couldn't more than turn around, and every soul of them was talking at once. And the duke and the king they stood there, looking very sorrowful and distressed and innocent. But the thing they said was, they warn't afraid; they was perfectly willing to face it; they wished they had come sooner, because then they could have stopped it at the start, and saved a world of trouble; but now things had got so tangled up, it was hard to know what to do. events.title: The King's Deflection and Hines's Accusation
detailed_summary: As the genuine Wilks brothers depart for the hotel, the king vociferously derides their explanation, suggesting their misfortunes are fabrications typical of frauds.
The majority of the onlookers laugh in agreement with the king.
However, a small group, including Doctor Robinson and a lawyer named Levi Bell, who has just arrived by steamboat, remain unconvinced and are seen conferring quietly.
A local man, identified later as Hines, steps forward and directly confronts the king about his account of arriving in town.
The king reiterates his claim of arriving by steamboat from Cincinnati the evening before the funeral.
Hines sharply contradicts the king, stating he personally saw the king, along with Tim Collins and a boy, at 'the Pint' that very morning, having arrived in a canoe.
Doctor Robinson inquires if Hines would recognize the boy again.
Hines immediately points to Huck, confirming him as the boy he saw with the king.

Doctor Robinson then addresses the crowd, expressing his conviction that the king and duke are impostors and proposing they all go to the tavern to confront the two pairs of claimants to ascertain the truth.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I reckon we’ll find out		something		before we get through.”

events.text_segment:
So him and the new dummy started off; and the king he laughs, and blethers out:
“Broke his arm—very likely, ain’t it?—and very convenient, too, for a fraud that’s got to make signs, and ain’t learnt how. Lost their baggage! That’s mighty good!—and mighty ingenious—under the circumstances!”
So he laughed again; and so did everybody else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen. One of these was that doctor; another one was a sharp-looking gentleman, with a carpet-bag of the old-fashioned kind made out of carpet-stuff, that had just come off of the steamboat and was talking to him in a low voice, and glancing towards the king now and then and nodding their heads—it was Levi Bell, the lawyer that was gone up to Louisville; and another one was a big rough husky that come along and listened to all the old gentleman said, and was listening to the king now. And when the king got done this husky up and says:
“Say, looky here; if you are Harvey Wilks, when’d you come to this town?”
“The day before the funeral, friend,” says the king.
“But what time o’ day?”
“In the evenin’—’bout an hour er two before sundown.”
“How’d you come?”
“I come down on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.”
“Well, then, how’d you come to be up at the Pint in the mornin’—in a canoe?”
“I warn’t up at the Pint in the mornin’.”
“It’s a lie.”
Several of them jumped for him and begged him not to talk that way to an old man and a preacher.
“Preacher be hanged, he’s a fraud and a liar. He was up at the Pint that mornin’. I live up there, don’t I? Well, I was up there, and he was up there. I see him there. He come in a canoe, along with Tim Collins and a boy.”
The doctor he up and says:
“Would you know the boy again if you was to see him, Hines?”
“I reckon I would, but I don’t know. Why, yonder he is, now. I know him perfectly easy.”
It was me he pointed at. The doctor says:
“Neighbors, I don’t know whether the new couple is frauds or not; but if these two ain’t frauds, I am an idiot, that’s all. I think it’s our duty to see that they don’t get away from here till we’ve looked into this thing. Come along, Hines; come along, the rest of you. We’ll take these fellows to the tavern and affront them with t’other couple, and I reckon we’ll find out something before we get through.”

events.title: The Investigation Begins: The Missing Gold
detailed_summary: The crowd, eager for the confrontation, proceeds with all parties to a spacious room in the hotel, where candles are lit.
Doctor Robinson voices his suspicion that the king and duke are frauds and expresses concern that any accomplices they might have could escape with Peter Wilks's gold.
He suggests that if the king and duke are genuine, they should not oppose sending for the money and allowing the townsfolk to keep it safe until their identities are proven.
The king, affecting a sorrowful demeanor, agrees with the sentiment but declares that the money is unfortunately no longer where it was.
He fabricates a story, claiming he hid the gold inside his straw mattress for safekeeping, as he was unaccustomed to 'niggers' and assumed their honesty like English servants.
He alleges that the slaves, whom he subsequently sold, stole the gold the very next morning after he had hidden it, and he hadn't missed it before their departure.
He further states that his 'servant,' Huck, can attest to these events.
The doctor and several others react with audible disbelief to the king's tale.

When questioned, Huck claims he did not witness the slaves stealing the money but did see them surreptitiously leaving the room and hurrying away, which he had assumed was due to fear of having awakened his master.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That was all they asked me.

events.text_segment:
It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started. It was about sundown. The doctor he led me along by the hand, and was plenty kind enough, but he never let go my hand.
We all got in a big room in the hotel, and lit up some candles, and fetched in the new couple. First, the doctor says:
“I don’t wish to be too hard on these two men, but I think they’re frauds, and they may have complices that we don’t know nothing about. If they have, won’t the complices get away with that bag of gold Peter Wilks left? It ain’t unlikely. If these men ain’t frauds, they won’t object to sending for that money and letting us keep it till they prove they’re all right—ain’t that so?”
Everybody agreed to that. So I judged they had our gang in a pretty tight place right at the outstart. But the king he only looked sorrowful, and says:
“Gentlemen, I wish the money was there, for I ain’t got no disposition to throw anything in the way of a fair, open, out-and-out investigation o’ this misable business; but, alas, the money ain’t there; you k’n send and see, if you want to.”
“Where is it, then?”
“Well, when my niece give it to me to keep for her I took and hid it inside o’ the straw tick o’ my bed, not wishin’ to bank it for the few days we’d be here, and considerin’ the bed a safe place, we not bein’ used to niggers, and suppos’n’ ’em honest, like servants in England. The niggers stole it the very next mornin’ after I had went down stairs; and when I sold ’em I hadn’t missed the money yit, so they got clean away with it. My servant here k’n tell you ’bout it, gentlemen.”
The doctor and several said “Shucks!” and I see nobody didn’t altogether believe him. One man asked me if I see the niggers steal it. I said no, but I see them sneaking out of the room and hustling away, and I never thought nothing, only I reckoned they was afraid they had waked up my master and was trying to get away before he made trouble with them. That was all they asked me.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started. It was about dark now. We all went into a big room in the hotel, and lit up. The doctor he stood grand and still, and didn’t say nothing; but everybody else was talking, and the noise went up just like it does when it’s raining and it starts on the roof—drip, drip, drip, splash, splash, splash! every now and then a shout, you know. Well, the doctor he waited till his chance come, and then he up and says:

“Set down, everybody. People, I found out something. Here is these two frauds, and I told you they warn’t nobody. Now is the time to prove it. These two chaps here has palmed themselves off as Peter Wilks’s brothers, and they’ve hoodwinked you marvelous. They hain’t Peter Wilks’s brothers; they are frauds, and I can prove it. Don’t say a word—not a single word. You wait, and let me talk; it’s my turn now. It was ME that sent for the real brothers to come. They are here.”

Everybody looked surprised. The doctor went on:

“I told you these warn’t Peter Wilks’s brothers; well, I’ve told the truth. And I told you they’d hoodwink you; well, they have. But you’ve been fooled by a couple of ignorant lunkheads, after all. Set down, everybody! Don’t crowd around me—get back—give me room. Let him stand up that says these two ain’t frauds. Not a soul? Very well. Now, let me have a word with YOU two.

“You didn’t know nothin’ about Peter Wilks, did you? You hain’t never seen him since you was boys, have you? And you never saw your brother George, nor your brother William, nuther, have you? Answer me!”

“Dr. Robinson, I will not allow you to talk like this. I am a respectable man, and old, and my head is gray. You insult me.”

“Old you are—though I haven’t got anything against that. But you hain’t respectable; you hain’t honest; and your head ain’t gray. You only THINK it’s gray; and you think you’re old, too, if you only knew yourself. Well, that’s enough. I’m going to show you up, now, before these people. It’s high time somebody did, anyway. People, ain’t these pilgrims men? Here they are, you see. They’re men. You’ve seen them act like men, hain’t you? Well, all right, then. I’m going to tell you what I know about them. It’s not much, but it’s enough. They are frauds. They are not Peter Wilks’s brothers. They are not even men. They are—well, I don’t know what they are. But they are frauds. That’s enough. Now, I’m going to prove it. Where is the gold?”

“Dr. Robinson, I protest! This is an outrage! I am a respectable man—”

“Oh, yes, I know. But where is the gold? That’s the point. You’ve got it, hain’t you? You’ve had it ever since you come here. Now, I want it. Where is it?”

“Dr. Robinson, I protest! I am a respectable man—”

“Oh, yes, I know. But where is the gold? That’s the point. You’ve got it, hain’t you? You’ve had it ever since you come here. Now, I want it. Where is it?”

“Dr. Robinson, I protest! I am a respectable man—”

events.title: Huck's Interrogation and Awkward Testimony
detailed_summary: Doctor Robinson abruptly turns his attention to Huck and questions if he is also English.
Huck affirms that he is, which elicits laughter and expressions of disbelief, such as 'Stuff!', from the doctor and others.
A lengthy and disorganized general investigation commences, continuing for hours without any mention of supper.
Both the king and the newly arrived old gentleman (the real Harvey Wilks) are compelled to share their respective narratives.
Huck privately observes that any unbiased person would easily discern that the old gentleman was telling the truth while the king was lying.
Eventually, Huck is called upon to provide his account of events.
The king gives Huck a subtle, sidelong glance, which Huck understands as a cue to support the king's version of the story.
Huck begins to invent details about their supposed life in Sheffield and information about the English Wilks family.
He does not get very far into his fabricated tale before Doctor Robinson starts to laugh.
Levi Bell, the lawyer, interjects, advising Huck to stop, remarking on his apparent lack of experience and skill in lying, and suggesting he needs more practice.
Although Huck doesn't appreciate the nature of the 'compliment,' he is relieved to be excused from further testimony.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then the doctor whirls on me and says:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I didn’t care nothing for the compliment, but I was glad to be let off, anyway.

events.text_segment:
Then the doctor whirls on me and says:
“Are you English, too?”
I says yes; and him and some others laughed, and said, “Stuff!”
Well, then they sailed in on the general investigation, and there we had it, up and down, hour in, hour out, and nobody never said a word about supper, nor ever seemed to think about it—and so they kept it up, and kept it up; and it was the worst mixed-up thing you ever see. They made the king tell his yarn, and they made the old gentleman tell his’n; and anybody but a lot of prejudiced chuckleheads would a seen that the old gentleman was spinning truth and t’other one lies. And by-and-by they had me up to tell what I knowed. The king he give me a left-handed look out of the corner of his eye, and so I knowed enough to talk on the right side. I begun to tell about Sheffield, and how we lived there, and all about the English Wilkses, and so on; but I didn’t get pretty fur till the doctor begun to laugh; and Levi Bell, the lawyer, says:
“Set down, my boy; I wouldn’t strain myself if I was you. I reckon you ain’t used to lying, it don’t seem to come handy; what you want is practice. You do it pretty awkward.”
I didn’t care nothing for the compliment, but I was glad to be let off, anyway.

events.title: The Handwriting Test Exposes Frauds but Adds Complexity
detailed_summary: As Doctor Robinson begins to speak, the king interrupts him to warmly greet Levi Bell, claiming that his deceased brother Peter often wrote about Bell.
The lawyer and the king shake hands and converse for a while, eventually stepping aside for a private discussion.
Following their conversation, the lawyer announces a plan involving an order that he will send, which should resolve the matter.
The king then sits down and, with some effort, scrawls something on a piece of paper.
When the pen is handed to the duke, he appears visibly ill for the first time but proceeds to write.
The lawyer then requests the newly arrived old gentleman (Harvey Wilks) and his brother (William Wilks) to write a line or two and sign their names.
The old gentleman writes, but his script is illegible to everyone.
The lawyer, looking very surprised, retrieves old letters from his pocket, purportedly from Harvey Wilks, and compares the handwriting.
He declares that the handwriting in the old letters does not match that of the king, the duke, or the new old gentleman, pointing out the king and duke's dismay at being caught.
He further comments that the new old gentleman's marks are not proper writing at all.
The new old gentleman explains that his mute brother William is the one who copies his letters, so the handwriting on the old documents is William's.
The lawyer, noting he also has letters from William, asks William to write, but Harvey explains William cannot write with his injured right hand and uses his left.
Harvey asks the lawyer to compare both sets of old letters, stating they are by the same hand (William's).

After examining them, the lawyer concedes a strong resemblance, admitting his current line of proof is partly foiled, but firmly reiterates that the king and duke are definitely not the Wilks brothers.

events.text_segment:
The doctor he started to say something, and turns and says:
“If you’d been in town at first, Levi Bell—” The king broke in and reached out his hand, and says:
“Why, is this my poor dead brother’s old friend that he’s wrote so often about?”
The lawyer and him shook hands, and the lawyer smiled and looked pleased, and they talked right along awhile, and then got to one side and talked low; and at last the lawyer speaks up and says:
“That’ll fix it. I’ll take the order and send it, along with your brother’s, and then they’ll know it’s all right.”
So they got some paper and a pen, and the king he set down and twisted his head to one side, and chawed his tongue, and scrawled off something; and then they give the pen to the duke—and then for the first time the duke looked sick. But he took the pen and wrote. So then the lawyer turns to the new old gentleman and says:
“You and your brother please write a line or two and sign your names.”
The old gentleman wrote, but nobody couldn’t read it. The lawyer looked powerful astonished, and says:
“Well, it beats me”—and snaked a lot of old letters out of his pocket, and examined them, and then examined the old man’s writing, and then them again; and then says: “These old letters is from Harvey Wilks; and here’s these two handwritings, and anybody can see they didn’t write them” (the king and the duke looked sold and foolish, I tell you, to see how the lawyer had took them in), “and here’s this old gentleman’s hand writing, and anybody can tell, easy enough, he didn’t write them—fact is, the scratches he makes ain’t properly writing at all. Now, here’s some letters from—”
The new old gentleman says:
“If you please, let me explain. Nobody can read my hand but my brother there—so he copies for me. It’s his hand you’ve got there, not mine.”
“Well!” says the lawyer, “this is a state of things. I’ve got some of William’s letters, too; so if you’ll get him to write a line or so we can com—”
“He can’t write with his left hand,” says the old gentleman. “If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote his own letters and mine too. Look at both, please—they’re by the same hand.”
The lawyer done it, and says:
“I believe it’s so—and if it ain’t so, there’s a heap stronger resemblance than I’d noticed before, anyway. Well, well, well! I thought we was right on the track of a solution, but it’s gone to grass, partly. But anyway, one thing is proved—these two ain’t either of ’em Wilkses”—and he wagged his head towards the king and the duke.

events.title: The Tattoo Controversy Deepens the Mystery
detailed_summary: Despite the evidence from the handwriting test, the king refuses to concede defeat, dismissing the test as unfair.
He claims his supposed brother William was merely playing a joke and hadn't genuinely tried to write.
The king passionately continues his defense, almost convincing himself of his own fabrications.
The real Harvey Wilks interrupts with a new idea for verification.
He asks if anyone present assisted in preparing the late Peter Wilks's body for burial.
Two men, one named Ab Turner, confirm their involvement.
Harvey Wilks then directly challenges the king to describe what, if anything, was tattooed on Peter Wilks's breast.
The king is visibly taken aback but quickly recovers, claiming Peter Wilks had a small, thin, blue arrow tattooed on his breast, so faint it was hard to see.
Huck is inwardly astonished by the king's sheer audacity.
The real Harvey, believing he has trapped the king, turns to Ab Turner and his companion, asking if they observed such a mark.
Both men firmly state they did not see any arrow tattoo.
Harvey Wilks then declares that the actual tattoo was a small, dim 'P-B-W' with dashes in between, sketching it on paper.
He asks the two men if this was the mark they saw.
However, both Ab Turner and his partner again deny this, stating they saw no marks whatsoever on Peter Wilks's breast.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, what do you think?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: No, we	didn’t. We never seen any marks at all.”

events.text_segment:
Well, what do you think? That muleheaded old fool wouldn’t give in then! Indeed he wouldn’t. Said it warn’t no fair test. Said his brother William was the cussedest joker in the world, and hadn’t tried to write—he see William was going to play one of his jokes the minute he put the pen to paper. And so he warmed up and went warbling and warbling right along till he was actuly beginning to believe what he was saying himself; but pretty soon the new gentleman broke in, and says:
“I’ve thought of something. Is there anybody here that helped to lay out my br—helped to lay out the late Peter Wilks for burying?”
“Yes,” says somebody, “me and Ab Turner done it. We’re both here.”
Then the old man turns towards the king, and says:
“Perhaps this gentleman can tell me what was tattooed on his breast?”
Blamed if the king didn’t have to brace up mighty quick, or he’d a squshed down like a bluff bank that the river has cut under, it took him so sudden; and, mind you, it was a thing that was calculated to make most anybody sqush to get fetched such a solid one as that without any notice, because how was he going to know what was tattooed on the man? He whitened a little; he couldn’t help it; and it was mighty still in there, and everybody bending a little forwards and gazing at him. Says I to myself, Now he’ll throw up the sponge—there ain’t no more use. Well, did he? A body can’t hardly believe it, but he didn’t. I reckon he thought he’d keep the thing up till he tired them people out, so they’d thin out, and him and the duke could break loose and get away. Anyway, he set there, and pretty soon he begun to smile, and says:
“Mf! It’s a very tough question, ain’t it! Yes, sir, I k’n tell you what’s tattooed on his breast. It’s jest a small, thin, blue arrow—that’s what it is; and if you don’t look clost, you can’t see it. Now what do you say—hey?”
Well, I never see anything like that old blister for clean out-and-out cheek.
The new old gentleman turns brisk towards Ab Turner and his pard, and his eye lights up like he judged he’d got the king this time, and says:
“There—you’ve heard what he said! Was there any such mark on Peter Wilks’ breast?”
Both of them spoke up and says:
“We didn’t see no such mark.”
“Good!” says the old gentleman. “Now, what you did see on his breast was a small dim P, and a B (which is an initial he dropped when he was young), and a W, with dashes between them, so: P—B—W”—and he marked them that way on a piece of paper. “Come, ain’t that what you saw?”
Both of them spoke up again, and says:
“No, we didn’t. We never seen any marks at all.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, what do you think? — the king he says, he "warn't going to stand this kind of nonsense all the no account humbug about handwriting and such rot." Says, "there ain't no handwriting about it; that is the hand of Providence, that's what it is; and the darkest disposition the devil ever stood up in the nighest corner of hell could n't beat that." And so on, and so on. He raged up and down, with his face as red as fire, the whole time, roaring, and shaking his fist, and all that; and everybody else stood pale and scared, and not saying a word; and the duke, he groaned and moaned, and took on, but it warn't no use—nobody minding him. And he said new old gentleman was a fraud, and said the handwriting expert was a fraud, and said Tom Sawyer was an impostor, and said Sid Sawyer was an impostor, and said Mary Jane was an impostor, and said Susan was an impostor, and said Joanner was an impostor, and said they was all of them impostors, and said they bought the boys to swear that paper was wrote by William, when it was wrote by his own self. And then he come a-blubbering down on the mourners, and put his arm around the duke, and says, "Oh, the mockeries of this world! Oh, the deception and villainy of it! Oh, William, my poor brother, I knew you was dead, because you was so sick, but who'd a thought we'd meet up like this, in a strange land, and far away from home, and all of us friends together, and you so changed from what you was, and all your hair gone, and you so pale and weak!" And when he'd got a little calm again, he says, "But, bless you, it's all right; all we got to do is to prove who the rightful heirs is." Then he says, "You see," all of a sudden, "you see, the paper ain't of no consequence, now. I don't say who wrote the paper, or who didn't write it. I only say it ain't of no consequence. Fees before witnesses, that's what I say. If I've got to prove who I am, I can do it. I can do it easy. I can do it in a second. The only trouble is, I don't know the law, and I don't know what you want, or what you don't want. But just you tell me what you want, and I'll furnish the proofs." The new old gentleman says, "Well, then, what do you say to this? There was a tattoo-mark on his breast." The king he winced, and then he says, "Yes, there was. I know that. It was a small, thin, blue arrow—just over the breast—not very plain, you understand—but still, you could see it. Now," says he, "what do you say to that?" The new old gentleman says, "Well, I say it warn't no arrow. I say it was P-B-W." The king he winced again, and then he says, "No, it warn't. It was an arrow. I know it was an arrow. I seen it myself. It was a small, thin, blue arrow, and it was just over the breast. Now," says he, "what do you say to that?" The new old gentleman says, "Well, I say it warn't no arrow. events.title: Decision to Exhume the Body
detailed_summary: The contradictory testimonies regarding the tattoo leave the crowd utterly confused and agitated.
Many begin to shout that all the claimants are frauds and call for violent retribution, such as ducking, drowning, or riding them on a rail.
Amidst the uproar, the lawyer, Levi Bell, jumps onto a table, yelling to gain the crowd's attention and pleading for a moment to speak.
He proposes one final method to resolve the matter: exhuming Peter Wilks's corpse to directly examine it for any identifying marks.
This suggestion immediately captures the crowd's approval, and they shout their agreement, ready to proceed at once.
The lawyer and Doctor Robinson interject, instructing the crowd to detain all four men—the king, the duke, and the two real Wilks brothers—as well as Huck, and bring them to the graveyard.
The crowd enthusiastically agrees, vowing to lynch the entire group if the specified marks are not found on the body.
Huck admits to being deeply frightened by this dangerous turn of events.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I	was	scared, now, I tell you.

events.text_segment:
Well, everybody was in a state of mind now, and they sings out:
“The whole bilin’ of ’m ’s frauds! Le’s duck ’em! le’s drown ’em! le’s ride ’em on a rail!” and everybody was whooping at once, and there was a rattling powwow. But the lawyer he jumps on the table and yells, and says:
“Gentlemen—gentlemen! Hear me just a word—just a single word—if you PLEASE! There’s one way yet—let’s go and dig up the corpse and look.”
That took them.
“Hooray!” they all shouted, and was starting right off; but the lawyer and the doctor sung out:
“Hold on, hold on! Collar all these four men and the boy, and fetch them along, too!”
“We’ll do it!” they all shouted; “and if we don’t find them marks we’ll lynch the whole gang!”
I was scared, now, I tell you.

events.title: The Stormy Exhumation, Gold's Discovery, and Huck's Escape
detailed_summary: Huck recognizes the impossibility of escape as the group is marched towards the graveyard, located a mile and a half downriver, with the entire town following.
Passing the house where he stayed, Huck wistfully wishes Mary Jane were present, believing she could help him escape and expose the fraudulent king and duke.
The journey to the graveyard is tense; the sky darkens ominously, lightning begins to flash, and the wind rustles through the leaves, creating a frightening atmosphere.
Huck feels more terrified and in greater danger than ever before, as his fate now seems to depend entirely on the presence or absence of the tattoo marks.
Hines, the man who identified Huck earlier, keeps a firm grip on Huck's wrist, making escape seem impossible.
Upon arriving at the graveyard, the crowd swarms in, possessing an abundance of shovels but having forgotten to bring a lantern.
They begin digging by the sporadic illumination of lightning flashes while a man is sent to a nearby house to borrow a lantern.
The digging continues with fervent intensity, oblivious to the worsening storm, which now includes heavy rain, strong winds, and booming thunder.
The scene alternates between brief, vivid illumination by lightning and complete darkness.
At last, the coffin is unearthed, and the lid is unscrewed, prompting a chaotic rush as people push to get a view of the body in the dark.
Suddenly, a powerful flash of lightning reveals the scene, and someone exclaims that the bag of gold is on the deceased's breast.
In the ensuing commotion and excitement, Hines shouts along with everyone else, drops Huck's wrist, and surges forward to see, allowing Huck to seize the moment and flee unseen into the darkness.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Hines let out a whoop, like everybody else, and dropped my wrist and give a big surge to bust his way in and get a look, and the way I lit out and shinned for the road in the dark there ain’t nobody can tell.

events.text_segment:
But there warn’t no getting away, you know. They gripped us all, and marched us right along, straight for the graveyard, which was a mile and a half down the river, and the whole town at our heels, for we made noise enough, and it was only nine in the evening.
As we went by our house I wished I hadn’t sent Mary Jane out of town; because now if I could tip her the wink she’d light out and save me, and blow on our dead-beats.
Well, we swarmed along down the river road, just carrying on like wildcats; and to make it more scary the sky was darking up, and the lightning beginning to wink and flitter, and the wind to shiver amongst the leaves. This was the most awful trouble and most dangersome I ever was in; and I was kinder stunned; everything was going so different from what I had allowed for; stead of being fixed so I could take my own time if I wanted to, and see all the fun, and have Mary Jane at my back to save me and set me free when the close-fit come, here was nothing in the world betwixt me and sudden death but just them tattoo-marks. If they didn’t find them—
I couldn’t bear to think about it; and yet, somehow, I couldn’t think about nothing else. It got darker and darker, and it was a beautiful time to give the crowd the slip; but that big husky had me by the wrist—Hines—and a body might as well try to give Goliar the slip. He dragged me right along, he was so excited, and I had to run to keep up.
When they got there they swarmed into the graveyard and washed over it like an overflow. And when they got to the grave they found they had about a hundred times as many shovels as they wanted, but nobody hadn’t thought to fetch a lantern. But they sailed into digging anyway by the flicker of the lightning, and sent a man to the nearest house, a half a mile off, to borrow one.
So they dug and dug like everything; and it got awful dark, and the rain started, and the wind swished and swushed along, and the lightning come brisker and brisker, and the thunder boomed; but them people never took no notice of it, they was so full of this business; and one minute you could see everything and every face in that big crowd, and the shovelfuls of dirt sailing up out of the grave, and the next second the dark wiped it all out, and you couldn’t see nothing at all.
At last they got out the coffin and begun to unscrew the lid, and then such another crowding and shouldering and shoving as there was, to scrouge in and get a sight, you never see; and in the dark, that way, it was awful. Hines he hurt my wrist dreadful pulling and tugging so, and I reckon he clean forgot I was in the world, he was so excited and panting.
All of a sudden the lightning let go a perfect sluice of white glare, and somebody sings out:
“By the living jingo, here’s the bag of gold on his breast!”
Hines let out a whoop, like everybody else, and dropped my wrist and give a big surge to bust his way in and get a look, and the way I lit out and shinned for the road in the dark there ain’t nobody can tell.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But there warn’t no getting away, you know. They packed us along with the crowd, and the whole town packed along after us, so there couldn’t be nothing done. They marched us over to the graveyard and stopped. We stood around three or four minutes considerable perplexed, just waiting for something to happen that nobody knew what it was. So they started in digging, and they dug in solemn silence. They dug as much as a foot down, and the rain begun to drip, and come down faster and faster, till it was a regular storm. They kept on digging, and nobody said a word. We stood there, getting soaked and shivering, and the lightning was ripping around and the thunder a-booming, and the wind a-blowing the clothes tight against our bodies. At last they hit something hard. It was the coffin. They got a rope around it and hoisted it out of the hole. They unscrewed the lid, and everybody crowded around to look. The lightning flashed out, and somebody shouted, “There it is!” and sure enough, there was the bag of gold on the breast of the dead man. The crowd surged forward, and Hines, who had hold of my wrist, let go and plunged in with the rest. I didn’t wait for no second invitation. I lit out and went tearing down the road, and the storm was a-howling and the thunder a-crashing and the lightning a-blazing, and I was the most scared I ever was in my life.
