LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I said, “Don’t do nothing of the kind; it’s one of the most jackass ideas I ever struck;” but he never paid no attention to me; went right on. He was all fired up about how we had to do it the regular way, the way they did in the books. He said we had to dig Jim out with case-knives, and saw the leg off the bed, and write messages on a shirt with blood, and have a rope-ladder made out of sheets, and all sorts of foolishness like that. I told him it was crazy, that it would take forever, and likely get us all caught, or worse, get Jim killed. It was too much trouble for nothing. We could just lift the latch or steal the key and be done with it quick and easy. But Tom, he just wouldn't listen to sense. He said that wouldn't be romantic or adventurous enough. It had to be done with style and difficulty, or it wouldn't count as a proper rescue. He was so excited about all the unnecessary complications, his eyes shining like he'd found a gold mine. He started talking about moats and sentinels and secret signs, things that had no business being mixed up with getting a poor runaway slave free. It made my head swim just listening to him. I knew it was going to be a heap of trouble, and probably wouldn't work, but when Tom Sawyer gets an idea, there ain't no stopping him. He just drags you along whether you want to go or not. I sighed and figured I was in for it, no matter how much I knew it was pure foolishness.

events.title: The Painful Candlestick Prank and an Unexpected Canine Intrusion
detailed_summary: The next morning, Tom and Huck go to the woodpile and chop the stolen brass candlestick into manageable pieces.
Tom pockets these pieces along with the pewter spoon.
They proceed to the slave cabins where, while Huck distracts Nat, Jim's caretaker, Tom embeds a piece of the candlestick into a corn-pone meant for Jim's meal.
They accompany Nat to witness the outcome of their prank.
The prank succeeds dramatically when Jim bites into the corn-pone, almost breaking all his teeth on the hidden metal piece.
Jim, however, does not betray any awareness of the prank, merely acting as if he encountered a common stone in his bread.
This incident leads Jim to meticulously inspect all his food with a fork before taking a bite thereafter.
As they stand in the dim cabin, a sudden commotion occurs as eleven hounds burst in from under Jim's bed, having entered through the lean-to door which the boys had forgotten to secure.
Nat, utterly terrified by the sudden appearance of the dogs, screams "Witches" once before collapsing onto the floor amidst them, groaning as if he were dying.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the morning we went out to the woodpile and chopped up the brass candlestick into handy sizes, and Tom put them and the pewter spoon in his pocket.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The nigger Nat he only just hollered “Witches” once, and keeled over on to the floor amongst the dogs, and begun to groan like he was dying.

events.text_segment:
In the morning we went out to the woodpile and chopped up the brass candlestick into handy sizes, and Tom put them and the pewter spoon in his pocket. Then we went to the nigger cabins, and while I got Nat’s notice off, Tom shoved a piece of candlestick into the middle of a corn-pone that was in Jim’s pan, and we went along with Nat to see how it would work, and it just worked noble; when Jim bit into it it most mashed all his teeth out; and there warn’t ever anything could a worked better. Tom said so himself. Jim he never let on but what it was only just a piece of rock or something like that that’s always getting into bread, you know; but after that he never bit into nothing but what he jabbed his fork into it in three or four places first.
And whilst we was a-standing there in the dimmish light, here comes a couple of the hounds bulging in from under Jim’s bed; and they kept on piling in till there was eleven of them, and there warn’t hardly room in there to get your breath. By jings, we forgot to fasten that lean-to door! The nigger Nat he only just hollered “Witches” once, and keeled over on to the floor amongst the dogs, and begun to groan like he was dying.

events.title: Tom Exploits Nat's Superstition with the "Witch Pie" Ruse
detailed_summary: Tom reacts quickly to the hound invasion, throwing a piece of Jim's meat to distract the dogs, then slips out to secure the lean-to door and returns.
He attempts to soothe the terrified Nat, suggesting that Nat might have merely imagined the swarm of dogs.

Nat, however, remains adamant, vividly describing his conviction that he saw nearly a million dogs or devils and felt their presence all over him, expressing both a desire for revenge on the 'witches' and a stronger wish to be left alone by them.
Tom seizes upon Nat's superstitious fear, theorizing that the 'witches' (the dogs) appeared at the runaway slave's breakfast time because they were hungry.
He then proposes that Nat should make a 'witch pie' to appease these supernatural visitors.
When Nat confesses his ignorance on how to prepare such a pie, Tom offers to make it himself, an offer Nat gratefully accepts.

Tom then issues a series of mysterious instructions to Nat: he must turn his back while the pie is being prepared, not acknowledge anything put into the pan, avoid looking when Jim unloads the pan, and, most importantly, never touch any of the 'witch-things'.
Nat, thoroughly convinced of the supernatural danger, vehemently promises to follow Tom's instructions, asserting he wouldn't touch the enchanted items for an astronomical sum of money.

events.text_segment:
Tom jerked the door open and flung out a slab of Jim’s meat, and the dogs went for it, and in two seconds he was out himself and back again and shut the door, and I knowed he’d fixed the other door too. Then he went to work on the nigger, coaxing him and petting him, and asking him if he’d been imagining he saw something again. He raised up, and blinked his eyes around, and says:
“Mars Sid, you’ll say I’s a fool, but if I didn’t b’lieve I see most a million dogs, er devils, er some’n, I wisht I may die right heah in dese tracks. I did, mos’ sholy. Mars Sid, I felt um—I felt um, sah; dey was all over me. Dad fetch it, I jis’ wisht I could git my han’s on one er dem witches jis’ wunst—on’y jis’ wunst—it’s all I’d ast. But mos’ly I wisht dey’d lemme ’lone, I does.”
Tom says:
“Well, I tell you what I think. What makes them come here just at this runaway nigger’s breakfast-time? It’s because they’re hungry; that’s the reason. You make them a witch pie; that’s the thing for you to do.”
“But my lan’, Mars Sid, how’s I gwyne to make ’m a witch pie? I doan’ know how to make it. I hain’t ever hearn er sich a thing b’fo’.”
“Well, then, I’ll have to make it myself.”
“Will you do it, honey?—will you? I’ll wusshup de groun’ und’ yo’ foot, I will!”
“All right, I’ll do it, seeing it’s you, and you’ve been good to us and showed us the runaway nigger. But you got to be mighty careful. When we come around, you turn your back; and then whatever we’ve put in the pan, don’t you let on you see it at all. And don’t you look when Jim unloads the pan—something might happen, I don’t know what. And above all, don’t you handle the witch-things.”
“Hannel ’m, Mars Sid? What is you a-talkin’ ’bout? I wouldn’ lay de weight er my finger on um, not f’r ten hund’d thous’n billion dollars, I wouldn’t.”

Why, what under the sun was the matter? Don’t you stand there palavering all day, but tell us what was the trouble.” Nat he only shivered, and says: “I hain’t ever had no heart to tell no tale till now. I break out all over, I can’t hardly stand it. I’ve been setting here ever since, shiverin’ and shakin’, and drenched for the want of a dry rag. For goodness gracious sakes, Mr. Tom, don’t ask me nothin’—don’t ask me a single thing; just let me alone—let me alone.” “Shucks, it ain’t nothing but right that the dogs went for you, Nat, after the way you served them.” “Who? Me? I hain’t done nothing to them, poor things, I swear.” “Well, you must have done something. They wouldn’t come at you like that for nothing.” “I tell you, Mr. Tom, I hain’t done nothing. I was setting here, just like I am now, and I heard a noise, and I looked up, and there was a million dogs, or devils, or something, and they was all over me, and I felt them, and I was so scared I couldn’t move, and I thought I was going to die, and I hain’t ever been so scared in all my life.” “Well, Nat, I reckon you was scared, but I don’t reckon there was a million dogs. events.title: Preparations and Planting Evidence for Jim's Escape
detailed_summary: Huck and Tom searched a rubbish pile for necessary items.
They found an old tin washpan to bake a pie in, stopping its holes.
They took the washpan to the cellar and filled it with stolen flour.
They found two shingle-nails, which Tom suggested a prisoner could use to write on dungeon walls.
One nail was placed in Aunt Sally's apron pocket, which was on a chair.
The other nail was stuck in the band of Uncle Silas's hat on the bureau.
They did this knowing the Phelpses planned to visit Jim (the runaway nigger) that morning.
At breakfast, before Aunt Sally arrived, Tom put a pewter spoon into Uncle Silas's coat pocket.
They had to wait for Aunt Sally to join them for breakfast.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That was all fixed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn’t hardly wait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with one hand and cracking the handiest child’s head with her thimble with the other, and says:

events.text_segment: That was all fixed. So then we went away and went to the rubbage-pile in the back yard, where they keep the old boots, and rags, and pieces of bottles, and wore-out tin things, and all such truck, and scratched around and found an old tin washpan, and stopped up the holes as well as we could, to bake the pie in, and took it down cellar and stole it full of flour and started for breakfast, and found a couple of shingle-nails that Tom said would be handy for a prisoner to scrabble his name and sorrows on the dungeon walls with, and dropped one of them in Aunt Sally’s apron-pocket which was hanging on a chair, and t’other we stuck in the band of Uncle Silas’s hat, which was on the bureau, because we heard the children say their pa and ma was going to the runaway nigger’s house this morning, and then went to breakfast, and Tom dropped the pewter spoon in Uncle Silas’s coat-pocket, and Aunt Sally wasn’t come yet, so we had to wait a little while.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: That was all fixed. So then we went to searching around for some more things. We found an old tin washpan, and stopped up the holes with dough, and sunk it in water to swell the dough -- sowe could bake a pie in it. We found an old saw, but it warn't filed, and we couldn't file it; we ain't got a file. But we found an old shovel, and an old pick-axe, and a rusty old tin coffee-pot. We found some candlesticks and some tallow candles in the bottom of a dilapidated old hair trunk; and found some pewter spoons, and a tin plate in a box; and we found a rat in the garret that had been dead a long time, and hadn't been buried. She was dried up and stiff. I taken a notion to stuff her and stand her up on the limb of a tree to scare the children, but Tom said no; he allowed we hadn't time to fool away on no rats. We found a spinning-wheel, and a hair-sofy, and a wooden clock, and a barrel of rags. We found a real handsome old card-board box, that was paint all over, not pretty, but gaudy -- what you call gaudy. The lid was hinged on with rags. We found an old pipe, and a tin lantern; and a bottle that had had lightning-rod fluid in it; and a jug that was jug, though it had a handle, and a spout, and was a lady, too, no doubt, for that is the way they make jugs, and I've seen a many of them at home, and they ain't got no legs. Well, that was about all. We shoved the things under the front porch and hid them. One thing was we got to thinking of was, Jim might want some light to do his work by, and Tom said the rats would eat the candles, and the candles wouldn't make light enough anyway; and that what Jim needed was a spoon, and plenty of them, so as to dig a passage under the cabin, and STATEMENT: why you couldn't dig with a spoon, and STATEMENT: why you could dig with a spoon. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: That was all fixed. So then we went to searching around for some more things. We found an old tin washpan, and stopped up the holes with dough, and sunk it in water to swell the dough -- so we could bake a pie in it. We found two shingle-nails, and Tom said they'd come handy for a prisoner to scratch his name and sorrows on the walls of his dungeon, and so they had to be saved. Then we took the tin washpan at midnight and went down in the cellar and stole the flour, and filled the pan with the flour, and hid the pan and flour away. And when breakfast was ready, we waited and waited and waited, for Aunt Sally to come down; but she didn't come, and didn't come, and didn't come. So at last Uncle Silas he said he wouldn't wait no longer, but set down and went to tearing away at the meat and other things, and we set in, too. Of course our hands and faces were perfectly clean, and so was our clothes; for we'd got up early and washed. But we didn't know what the upshot was going to be; and we felt pretty mean, and pretty uncomfortable. While we was eating, Tom he reached over and put a pewter spoon in Uncle Silas's coat pocket. Uncle Silas says: "Why, what's this?" "Nothing," says Tom. "It's only a spoon." "A spoon? What business has a spoon in my pocket?" "Well, I don't know, Uncle Silas; I reckon somebody put it there." "Somebody put it there? Who do you reckon it was?" "I don't know; must 'a' been you, Uncle Silas; you ain't got anybody else to blame." He looked kind of bothered, and stood there with his mouth full, considering; and his eye got kind of glazed and vacant, and he seemed to lose himself. Then he shook his head, and sighed, and says: "I reckon I did do it, Tom; but it's the most puzzlingest thing I ever heard of." And he went on eating. So then we went and stuck one of the shingle-nails in Aunt Sally's apron pocket that was hanging on a chair; and whilst we was at it, we stuck the other one in the band of Uncle Silas's hat that was laying on the bureau; because we heard the Phelpses was going to see Jim that morning, and we wanted them to have something to find.

events.title: Breakfast Turmoil: The Mystery of the Missing Items
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally arrived for breakfast visibly hot, flushed, and annoyed, immediately disciplining a child.
She exclaimed her frustration over Uncle Silas's other shirt being missing despite extensive searching.
Huck was startled, and a piece of corn-crust he was eating shot out of his mouth, hitting a child.
Tom also appeared visibly uneasy due to this unexpected complication.
Uncle Silas expressed his confusion, stating he knew he had taken the shirt off.
Aunt Sally countered that she saw it on the clothesline the previous day and that it was now gone, forcing Uncle Silas to wear a red flannel one.
She lamented having to make him a third shirt in two years, puzzled by how he managed to lose them.
Uncle Silas defended himself, saying he only wears the shirts and doesn't believe he loses them while wearing them.
Aunt Sally retorted that other items were also missing: a spoon (from a set of ten, now nine) and six candles.
She speculated that rats might have taken the candles, criticizing Uncle Silas for not stopping their holes, but insisted rats wouldn't take a spoon.
Uncle Silas admitted his fault regarding the rat holes and promised to fix them the next day.
Aunt Sally sarcastically told him not to rush, then disciplined another child for reaching for the sugar bowl.
A servant woman, Lize, then reported that a sheet was missing from the clothesline.
Uncle Silas, looking sorrowful, reiterated his promise to stop up the rat holes that very day.
Aunt Sally angrily dismissed the idea of rats taking a sheet and questioned Lize about its whereabouts.
Lize confirmed the sheet was on the line yesterday but was gone now.
Aunt Sally despaired at the series of disappearances, listing the shirt, sheet, spoon, and starting to mention the candles when interrupted.
A young female servant then announced that a brass candlestick was also missing.
Aunt Sally, now utterly incensed, threatened the servant with a skillet.

events.text_segment:
And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn’t hardly wait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with one hand and cracking the handiest child’s head with her thimble with the other, and says:
“I’ve hunted high and I’ve hunted low, and it does beat all what has become of your other shirt.”
My heart fell down amongst my lungs and livers and things, and a hard piece of corn-crust started down my throat after it and got met on the road with a cough, and was shot across the table, and took one of the children in the eye and curled him up like a fishing-worm, and let a cry out of him the size of a warwhoop, and Tom he turned kinder blue around the gills, and it all amounted to a considerable state of things for about a quarter of a minute or as much as that, and I would a sold out for half price if there was a bidder. But after that we was all right again—it was the sudden surprise of it that knocked us so kind of cold. Uncle Silas he says:
“It’s most uncommon curious, I can’t understand it. I know perfectly well I took it off, because—”
“Because you hain’t got but one on. Just listen at the man! I know you took it off, and know it by a better way than your wool-gethering memory, too, because it was on the clo’s-line yesterday—I see it there myself. But it’s gone, that’s the long and the short of it, and you’ll just have to change to a red flann’l one till I can get time to make a new one. And it’ll be the third I’ve made in two years. It just keeps a body on the jump to keep you in shirts; and whatever you do manage to do with ’m all is more’n I can make out. A body ’d think you would learn to take some sort of care of ’em at your time of life.”
“I know it, Sally, and I do try all I can. But it oughtn’t to be altogether my fault, because, you know, I don’t see them nor have nothing to do with them except when they’re on me; and I don’t believe I’ve ever lost one of them off of me.”
“Well, it ain’t your fault if you haven’t, Silas; you’d a done it if you could, I reckon. And the shirt ain’t all that’s gone, nuther. Ther’s a spoon gone; and that ain’t all. There was ten, and now ther’s only nine. The calf got the shirt, I reckon, but the calf never took the spoon, that’s certain.”
“Why, what else is gone, Sally?”
“Ther’s six candles gone—that’s what. The rats could a got the candles, and I reckon they did; I wonder they don’t walk off with the whole place, the way you’re always going to stop their holes and don’t do it; and if they warn’t fools they’d sleep in your hair, Silas—you’d never find it out; but you can’t lay the spoon on the rats, and that I know.”
“Well, Sally, I’m in fault, and I acknowledge it; I’ve been remiss; but I won’t let to-morrow go by without stopping up them holes.”
“Oh, I wouldn’t hurry; next year’ll do. Matilda Angelina Araminta Phelps!”
Whack comes the thimble, and the child snatches her claws out of the sugar-bowl without fooling around any. Just then the nigger woman steps on to the passage, and says:
“Missus, dey’s a sheet gone.”
“A sheet gone! Well, for the land’s sake!”
“I’ll stop up them holes to-day,” says Uncle Silas, looking sorrowful.
“Oh, do shet up!—s’pose the rats took the sheet? Where’s it gone, Lize?”
“Clah to goodness I hain’t no notion, Miss’ Sally. She wuz on de clo’sline yistiddy, but she done gone: she ain’ dah no mo’ now.”
“I reckon the world is coming to an end. I never see the beat of it in all my born days. A shirt, and a sheet, and a spoon, and six can—”
“Missus,” comes a young yaller wench, “dey’s a brass cannelstick miss’n.”
“Cler out from here, you hussy, er I’ll take a skillet to ye!”

And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn’t hardly wait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with one hand and cracking the handiest child’s head with her thimble with the other, and says:

“I b’lieve the child’s crazy—shet up!—Don’t you reckon I know who it is? It’s Uncle Silas—and him a preacher, too, and a deacon besides—away out in the woods, eight mile from anywheres, and his church only three mile off, yet; he can’t nobody hear him preach but a little handful, all told, and they ain’t never been used to no other preacher but him all their lives, and so they’ve got to stand it, I reckon. And he’s a-preachin’ and a-preachin’ away, and in his righteous mind he knows he don’t belong there at all; and he knows he’s got to come to dinner, too, and yet he stays away all the mornin’, no doubt, and preaches his fool head off, for forty cents a year, when he’s got one of the likeliest plantations in this State. It ain’t right, and I wouldn’t do it if I was him. No, sir, I wouldn’t do it. And what’s become of that shirt?”

Now, that took me aback. I says to myself, and blushes like a girl, “It’s up a stump, I reckon. I’m a goner.” Tom he looks at me, and I look at him; and he blushes, too. “What shirt, Aunt Sally?”

“Why, Silas’s new calico one—the one you brought him.”

“What do you reckon’s become of it, Aunt Sally?”

“Reckon? I reckon it’s been stole! That’s what I reckon.”

“Stole by a nigger?”

“Course it was stole by a nigger. Who else would want it? And what do they want with it? I wish the crows’d get it and tear it up and pack it off to the woods and git rid of it. They’ve stole Silas’s white shirt, too.”

“What white shirt, Aunt Sally?”

“Why, the one he had on yesterday—the one you brought him.”

“He had it on yesterday, did he?”

“Yes, he did. I see him come in with it.”

“Well, I reckon he’s got it on now, ain’t he?”

“No, he ain’t. I see him take it off and hang it up on the clothes-line where the washin’ was. And it ain’t there now. And he ain’t got it on, neither. And I can’t find it nowhere. And I’ve looked everywhere. And I’m a-goin’ to have it, too. I ain’t a-goin’ to have niggers stealin’ my clothes. I ain’t a-goin’ to have it.”

She was a-goin’ on that way when Uncle Silas come in, and he was a-lookin’ pretty meek, and he says:

“Good mornin’, Sally.”

“Good mornin’, Silas. What do you reckon’s become of your shirt?”

He looked surprised, and says:

“What shirt, Sally?”

“Why, the one you had on yesterday.”

“Well, I reckon I got it on now, ain’t I?”

“No, you ain’t. I see you take it off and hang it up on the clothes-line where the washin’ was. And it ain’t there now. And you ain’t got it on, neither. And I can’t find it nowhere. And I’ve looked everywhere. And I’m a-goin’ to have it, too. I ain’t a-goin’ to have niggers stealin’ my clothes. I ain’t a-goin’ to have it.”

He looked pretty meek, and says:

“Well, I reckon I did take it off and hang it up on the clothes-line where the washin’ was. But I don’t reckon it’s been stole. I reckon it’s just mislaid.”

“Mislaid? Mislaid by who? Mislaid by a nigger, that’s who. And what do they want with it? I wish the crows’d get it and tear it up and pack it off to the woods and git rid of it. They’ve stole Silas’s white shirt, too.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn’t hardly wait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with one hand and cracking the handiest child’s head with her thimble with the other, and says: “I hope to goodness gracious that blessing’s done – I don’t know what you keep a-mumbling about, Colonel, I’m sure. I wish you would say grace and be done with it; I’m a-frying to death; and the children’s a-getting’ cold.”

Well, the Colonel he just set there, looking as grand and solemn as a funeral, and didn’t let on he heard her at all, but kept right on a-mumbling. And the children they kept a-squirming and a-whispering and a-kicking each other under the table, and the mother she kept a-thimbling them and a-sloshing coffee, and the whole business was the most awful racket you ever struck. It was a big table, and everybody was there – the old man and the old woman, and Buck, and the two young women, Miss Charlotte and Miss Sophia, and the four young men, and me. And there was a nigger woman standing behind each of the young women, fanning them with a fan made of turkey-feathers, and another nigger woman standing behind the old woman and the old man, doing the same. And there was a nigger man standing behind each of the young men, and they had a big fan made of peacock-feathers, and they didn’t do nothing but fan them. And there was a nigger boy standing behind me, and he didn’t have no fan, but he was there to wait on me, I reckon. And there was a nigger man standing at each end of the table, carving the meat.

It was a mighty nice dinner, though. Plenty of everything – fried chicken, and roast pig, and ham, and greens, and corn-pone, and hot biscuits, and sweet potatoes, and pie, and cake, and I don’t know what all. And everybody eat like they hadn’t had nothing for a week. And the Colonel he set there and eat, and didn’t say a word, except now and then he’d look up and say, “Buck, fetch me some more of that chicken,” or “Charlotte, pass me them biscuits.” And the young men they eat and talked about horses and dogs and guns, and the young women they eat and talked about clothes and parties and young men, and the children they eat and fit amongst themselves, and the mother she eat and thimbled and sloshed, and the niggers they stood and fanned and waited.

After a while, the Colonel he laid down his knife and fork and wiped his mouth, and then everybody laid down their knives and forks and wiped their mouths. And then the Colonel he says, “Well, Buck, what’s the news?”

And Buck he says, “Well, pap, I reckon there ain’t much news, except old man Shepherdson’s got a new horse – a sorrel, a beauty.”

And the Colonel he says, “A sorrel, eh? Well, I reckon he won’t keep him long.” And he give a little chuckle, and everybody else give a little chuckle, except me. I didn’t see nothing to chuckle about. It seemed to me like a mighty serious business, them Shepherdsons and

events.title: Planted Items Surface and Tom's New Scheme
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally was extremely agitated, and Huck contemplated escaping to the woods until her temper subsided.
Amidst the chaos, Uncle Silas, looking rather foolish, retrieved the pewter spoon (planted by Tom) from his own pocket.
Aunt Sally reacted as if her suspicions were confirmed, accusing him of having the spoon all along and possibly the other missing items too.
Uncle Silas, apologetically, claimed he didn't know how the spoon got there, speculating he might have put it in his pocket mistakenly while studying his Testament.
Exasperated, Aunt Sally dismissed his convoluted explanation and ordered everyone to leave her until she regained her composure.
As Huck and Tom were leaving through the sitting-room, the shingle-nail they had hidden in Uncle Silas's hat fell out onto the floor.
Uncle Silas picked it up, placed it on the mantel-shelf without comment, and left.
Tom observed this and remarked that Uncle Silas was unreliable for their purposes of sending items to Jim.
However, Tom noted that Uncle Silas had unintentionally helped them with the spoon situation.
Tom then proposed they should do Uncle Silas a favor in return without his knowledge: stop up the rat-holes he frequently mentioned but neglected.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, she was just a-biling.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he says: “But he done us a good turn with the spoon, anyway, without knowing it, and so we’ll go and do him one without him knowing it—stop up his rat-holes.”

events.text_segment:
Well, she was just a-biling. I begun to lay for a chance; I reckoned I would sneak out and go for the woods till the weather moderated. She kept a-raging right along, running her insurrection all by herself, and everybody else mighty meek and quiet; and at last Uncle Silas, looking kind of foolish, fishes up that spoon out of his pocket. She stopped, with her mouth open and her hands up; and as for me, I wished I was in Jeruslem or somewheres. But not long, because she says:
“It’s just as I expected. So you had it in your pocket all the time; and like as not you’ve got the other things there, too. How’d it get there?”
“I reely don’t know, Sally,” he says, kind of apologizing, “or you know I would tell. I was a-studying over my text in Acts Seventeen before breakfast, and I reckon I put it in there, not noticing, meaning to put my Testament in, and it must be so, because my Testament ain’t in; but I’ll go and see; and if the Testament is where I had it, I’ll know I didn’t put it in, and that will show that I laid the Testament down and took up the spoon, and—”
“Oh, for the land’s sake! Give a body a rest! Go ’long now, the whole kit and biling of ye; and don’t come nigh me again till I’ve got back my peace of mind.”
I’d a heard her if she’d a said it to herself, let alone speaking it out; and I’d a got up and obeyed her if I’d a been dead. As we was passing through the setting-room the old man he took up his hat, and the shingle-nail fell out on the floor, and he just merely picked it up and laid it on the mantel-shelf, and never said nothing, and went out. Tom see him do it, and remembered about the spoon, and says:
“Well, it ain’t no use to send things by him no more, he ain’t reliable.” Then he says: “But he done us a good turn with the spoon, anyway, without knowing it, and so we’ll go and do him one without him knowing it—stop up his rat-holes.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Well, she was just a-biling. I begun to lay plans to get away, and go and hide in the woods. I was before the mast with a sick man, one time, and he says, no matter how much you feel it, don’t cry; if you do, it will set you back one hundred years in a minute, so you can’t ever get well any more. So I wouldn’t cry. I got a good place to cry in, too—the woods, safe and out of the way of everybody, and I could furnish them myself, if I wanted to, but I didn’t want to. I couldn’t see no sense in it. Aunt Sally she was a-walking up and down, and her face was burning, and she give me a look now and then that was as hot as blazes, and I begun to feel uncomfortable. She begun to rip, and tear, and snort, and rave, and she says:

“Don’t talk to me! I don’t want to hear another single word out of none of you. And Huck Finn, if you open your mouth I’ll skin you. I will, I tell you! And as for you, Tom Sawyer, you played me a trick, and you’ve acted the part of a ornery, ungrateful, low-down hound you have. You lay there, and said your prayers, and it was all a lie. I’ve seen such sons of guns before. But it’s no matter—you wait till I get holt of you. I’ll show you what it is to come here and act like that. I will. I’ll open you up and spread you out on a fence, and dry you in the sun like a sheep-skin. As for you, Mr. Silas, you’d better say your prayers, too, and get ready, because I’m a-going to skin you alive. I never see such a gang of ornery, low-down characters in my life. I never did. They ain’t no more sense in them than there is in a chicken that’s got the pip. And as for you, Jim”—

She stopped, and looked around for Jim; but Jim wasn’t there. He was in the cabin, you know. She sees me, and she says:

“Oh, I see you. You’re in it, too. You’re the one that’s been helping them. You’re the one that’s been bringing them things. You’re the one that’s been helping them to get away. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my niggers. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my spoons. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my shirts. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my sheets. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my pillow-cases. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my blankets. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my quilts. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my everything. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my life. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my soul. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my salvation. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my heaven. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my God. You’re the one that’s been helping them to steal my all.”

She stopped, and she was a-breathing hard. She looked at me, and she looked at Tom, and she looked at Uncle Silas, and she looked at Aunt Sally, and she looked at everybody, and she says:

“Now, you just wait. I’ll show you. I’ll show you all. I’ll show you what it is to come here and act like this. I will. Well, she was just a-biling. I begun to lay plans to get away, and go and hide in the woods. I was before the mast with a sick man, one time, and he says, no matter how much you feel it, don’t cry; if you do, it will set you back one hundred years in a minute, so you can’t ever get well any more. So I wouldn’t cry. I got a good place to cry in, too—the woods, safe and out of the way of everybody, and I could furnish them myself, if I wanted to, but I didn’t want to. I couldn’t see no sense in it. Aunt Sally she was a-walking up and down, and her face was burning, and she give me a look now and then that was as hot as blazes, and I begun to feel uncomfortable. She begun to rip, and tear, and snort, and rave, and she says:

“Don’t talk to me! I don’t want to hear another single word out of none of you. And Huck Finn, if you open your mouth I’ll skin you. I will, I tell you! And as for you, Tom Sawyer, you played me a trick, and you’ve acted the part of a ornery, ungrateful, low-down hound you have. You lay there, and said your prayers, and it was all a lie. I’ve seen such sons of guns before. But it’s no matter—you wait till I get holt of you. I’ll show you what it is to come here and act like that. I will. events.title: Sealing Rat-Holes and Uncle Silas's Bewilderment
detailed_summary: Tom and Huck found numerous rat-holes in the cellar and spent a full hour meticulously sealing them all.
Upon hearing footsteps, they extinguished their light and hid.
Uncle Silas entered the cellar carrying a candle and a bundle, appearing very absent-minded.
He wandered around, examining each of the now-sealed rat-holes one by one.
After inspecting all the holes, he stood for about five minutes, pensively picking tallow drips from his candle.
He then slowly and dreamily turned towards the stairs, muttering that he couldn't remember when he had sealed the holes.
He mused that he could now show Aunt Sally he wasn't to blame for the rats, but decided against it, thinking it wouldn't do any good.
He continued mumbling to himself as he went upstairs, and the boys then departed.
Huck reflected that Uncle Silas was, and always is, a very kind old man.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a noble good lot of them down cellar, and it took us a whole hour, but we done the job tight and good and shipshape.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And so he went on a-mumbling up stairs, and then we left. He was a mighty nice old man. And always is.

events.text_segment:
There was a noble good lot of them down cellar, and it took us a whole hour, but we done the job tight and good and shipshape. Then we heard steps on the stairs, and blowed out our light and hid; and here comes the old man, with a candle in one hand and a bundle of stuff in t’other, looking as absent-minded as year before last. He went a mooning around, first to one rat-hole and then another, till he’d been to them all. Then he stood about five minutes, picking tallow-drip off of his candle and thinking. Then he turns off slow and dreamy towards the stairs, saying:
“Well, for the life of me I can’t remember when I done it. I could show her now that I warn’t to blame on account of the rats. But never mind—let it go. I reckon it wouldn’t do no good.”
And so he went on a-mumbling up stairs, and then we left. He was a mighty nice old man. And always is.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There was a noble good lot of them down cellar, and it took us a whole hour, but we done the job tight and good and shipshape. Then we heard steps on the stairs, and blowed out our light and hid. And here comes old Uncle Silas, thirty foot of rope in his hand, and a candle. He had a bundle under his arm and his hat slouched down over his eyes. He came in, and stood around looking absent-minded and fumbling with the end of the rope. Pretty soon he got it all ravelled out, and then he hitched one end of it to a beam, and stood there a-thinking, and scratching his head. He looked like he was trying to remember something, but couldn't. At last he sighed, and begun to look around; and pretty soon his eyes fell on the rat-holes. He went and looked at them, and then he stood there a good while thinking. By-and-by he sighed again, and fumbled in his bundle, and got out a pipe and a plug of tobacco, and laid them down on a barrel, and set down by the rope and begun to pick his teeth with a pin. He sat there a-mumbling and a-mussing around till I thought he was asleep; then he got up and looked at the rat-holes again, and picked up his candle and started to go. Then he stopped, and looked down at the pipe and the tobacco; then he sighed again, and picked them up and laid them on the shelf and then started again. Then he stopped again, and looked back at the rope which he had hitched to the beam, and then laid down his candle and fumbled with it. By-and-by he got it unhitched, and then he coiled it up and laid it down with his bundle, and sighed again and picked up his candle and started again. He didn't act like he knew what he was about, but just acted like he was moony and absent-minded. As he was going out he stopped again and looked at the rat-holes, and then picked up his candle and went on out. We waited till we didn't hear him any more, and then we come out. events.title: The Spoon-Counting Deception
detailed_summary: Tom, determined to get a spoon for their plans, devised a strategy.
He and Huck waited near the spoon-basket until Aunt Sally approached.
Tom began counting the spoons aloud while Huck surreptitiously slipped one up his sleeve.
Tom then declared to Aunt Sally that there were only nine spoons.
Initially telling them to go play, Aunt Sally eventually recounted the spoons herself and confirmed there were only nine.
Huck then secretly returned the stolen spoon to the basket.
When Aunt Sally counted again, she found ten spoons, leaving her huffy and bothered.
Tom feigned skepticism, prompting her to count yet again.
Huck pilfered another spoon, and the count came out as nine once more.
Aunt Sally became extremely agitated and furious, trembling with anger.
She counted repeatedly, becoming so confused that she sometimes tried to count spoons still in the basket; the count alternated between correct and incorrect totals.
Finally, in a fit of rage, she grabbed the spoon-basket, hurled it across the room, and ordered the boys to leave her in peace, threatening to skin them if they bothered her again before dinner.
The boys successfully obtained the extra spoon and later placed it in Aunt Sally's apron pocket, from which Jim retrieved it, along with the shingle-nail, before noon.
Tom was highly satisfied, believing Aunt Sally would be so traumatized by the experience that she'd never trust her own ability to count spoons again and would eventually give up trying.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom was a good deal bothered about what to do for a spoon, but he said we’d got to have it; so he took a think.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So we had the odd spoon, and dropped it in her apron-pocket whilst she was a-giving us our sailing orders, and Jim got it all right, along with her shingle nail, before noon. We was very well satisfied with this business, and Tom allowed it was worth twice the trouble it took, because he said now she couldn’t ever count them spoons twice alike again to save her life; and wouldn’t believe she’d counted them right if she did; and said that after she’d about counted her head off for the next three days he judged she’d give it up and offer to kill anybody that wanted her to ever count them any more.

events.text_segment:
Tom was a good deal bothered about what to do for a spoon, but he said we’d got to have it; so he took a think. When he had ciphered it out he told me how we was to do; then we went and waited around the spoon-basket till we see Aunt Sally coming, and then Tom went to counting the spoons and laying them out to one side, and I slid one of them up my sleeve, and Tom says:
“Why, Aunt Sally, there ain’t but nine spoons yet.”
She says:
“Go ’long to your play, and don’t bother me. I know better, I counted ’m myself.”
“Well, I’ve counted them twice, Aunty, and I can’t make but nine.”
She looked out of all patience, but of course she come to count—anybody would.
“I declare to gracious ther’ ain’t but nine!” she says. “Why, what in the world—plague take the things, I’ll count ’m again.”
So I slipped back the one I had, and when she got done counting, she says:
“Hang the troublesome rubbage, ther’s ten now!” and she looked huffy and bothered both. But Tom says:
“Why, Aunty, I don’t think there’s ten.”
“You numskull, didn’t you see me count ’m?”
“I know, but—”
“Well, I’ll count ’m again.”
So I smouched one, and they come out nine, same as the other time. Well, she was in a tearing way—just a-trembling all over, she was so mad. But she counted and counted till she got that addled she’d start to count in the basket for a spoon sometimes; and so, three times they come out right, and three times they come out wrong. Then she grabbed up the basket and slammed it across the house and knocked the cat galley-west; and she said cle’r out and let her have some peace, and if we come bothering around her again betwixt that and dinner she’d skin us. So we had the odd spoon, and dropped it in her apron-pocket whilst she was a-giving us our sailing orders, and Jim got it all right, along with her shingle nail, before noon. We was very well satisfied with this business, and Tom allowed it was worth twice the trouble it took, because he said now she couldn’t ever count them spoons twice alike again to save her life; and wouldn’t believe she’d counted them right if she did; and said that after she’d about counted her head off for the next three days he judged she’d give it up and offer to kill anybody that wanted her to ever count them any more.

events.title: The Sheet-Counting Deception and Resolution of Missing Items
detailed_summary: The boys employed a similar deceptive tactic with the sheets.
They returned the original missing sheet to the clothesline that night but then stole a different one from Aunt Sally's closet.
They repeated this process of returning one sheet and stealing another for a couple of days.
This manipulation led Aunt Sally to become completely confused about the actual number of sheets she possessed.
Eventually, she grew indifferent to the count and resolved to stop worrying about it, refusing to count them again under any circumstances.

Huck concluded that they had successfully resolved the mysteries of the missing shirt (attributed to the calf), the sheet and spoon (through confusing Aunt Sally's counts), and the candles (blamed on rats).
The missing candlestick was deemed inconsequential and expected to be forgotten over time.
The narrative then shifts, with Huck noting that their next significant challenge was the difficult task of baking the pie for Jim.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So we put the sheet back on the line that night, and stole one out of her closet; and kept on putting it back and stealing it again for a couple of days till she didn’t know how many sheets she had any more, and she didn’t care, and warn’t a-going to bullyrag the rest of her soul out about it, and wouldn’t count them again not to save her life; she druther die first.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But that pie was a job; we had no end of trouble with that pie.

events.text_segment:
So we put the sheet back on the line that night, and stole one out of her closet; and kept on putting it back and stealing it again for a couple of days till she didn’t know how many sheets she had any more, and she didn’t care, and warn’t a-going to bullyrag the rest of her soul out about it, and wouldn’t count them again not to save her life; she druther die first.
So we was all right now, as to the shirt and the sheet and the spoon and the candles, by the help of the calf and the rats and the mixed-up counting; and as to the candlestick, it warn’t no consequence, it would blow over by-and-by.
But that pie was a job; we had no end of trouble with that pie.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: So we put the sheet back on the line that night, and stole one out of her closet; and kept on putting it back and stealing it again for a couple of days till she didn’t know how many sheets she had any more, and she didn’t care, and warn’t a-going to bullyrag the rest of her soul out about it, and wouldn’t count them again not to save her life; she druther die first. So that was all right, and we got the sheets no problem at all. My conscience felt better, but I felt meaner than ever myself, for doing it. We had all the mysteries settled now. We hadn’t done anything to the shirt, and so we couldn’t account for it; but that didn’t matter, she hadn’t missed it. Nobody couldn’t account for the candlestick; but that didn’t matter, she hadn’t missed it. But she missed the spoons, and she missed the sheets; and we accounted for them by the rats. She knew the rats was there, and she see their signs, which was satisfactory. And so that matter was all comfortable. We was feeling pretty comfortable all altogether, now, and there warn’t nothing to worry about any more, except Jim, and that warn’t no great trouble. We was feeling so comfortable we begun to run out of trouble. What we wanted was for the pie to come along; but we had plenty of time on our hands, and so we struck the next thing on the list, which was the moat—to dig it.

events.title: The Complicated Process of Making the Rope Ladder Pie
detailed_summary: The boys undertook the baking of the special pie in a secluded location in the woods.
This proved to be a challenging and lengthy endeavor, not completed within a single day.
They used a substantial amount of flour, equivalent to three washpans full.
During the process, they sustained minor burns and suffered from smoke irritating their eyes.
The primary difficulty was creating a hollow pie crust that would maintain its shape without collapsing, as they only needed the outer shell.
They eventually conceived the idea of baking the rope ladder inside the pie to provide internal support for the crust.
Collaborating with Jim on the second night, they meticulously fashioned a rope ladder by shredding a sheet into thin strips and twisting them together, finishing the task before daylight.
They planned to tell Jim that the ladder's intricate construction had taken nine months to complete.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We fixed it up away down in the woods, and cooked it there; and we got it done at last, and very satisfactory, too; but not all in one day; and we had to use up three wash-pans full of flour before we got through, and we got burnt pretty much all over, in places, and eyes put out with the smoke; because, you see, we didn’t want nothing but a crust, and we couldn’t prop it up right, and she would always cave in.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We let on it took nine months to make it.

events.text_segment: We fixed it up away down in the woods, and cooked it there; and we got it done at last, and very satisfactory, too; but not all in one day; and we had to use up three wash-pans full of flour before we got through, and we got burnt pretty much all over, in places, and eyes put out with the smoke; because, you see, we didn’t want nothing but a crust, and we couldn’t prop it up right, and she would always cave in. But of course we thought of the right way at last—which was to cook the ladder, too, in the pie. So then we laid in with Jim the second night, and tore up the sheet all in little strings and twisted them together, and long before daylight we had a lovely rope that you could a hung a person with. We let on it took nine months to make it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We fixed it up away down in the woods, and cooked it there; and we got it done at last, and very satisfactory, too; but not all in one day; and we had to use up three wash-pans full of flour before we got through, and we got burnt pretty much all over, in places, and eyes put out with the smoke; because, you see, we didn’t want nothing but a crust, and we couldn’t prop it up right, and she would always cave in. But of course we thought of the right way at last; which was to bake the ladder in it. So we baked the ladder in it, and after that it come out all right. But we had to work pretty near all night, and sweat considerable; and when a body’s burnt here and there, and all over in spots, it makes it dreadful itchy to sweat—besides, the smoke was so powerful it made us blind amongst other things, and we couldn’t hardly stand it. Well, when we got done, we told Jim we hadn’t got the pie finished yet, and we warn’t going to try to finish it, either, but give him to understand that we hadn’t had no chance, and couldn’t the way we was fixed. But if he would give us a hand, we would manage it—and so he done it; and we finished it up grand, and Joe was happy and satisfied. But it warn’t Joe that was happy and satisfied, it was Jim. This kind of work was right down his alley, he was so enthused over it. He said he hadn’t ever hearn of such a thing as that before. He said he wished the boys had been there, and he could a showed them one or two things; he said that that rope ladder was a perfect curiosity; said it was the beatenest thing he ever laid his eyes on; said them twists and knots was a work of art; said it would take a man a long time to learn to make such like; and said that if ever he got out, this was the thing he would take to for a living. We told him we had—been—a-working at it—off and on—for nine months, and the like of that; and so he said it warn’t no wonder it was so perfect. We had him out that night, and Jim and us felt pretty gay that it was done and ready for hiding. It was a tolerable long ladder, but not thicker than a man’s wrist when it was twisted; you could hide it in a chair-cushion. We had to cut the ladder in two pieces, though, before we could get it in the pie; and we had to bend it and cram it, too. So it warn’t no time till it was baked hard, and we done it all right. And as for the pie, it warn’t no great things, because my hands was all only just big clots of dough and flour, and I couldn’t see the way it was working, and the oven warn’t right, and everything was wrong. But when the ladder was all baked solid, too, I removed the pie, and Jim and I hid the ladder in the straw under the bed. We got it there all safe, and then we was done for the night.

You see, we was setting a witch free; and you got to set a witch free by digging him out.

events.title: Baking the Pie in the Ancestral Warming-Pan
detailed_summary: When they brought the finished rope ladder to their woodland baking site, they found it was far too large for a single pie, as it had been made from an entire bedsheet.
Realizing they only needed enough rope for one pie, they discarded the excess.
They decided against using their tin washpan for baking, fearing its solder might melt under the heat.

Instead, they secretly retrieved Uncle Silas's valuable brass warming-pan, an heirloom with a long wooden handle that had supposedly come from England with an early colonist, from its storage place in the garret.
Their initial attempts to bake the pie using the warming-pan were unsuccessful due to their inexperience with it.
However, they persisted and finally achieved success on their last attempt.
They lined the warming-pan with dough, placed the rag rope ladder inside, covered it with a dough roof, sealed the lid, and then applied hot embers to the top and bottom for even baking.
After approximately fifteen minutes, the warming-pan produced a pie that was visually perfect and satisfying to behold.
Huck humorously commented that anyone attempting to eat the pie would find the rope ladder filling highly indigestible and would likely suffer significant stomach discomfort.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And in the forenoon we took it down to the woods, but it wouldn’t go into the pie.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But the person that et it would want to fetch a couple of kags of toothpicks along, for if that rope ladder wouldn’t cramp him down to business I don’t know nothing what I’m talking about, and lay him in enough stomach-ache to last him till next time, too.

events.text_segment:
And in the forenoon we took it down to the woods, but it wouldn’t go into the pie. Being made of a whole sheet, that way, there was rope enough for forty pies if we’d a wanted them, and plenty left over for soup, or sausage, or anything you choose. We could a had a whole dinner.
But we didn’t need it. All we needed was just enough for the pie, and so we throwed the rest away. We didn’t cook none of the pies in the wash-pan—afraid the solder would melt; but Uncle Silas he had a noble brass warming-pan which he thought considerable of, because it belonged to one of his ancesters with a long wooden handle that come over from England with William the Conqueror in the Mayflower or one of them early ships and was hid away up garret with a lot of other old pots and things that was valuable, not on account of being any account, because they warn’t, but on account of them being relicts, you know, and we snaked her out, private, and took her down there, but she failed on the first pies, because we didn’t know how, but she come up smiling on the last one. We took and lined her with dough, and set her in the coals, and loaded her up with rag rope, and put on a dough roof, and shut down the lid, and put hot embers on top, and stood off five foot, with the long handle, cool and comfortable, and in fifteen minutes she turned out a pie that was a satisfaction to look at. But the person that et it would want to fetch a couple of kags of toothpicks along, for if that rope ladder wouldn’t cramp him down to business I don’t know nothing what I’m talking about, and lay him in enough stomach-ache to last him till next time, too.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: And in the forenoon we took it down to the woods, but it wouldn’t go into the pie. The minute we begun to stick it in it was too big, and we cut it down, private, till it would go. But Lord, it was a short rope ladder, now, I can tell you. It warn’t long enough for a yard let alone reaching from the window down to the ground. They was six foot of it—no, there warn’t that much, either—about four foot, I reckon—and they took the rest of it and hid it in a brier patch to keep it from telling on them. They was going to make a pie big enough for him to get whole object in, and bake it, and send it to him at his dungeon. But they didn’t know how to make pie, and so they had to give it up. They had been fixing to bake it right there in the woods, but they hadn’t any way to do it. They wanted to use a tin washpan for an oven, but they were afraid the solder would melt. So they stood there a-gaping at the ladder and the pie-dough, like a couple of fools, till that idea come into my head. “Why not use Uncle Silas’s old brass warming-pan?” says I. “It ain’t been used for forty or fifty year, and it’s down cellar, handy.” “That’s it!” says Tom. “He wouldn’t ever think of that. And the handle’s long enough for a yard, too. I’ll go and get it.” He fetched it, and sure enough, it was a grand big warming-pan, and old, and black with age, and had a long wooden handle. It was an heirloom, they said; it come from England with the first emigrant, and was very valuable. They didn’t know how to use it, though. They tried to bake the pie in it, but it wouldn’t bake right. They tried it every way, but it wouldn’t work. At last, they give it up, and was a-going to throw the whole thing away, ladder and all, when I thought of another idea. “Why not,” says I, “put the ladder in the pie, and then bake the pie in the warming-pan?” “That’s it!” says Tom. “We’ll do it that way.” So they lined the warming-pan with dough, and put the ladder in, and covered it over with dough, and sealed it up, and then put hot embers on top and bottom, and baked it. It took about fifteen minutes, and it come out a beautiful pie. It looked like a regular pie, and it smelt like a regular pie, and it was a regular pie, only it had a rope ladder in it. Anybody that would eat that pie would have a good deal of rope ladder in him, I can tell you.

events.title: Delivery of the Pie and Jim's Resourceful Actions
detailed_summary: The boys discreetly placed the specially prepared "witch pie," containing the rope ladder, into Jim's food pan, ensuring Nat, Jim's attendant, did not observe them.
They also hid three tin plates at the bottom of the pan, underneath Jim's meal.
Jim successfully received all the items intended for him.
Once he was alone, Jim broke open the pie to access its contents.
He carefully extracted the rope ladder and concealed it within the straw of his mattress.
He then used one of the tin plates to scratch some kind of message or marks on it, before throwing the inscribed plate out through the small window opening of his cabin.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Nat didn’t look when we put the witch pie in Jim’s pan; and we put the three tin plates in the bottom of the pan under the vittles; and so Jim got everything all right, and as soon as he was by himself he busted into the pie and hid the rope ladder inside of his straw tick, and scratched some marks on a tin plate and throwed it out of the window-hole.

events.title: Designing the Prisoner's Legacy: Inscriptions and a Coat of Arms
detailed_summary: The creation of makeshift pens and a saw is proving to be a challenging endeavor, and Jim expresses his belief that carving an inscription will be the most difficult task of all.
Tom Sawyer insists that, like all notable state prisoners from history such as Lady Jane Grey, Jim must leave behind a carved inscription and a coat of arms.
Jim is bewildered, pointing out that he possesses only his old shirt, which he is already supposed to use for keeping a journal.
Tom clarifies that a coat of arms is a distinct heraldic emblem, not an item of clothing, a point Huck Finn tries to support by affirming Jim doesn't own one.
Tom remains adamant, declaring that Jim will have a proper coat of arms before his escape to ensure every detail is authentic and there are no 'flaws in his record.'
While Huck and Jim laboriously fashion pens—Jim from brass, Huck from a spoon—Tom dedicates himself to conceptualizing Jim's coat of arms.

Tom unveils a highly elaborate and complex design for the coat of arms, replete with obscure heraldic terms and symbols, including a motto, 'Maggiore fretta, minore atto,' which he translates as 'the more haste, the less speed.'
Huck, confused by the jargon, asks for clarification on terms like 'fess' and 'bar sinister,' but Tom deflects his questions, claiming lack of time or necessity for Huck to understand.
With the coat of arms designed, Tom shifts his focus to composing suitably mournful inscriptions for Jim to carve, as was customary for prisoners.

He drafts several dramatic inscriptions, such as 'Here a captive heart busted,' and 'Here, homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble stranger, natural son of Louis XIV.'
Tom is visibly moved while reading his compositions and, unable to choose the best one, decides Jim should carve all of them.
Jim protests the immense labor this would involve, particularly given his inability to make letters, but Tom offers to sketch the outlines for him.
Tom then revises his plan, realizing that log walls are inappropriate for a dungeon setting and that the inscriptions must be carved into a rock.
Jim laments that carving into rock would be an even more arduous and lengthy task, but Tom volunteers Huck to assist Jim.

Noticing the slow and painful progress Huck and Jim are making on the pens, Tom devises a new plan: they will steal a large grindstone from the local mill. This grindstone will serve for carving the coat of arms and inscriptions, as well as for sharpening their tools.

events.text_segment:
Making them pens was a distressid tough job, and so was the saw; and Jim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all. That’s the one which the prisoner has to scrabble on the wall. But he had to have it; Tom said he’d got to; there warn’t no case of a state prisoner not scrabbling his inscription to leave behind, and his coat of arms.
“Look at Lady Jane Grey,” he says; “look at Gilford Dudley; look at old Northumberland! Why, Huck, s’pose it is considerble trouble?—what you going to do?—how you going to get around it? Jim’s got to do his inscription and coat of arms. They all do.”
Jim says:
“Why, Mars Tom, I hain’t got no coat o’ arm; I hain’t got nuffn but dish yer ole shirt, en you knows I got to keep de journal on dat.”
“Oh, you don’t understand, Jim; a coat of arms is very different.”
“Well,” I says, “Jim’s right, anyway, when he says he ain’t got no coat of arms, because he hain’t.”
“I reckon I knowed that,” Tom says, “but you bet he’ll have one before he goes out of this—because he’s going out right, and there ain’t going to be no flaws in his record.”
So whilst me and Jim filed away at the pens on a brickbat apiece, Jim a-making his’n out of the brass and I making mine out of the spoon, Tom set to work to think out the coat of arms. By-and-by he said he’d struck so many good ones he didn’t hardly know which to take, but there was one which he reckoned he’d decide on. He says:
“On the scutcheon we’ll have a bend or in the dexter base, a saltire murrey in the fess, with a dog, couchant, for common charge, and under his foot a chain embattled, for slavery, with a chevron vert in a chief engrailed, and three invected lines on a field azure, with the nombril points rampant on a dancette indented; crest, a runaway nigger, sable, with his bundle over his shoulder on a bar sinister; and a couple of gules for supporters, which is you and me; motto, Maggiore fretta, minore atto. Got it out of a book—means the more haste, the less speed.”
“Geewhillikins,” I says, “but what does the rest of it mean?”
“We ain’t got no time to bother over that,” he says; “we got to dig in like all git-out.”
“Well, anyway,” I says, “what’s some of it? What’s a fess?”
“A fess—a fess is—you don’t need to know what a fess is. I’ll show him how to make it when he gets to it.”
“Shucks, Tom,” I says, “I think you might tell a person. What’s a bar sinister?”
“Oh, I don’t know. But he’s got to have it. All the nobility does.”
That was just his way. If it didn’t suit him to explain a thing to you, he wouldn’t do it. You might pump at him a week, it wouldn’t make no difference.
He’d got all that coat of arms business fixed, so now he started in to finish up the rest of that part of the work, which was to plan out a mournful inscription—said Jim got to have one, like they all done. He made up a lot, and wrote them out on a paper, and read them off, so:
1. Here a captive heart busted.
2. Here a poor prisoner, forsook by the world and friends, fretted out his sorrowful life.
3. Here a lonely heart broke, and a worn spirit went to its rest, after thirty-seven years of solitary captivity.
4. Here, homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble stranger, natural son of Louis XIV.
Tom’s voice trembled whilst he was reading them, and he most broke down. When he got done he couldn’t no way make up his mind which one for Jim to scrabble on to the wall, they was all so good; but at last he allowed he would let him scrabble them all on. Jim said it would take him a year to scrabble such a lot of truck on to the logs with a nail, and he didn’t know how to make letters, besides; but Tom said he would block them out for him, and then he wouldn’t have nothing to do but just follow the lines. Then pretty soon he says:
“Come to think, the logs ain’t a-going to do; they don’t have log walls in a dungeon: we got to dig the inscriptions into a rock. We’ll fetch a rock.”
Jim said the rock was worse than the logs; he said it would take him such a pison long time to dig them into a rock he wouldn’t ever get out. But Tom said he would let me help him do it. Then he took a look to see how me and Jim was getting along with the pens. It was most pesky tedious hard work and slow, and didn’t give my hands no show to get well of the sores, and we didn’t seem to make no headway, hardly; so Tom says:
“I know how to fix it. We got to have a rock for the coat of arms and mournful inscriptions, and we can kill two birds with that same rock. There’s a gaudy big grindstone down at the mill, and we’ll smouch it, and carve the things on it, and file out the pens and the saw on it, too.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Making them pens was a distressid tough job, and so was the saw; and Jim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all. That was going to be a job that would make a body sick, he said, and he wished he could get rid of it. It was to be on a stone, and Jim said if he had a chisel he wouldn’t mind it, but he didn’t have any, and so he stood there, looking like he wished he was dead, and Tom he stood there, looking like he was born for it. Tom said he would help him, and so he did. They took a nail and they worked at it, scraping and scratching, and it was the slowest work a body ever see. It took them days and days, and Jim he groaned and sweated over it, and Tom he just kep’ on, cheerful as a cricket, telling about all the famous prisoners that had done the same thing. He said it warn’t no escape unless you done it the regular way, and the regular way was to leave your inscription, and your coat of arms, and all that. Jim didn’t know what a coat of arms was, and he didn’t care, he just wanted to get out. But Tom he wouldn’t give up. He said it was the most important part of the whole business. So they kep’ on scraping and scratching, and by and by they got it done. It said: “Here a captive heart busted.” Jim said he didn’t know what it meant, but Tom said it was the regular thing, and it sounded good. It took them a week to do that inscription, and Jim he was wore out. He said he’d rather be in jail for life than do another one. But Tom he just laughed and said they warn’t done yet, not by a long sight. There was the rope ladder to make, and the shirt to keep a journal on, and the moat to dig, and the rats and snakes and spiders and things to tame for pets. Jim he just looked at him, his eyes big as saucers, and he didn’t say a word. He just looked like he thought Tom was crazy. And I reckon he warn’t far wrong. But Tom he was bound to do it all according to the books. He said it warn’t no fun if you didn’t do it the way the famous prisoners done it. So we went to work on the rope ladder. We had to get sheets from the house, and that was a job. We snuck in at night and took them off the beds, and Aunt Sally she never suspicioned a thing. We cut them up into strips and braided them together, and it made a powerful long ladder. It took us days and days to do that, too. Jim he done most of the work, and he grumbled about it, but he done it. He said he didn’t see no sense in a rope ladder when they could just walk out the door, but Tom he said that warn’t the regular way. The regular way was to have a rope ladder and let it down from the window. So we done it. Then there was the shirt. Tom said Jim had to keep a journal of his sufferings on a shirt, like the famous prisoners done. Jim he said he didn’t have no sufferings to write about, except having to do all this foolishness, but Tom he said that was part of the suffering. So we got a shirt and the pens we made, and Jim he had to write on it. He didn’t know how to write much, so Tom he had to help him. It was slow work, and the ink we made out of soot and grease didn’t work very good. It smeared all over the place. Jim he got ink all over himself, and he looked like a chimney sweep. He said he wished he was back in the cabin on the island, where things was simple. But Tom he just kep’ on, full of ideas. He said they had to have pets, like the famous prisoners. They had to tame rats and snakes and spiders and things. Jim he said he didn’t want no pets like that, he was scared of snakes and spiders. But Tom he said it was the regular way, and it showed you was brave. So we had to catch them. We caught rats in the smokehouse, and snakes down by the river, and spiders in the woodshed. It was a mess. We had them in boxes and jars, and they was always trying to get out. Jim he wouldn’t go near them. He said they give him the creeps. Tom he tried to tame them, but they just bit him and run away. It was a lot of trouble for nothing, if you ask me. Then there was the moat. Tom said they had to dig a moat around the cabin, like a castle. Jim he said he didn’t see no sense in digging a ditch around the place, but Tom he said it was the regular way, and it made the escape more romantic. So we got shovels and we started digging. It was hard work, and the ground was rocky. We dug for days and days, and we didn’t get very far. Jim he was wore out. He said he’d rather break rocks on the road than dig that moat. But Tom he just kep’ on, talking about castles and knights and things. He was having the time of his life, and Jim he was just suffering. I felt sorry for Jim, but I didn’t know how to stop Tom. He was so set on doing everything the regular way, according to the books. He said it warn’t no adventure if you

events.title: The Grindstone Heist and Inscription Work
detailed_summary: Huck acknowledges Tom's idea to use a grindstone is clever, though the grindstone itself is very large and heavy, presenting a significant challenge.
They decide to proceed with the theft, setting out for the mill before midnight while Jim continues his other assigned tasks.
Huck and Tom successfully 'smouch' (steal) the grindstone but find it exceedingly difficult to transport, struggling to roll it and narrowly avoiding being crushed by it multiple times.
Completely exhausted and drenched in sweat after getting it halfway, they admit defeat and realize they require Jim's superior strength.
Jim is summoned; he detaches his leg chain from the bed, wraps it around his neck for concealment, and exits through their escape tunnel.
With Jim's help, moving the massive grindstone becomes almost effortless, while Tom assumes a supervisory role, which Huck notes Tom performs with great aptitude.
The existing escape hole proves too small for the grindstone, prompting Jim to use a pickaxe to quickly enlarge it.
Once the grindstone is inside the hut, Tom uses a nail to sketch out the designs for the inscriptions and coat of arms.
Jim is then set to the task of carving these into the stone, using the nail as a chisel and an iron bolt found in nearby rubbish as a makeshift hammer.
Tom instructs Jim to work until his candle burns out, after which he should hide the grindstone under his straw mattress and sleep on it.
Finally, Huck and Tom assist Jim in re-securing his chain to the bed-leg, and the boys prepare to go to sleep.

events.text_segment:
It warn’t no slouch of an idea; and it warn’t no slouch of a grindstone nuther; but we allowed we’d tackle it. It warn’t quite midnight yet, so we cleared out for the mill, leaving Jim at work. We smouched the grindstone, and set out to roll her home, but it was a most nation tough job. Sometimes, do what we could, we couldn’t keep her from falling over, and she come mighty near mashing us every time. Tom said she was going to get one of us, sure, before we got through. We got her half way; and then we was plumb played out, and most drownded with sweat. We see it warn’t no use; we got to go and fetch Jim. So he raised up his bed and slid the chain off of the bed-leg, and wrapt it round and round his neck, and we crawled out through our hole and down there, and Jim and me laid into that grindstone and walked her along like nothing; and Tom superintended. He could out-superintend any boy I ever see. He knowed how to do everything.
Our hole was pretty big, but it warn’t big enough to get the grindstone through; but Jim he took the pick and soon made it big enough. Then Tom marked out them things on it with the nail, and set Jim to work on them, with the nail for a chisel and an iron bolt from the rubbage in the lean-to for a hammer, and told him to work till the rest of his candle quit on him, and then he could go to bed, and hide the grindstone under his straw tick and sleep on it. Then we helped him fix his chain back on the bed-leg, and was ready for bed ourselves.

It warn’t no slouch of an idea; and it warn’t no slouch of a grindstone nuther; but we allowed we’d tackle it. It warn’t quite midnight yet, so we had time. We slipped down the river a mile, and hid the canoe in the willows. Then we trudged back afoot the rest of the way. When we got below the ferry we struck for the woods, because we judged we might fetch up against somebody notwithstanding the late hour. We got up against the mill, finally, and stooped under the bottom log, and crawled in, and got it, and went right along with it. It was all we could do to manage it. We cooned it along, man fashion, some of it at a time, and at the end of an hour we had got it only a hundred yards, and we warn’t feeling very splendid, it was so heavy. We laid there, panting, a minute, and then Tom says:

“Ours is the swelled head, now, Huck. We’ve got to have help. I know where to get it. — Jim!”

Saying this, he whispered to Jim through the hole, and Jim come a-scrambling along with his chain, and piled out, all in a shiver, and says:

“Why, Mars Tom, I doan’ want no mo’ adventures. Dat last one was mos’ enough for me. She tuck de orneryest tuck dat ever I see.”

“Ah, shucks, Jim, it ain’t no harm. I only want you to help us lift a little.”

“Lift a little? Weel, I don’t know. You tell me what it is fust. Mars Tom, if you got any plans, I don’t want to hear ‘em. And if you got any more of these ventures, I don’t want no part of ‘em.”

“Come, come, hearken to me, Jim. Didn’t you hear a noise?”

“Well, I don’t know. I reckon I did hear a noise, but I didn’t pay no attention. It ain’t no matter.”

“Well, it is, too. You listen. Didn’t you hear a noise?”

“Why, Mars Tom, I doan’ want no mo’ adventures. Dat last one was mos’ enough for me. She tuck de orneryest tuck dat ever I see.”

“Ah, shucks, Jim, it ain’t no harm. I only want you to help us lift a little.”

“Come, come, hearken to me, Jim. Didn’t you hear a noise?”

“Well, I don’t know. I reckon I did hear a noise, but I didn’t pay no attention. It ain’t no matter.”

“Well, it is, too. You listen. Didn’t you hear a noise?”

events.title: Tom's Zoological Theatrics: Spiders, Snakes, and Jim's Protests
detailed_summary: Just as they are about to sleep, Tom conceives another idea for Jim's imprisonment, asking if Jim has any spiders in his dwelling.
Jim replies that he does not, expressing gratitude for their absence as he is afraid of them.
Tom announces their intention to procure some spiders for Jim.
Jim implores them not to, reiterating his fear of spiders.
Tom then escalates his idea, suggesting a rattlesnake would be a 'prime good idea' for a prisoner's pet, speculating it must have been done before.
Jim reacts with sheer terror, declaring he would break out of the hut if a rattlesnake were introduced.
Tom attempts to placate Jim, arguing that he could tame the rattlesnake, as animals supposedly respond to kindness, and even suggests Jim could let it sleep with him and put its head in his mouth.
Jim is profoundly disturbed by this notion and vehemently refuses, finding the idea of such intimacy with a snake repulsive.
Tom insists that a prisoner must have a 'dumb pet' and that taming a rattlesnake would bring Jim unique glory.
Jim counters that he desires no such glory, especially if it involves being bitten and potentially losing his chin.
Tom pressures Jim to at least try taming a rattlesnake, but Jim stands firm, stating he will leave if they bring one into the hut.

Frustrated by Jim's 'bull-headedness,' Tom concedes on the rattlesnake but proposes a compromise: they will get garter snakes, and Jim can tie buttons to their tails to make them resemble rattlesnakes.
Jim reluctantly accepts the garter snakes, though he would prefer to have no snakes at all, and remarks on the unexpected amount of bother and trouble involved in being a prisoner 'done right.'
