events.text_segment:
We was all glad as we could be, but Tom was the gladdest of all because he had a bullet in the calf of his leg.
When me and Jim heard that we didn’t feel so brash as what we did before. It was hurting him considerable, and bleeding; so we laid him in the wigwam and tore up one of the duke’s shirts for to bandage him, but he says:
“Gimme the rags; I can do it myself. Don’t stop now; don’t fool around here, and the evasion booming along so handsome; man the sweeps, and set her loose! Boys, we done it elegant!—’deed we did. I wish we’d a had the handling of Louis XVI., there wouldn’t a been no ‘Son of Saint Louis, ascend to heaven!’ wrote down in his biography; no, sir, we’d a whooped him over the border—that’s what we’d a done with him—and done it just as slick as nothing at all, too. Man the sweeps—man the sweeps!”
But me and Jim was consulting—and thinking. And after we’d thought a minute, I says:
“Say it, Jim.”
So he says:
“Well, den, dis is de way it look to me, Huck. Ef it wuz him dat ’uz bein’ sot free, en one er de boys wuz to git shot, would he say, ‘Go on en save me, nemmine ’bout a doctor f’r to save dis one?’ Is dat like Mars Tom Sawyer? Would he say dat? You bet he wouldn’t! Well, den, is Jim gywne to say it? No, sah—I doan’ budge a step out’n dis place ’dout a doctor; not if it’s forty year!”
I knowed he was white inside, and I reckoned he’d say what he did say—so it was all right now, and I told Tom I was a-going for a doctor.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We was all glad as we could be, but Tom was the gladdest of all because he had a bullet in the calf of his leg. When we found that out, we was powerful sorry, but Tom was just made. He laid there and moaned, and kept on saying he wouldn't take forty million dollars for that plant. It was "elegant," he said. He said it was what he was after; he never did care no more for a thing than he did for a bullet-hole in the calf of your leg. That was the finest I ever heard, he said. He wished it was a cannon-ball, he said, then he wouldn't take forty million dollars for the plant and the hole both. Jim said it hurt him considerable, and so it did. The blood was caked around the hole, and Tom winced when we helped him up. We tore a strip off of the duke's old shirt and bound up the leg with it. Huck and Jim they kept moaning and groaning and saying it was dreadful, but Tom said Lickety-split! second you hear the dogs we'll tear out for the raft and shove off—for we was bound to drift up the river all night and stand off from shore. I says: "But Tom, it's dreadful bad; it looks like gangrene." "Oh, shucks, Huck, what do you know about gangrene?" "I don't know anything at all, Tom, but it looks dreadful bad, whatever it is." "Well, you see," Tom says, "it's a kind of a beautiful accident, and it's a noble way to get hurt. It don't hurt bad; and I can't account for it the way it does hurt—it don't seem natural." He laid back and shut his eyes and moaned. Jim and me we set around and waited, and pretty soon Tom says: "Come, hurry up! Heaps of things to do. We'll leave Jim to his folks. They won't ever bother him any more. Set him free, and we'll give him a splendid time, and he can tell us all about his adventures when he was a slave. We'll have him up to the house, and—" He stopped, and his face was white. "What's the matter?" I says. "Oh, I know!" he says. "We'll have to wait. I can't walk. I can't do anything. I'm shot." Huck and Jim they kept moaning and groaning and saying it was dreadful, but Tom said Lickety-split! second you hear the dogs we'll tear out for the raft and shove off—for we was bound to drift up the river all night and stand off from shore. I says: "But Tom, it's dreadful bad; it looks like gangrene." "Oh, shucks, Huck, what do you know about gangrene?" "I don't know anything at all, Tom, but it looks dreadful bad, whatever it is." "Well, you see," Tom says, "it's a kind of a beautiful accident, and it's a noble way to get hurt. It don't hurt bad; and I can't account for it the way it does hurt—it don't seem natural." He laid back and shut his eyes and moaned. Jim and me we set around and waited, and pretty soon Tom says: "Come, hurry up! Heaps of things to do. We'll leave Jim to his folks. But he was in considerable pain, and his leg bled a good deal. We helped him into the wigwam and tore up one of the duke's old shirts for rags. We bandaged him up the best we could, and he kept moaning and saying it was "beautiful." He said he wouldn't have missed it for a thousand dollars. He said it was a grand adventure, and he wouldn't trade his bullet-hole for a barrel of gold eagles. When we got done, Tom says: "Now, Huck, we'll start right off. We won't lose a minute. events.title: Tom's Theatrical Plan for Fetching the Doctor
detailed_summary: Tom protested vigorously against the idea of fetching a doctor, but Huck and Jim remained steadfast in their decision, refusing to yield.
In his frustration, Tom even threatened to crawl out of the wigwam and set the raft adrift himself, but Huck and Jim prevented him from doing so.
Tom then delivered a tirade, expressing his displeasure, but his angry words had no impact on their resolve.
Seeing that Huck was already preparing the canoe for the journey, Tom reluctantly accepted their decision to seek medical help.
He then proceeded to give Huck a series of elaborate and highly theatrical instructions on how to fetch the doctor, drawing heavily on conventions from adventure stories and dime novels.

These detailed instructions included specific actions such as going to the doctor's house, shutting the door behind him, blindfolding the doctor tightly and securely, and making him swear a solemn oath to remain as silent as the grave about the entire affair.
Huck was also instructed to place a purse full of gold in the doctor's hand.
Following this, Huck was to lead the blindfolded doctor on a convoluted route through back alleys and various dark, out-of-the-way places.
He was then to transport the doctor to the raft by canoe, taking a deliberately roundabout path amongst the islands to further obscure their location.

Upon arrival at the raft, Huck was to search the doctor thoroughly and confiscate any chalk he might be carrying, not returning it until they had safely delivered the doctor back to the village. This precaution was to prevent the doctor from marking the raft's location for later discovery.
Tom concluded his instructions by explaining that this elaborate procedure was "the way they all do" in such clandestine operations described in his beloved books.
Huck agreed to follow Tom's complicated plan and then departed in the canoe.
It was arranged that Jim would conceal himself in the woods near the raft when he saw the doctor approaching and remain hidden until after the doctor had treated Tom and left again.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He raised considerable row about it, but me and Jim stuck to it and wouldn’t budge; so he was for crawling out and setting the raft loose himself; but we wouldn’t let him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I said I would, and left, and Jim was to hide in the woods when he see the doctor coming till he was gone again.

events.text_segment:
He raised considerable row about it, but me and Jim stuck to it and wouldn’t budge; so he was for crawling out and setting the raft loose himself; but we wouldn’t let him. Then he give us a piece of his mind, but it didn’t do no good.
So when he sees me getting the canoe ready, he says:
“Well, then, if you’re bound to go, I’ll tell you the way to do when you get to the village. Shut the door and blindfold the doctor tight and fast, and make him swear to be silent as the grave, and put a purse full of gold in his hand, and then take and lead him all around the back alleys and everywheres in the dark, and then fetch him here in the canoe, in a roundabout way amongst the islands, and search him and take his chalk away from him, and don’t give it back to him till you get him back to the village, or else he will chalk this raft so he can find it again. It’s the way they all do.”
So I said I would, and left, and Jim was to hide in the woods when he see the doctor coming till he was gone again.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
He raised considerable row about it, but me and Jim stuck to it and wouldn’t budge; so he was for crawling out and setting the raft loose himself; but we wouldn’t let him. Then he give us a lecture about it, and called us a couple of prejudiced ignoramuses till he was black in the face; but I set my teeth and wouldn’t say nothing, and neither wouldn’t Jim, and so we won out, and he shut up. Then I says:

“See here, Tom, what are we going to do? We can’t leave Jim to die, and we can’t stay here to die. Let’s send for the doctor. You ain’t got no broken bones—there’s nothing to hurt but your foot, and you want a doctor, I reckon. And he’s got his bills to collect the same as other people. He’ll get his pay, and be all right.”

This idea pleased me so much that I couldn’t help lightin’ out for the canoe a-going on forty mile an hour, and not waiting to hear what Tom had to say. But I did fetch up against his hard head just the same, for I got him out of patience, and he fired up and says:

“Ain’t you a sweet-scented dandy, butting in and spoiling everything again? Why didn’t you wait? I was going to tell you what to do. PADDY! Fetch the doctor!—why, that’s the commonest old thing! I was going to dig him out of here with a spoon!”

“No,” says I, “the spoon ain’t going to work; and besides, you don’t go digging people out with a spoon—you dig them out with a lightning-rod. When a cow’s struck, you dig her out with a lightning-rod; but—”

“SHUT UP!” says Tom. “Huck, you are exasperating beyond description—just your every way. You just wait till I tell you what to do. PADDY! “Come, now, you ain’t going to send me with any such mess as that, are you?”

“You mean they do it in the books? Well, it ain’t natural to do it that way, and I hain’t got no time to sweat and grunt and palaver all over a story that ain’t true. I’ve got to hunt up that doctor and get him here whilst I’m alive, or Jim’ll be dead when I get back.”

“Well, then, go ahead and do it your own way—but it’s the orneryest way that ever was.”

“All right,” he says; “but I ain’t going to lie down. Give me a pipe. Where’s the pipe? Hucky, you fetch it.”

events.title: Huck's Deception and the Doctor's Departure for Tom
detailed_summary: Huck awakens an elderly doctor, presenting himself as the brother of a boy named 'Sid' (actually Tom Sawyer).
He concocts a story about 'Sid' accidentally shooting himself in the leg on Spanish Island during a supposed hunting trip, emphasizing the need for secrecy to surprise their 'folks,' the Phelpses.
The doctor, though expressing some skepticism about the 'dream' that supposedly caused the gunshot, agrees to help and prepares his lantern and saddle-bags.
When the doctor sees Huck's small canoe, he expresses concern about its safety for two people.
Huck attempts to reassure him by claiming it previously carried three people and guns, a slip he quickly tries to cover.
The doctor tests the canoe, remains unconvinced, and decides to look for a larger one, but finds others locked.
He ultimately takes Huck's canoe alone, instructing Huck to either wait, search for another canoe, or go home to prepare for the 'surprise.'
Huck chooses to wait and provides the doctor with directions to the raft where Tom is located.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The doctor was an old man; a very nice, kind-looking old man when I got him up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: so I told him just how to find the raft, and then he started.

events.text_segment:
The doctor was an old man; a very nice, kind-looking old man when I got him up. I told him me and my brother was over on Spanish Island hunting yesterday afternoon, and camped on a piece of a raft we found, and about midnight he must a kicked his gun in his dreams, for it went off and shot him in the leg, and we wanted him to go over there and fix it and not say nothing about it, nor let anybody know, because we wanted to come home this evening and surprise the folks.
“Who is your folks?” he says.
“The Phelpses, down yonder.”
“Oh,” he says. And after a minute, he says:
“How’d you say he got shot?”
“He had a dream,” I says, “and it shot him.”
“Singular dream,” he says.
So he lit up his lantern, and got his saddle-bags, and we started. But when he sees the canoe he didn’t like the look of her—said she was big enough for one, but didn’t look pretty safe for two. I says:
“Oh, you needn’t be afeard, sir, she carried the three of us easy enough.”
“What three?”
“Why, me and Sid, and—and—and the guns; that’s what I mean.”
“Oh,” he says.
But he put his foot on the gunnel and rocked her, and shook his head, and said he reckoned he’d look around for a bigger one. But they was all locked and chained; so he took my canoe, and said for me to wait till he come back, or I could hunt around further, or maybe I better go down home and get them ready for the surprise if I wanted to. But I said I didn’t; so I told him just how to find the raft, and then he started.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: The doctor was an old man; a very nice, kind-looking old man when I got him up. I told him my brother Sid had been shot in the leg by accident, and was bleeding a good deal, and that Sid was jess visiting here, and his folks didn't know about it, and I wished he would come; please come. He mended up his fire and lit his lantern and got his saddle-bags, and said he would come right along. He said the boy was shot in the leg, then? I said, Yes. He said it was an accident, then? I said, Yes. He said what time did it happen? I told him it happened a little before daylight. He said, All right, then. Said he would take his canoe and paddle over there and see to him. I said he couldn't; I had come in a canoe myself. Said he would go right along with me, then. I told him he couldn't, because the canoe would not hold two, and I had come only to get him and then paddle back. He said, Well, you don't mean to tell me that you're going to take me over there in a little bit of a canoe like that? I said, Yes, sir. He said, I don't believe it. Said I couldn't do it. Said he would not risk his life in such a crazy craft. Said I could go and get a better canoe. I told him I couldn't; I hadn't any better. He said, Well, then, I'll go and see if I can't borrow one. So he went off, and I waited. He came back in a little while, and said he couldn't get none. Said all the canoes were locked up. Said he would have to go in mine. Said it was a risk, but he would chance it. Said I must tell him how to find the place. I told him it was away down the river, about two mile and a half, and a little side channel that you turned into, and rowed about a quarter of a mile, and there you would find the raft and the house on it. Said I must wait there till he come back, or else go home and tell the people about it. Said he wouldn't be gone long. I said I would wait. So he paddled off. The canoe was a little bit of a thing, and didn't look safe for one person, let alone two. I was afraid he would get drowned. But he didn't. He paddled off, and I sat down on the bank and waited. It was getting daylight now. I waited a long time, but he didn't come back. I was getting uneasy. I thought maybe he had got drowned. I didn't know what to do. I was afraid to go home and tell the people about it, because I knew they would be mad. I was afraid to stay there, because I was afraid he would get drowned. I was in a fix. events.title: Huck's Anxious Planning and Belated Awakening
detailed_summary: Immediately after the doctor departs, Huck begins to worry about the potential consequences if Tom's leg injury requires extended care.
He fears the doctor might reveal their situation prematurely, thus 'letting the cat out of the bag.'
To prevent this, Huck devises a contingency plan: if the doctor indicates a need for further visits, Huck will swim to the raft.
His plan involves forcibly detaining the doctor, keeping him on the raft downriver until Tom no longer needs medical attention, and then compensating him before releasing him.
Having formulated this drastic plan, Huck seeks rest in a lumber-pile.
He oversleeps significantly, waking to find the sun high in the sky, indicating much time has passed.
Rushing to the doctor's house, Huck learns that the doctor had left sometime during the night and has not yet returned.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I struck an idea pretty soon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I shot out and went for the doctor’s house, but they told me he’d gone away in the night some time or other, and warn’t back yet.

events.text_segment:
I struck an idea pretty soon. I says to myself, spos’n he can’t fix that leg just in three shakes of a sheep’s tail, as the saying is? spos’n it takes him three or four days? What are we going to do?—lay around there till he lets the cat out of the bag? No, sir; I know what I’ll do. I’ll wait, and when he comes back if he says he’s got to go any more I’ll get down there, too, if I swim; and we’ll take and tie him, and keep him, and shove out down the river; and when Tom’s done with him we’ll give him what it’s worth, or all we got, and then let him get ashore.
So then I crept into a lumber-pile to get some sleep; and next time I waked up the sun was away up over my head! I shot out and went for the doctor’s house, but they told me he’d gone away in the night some time or other, and warn’t back yet.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I struck an idea pretty soon.  The doctor he might tell who Tom was, and then somebody'd fetch Aunt Polly, or somebody, to watch around, and Tom'd be ketched, and all our plans smashed up.  You see, I was mighty scared that he'd say something about Tom's leg, and that'd set them belling around and searching.  Well, next, I meditated a bit, and says to myself, I got to do something, and that pretty quick.  Then I doubled up my fists and says, By jings, I would serve him right if he did, by jings!  I'd serve him right.  I'd do his nose a-bleeding for him, by jings.  I would.  And after that I got to thinking better about it.  Says I, it's considerable of a long time for a doctor to be away; he'll get to wondering what's keeping him so long, and he'll send somebody; and then they'll hunt around and find the raft, and I'm as good as jailed.  Then I begun to think of a plan.  I says, I'll wait till he comes back, and then if he ain't going to say nothing, I'll let him alone; but if he's going to say something I'll lay for him and such him, and take the canoe and make for the raft and hide him somewhere where they can't find him.  I says, I'll keep him there till Tom's well, and then I'll let him go.  I says, I'll give him a hundred dollars, and he won't say nothing.  I says, I'll do it.  I says, I'll lay for him. events.title: Unexpected Encounter with Uncle Silas and a New Fabrication
detailed_summary: Feeling that the doctor's prolonged absence bodes ill for Tom, Huck decides to head for the island immediately.
As he sets off, he unexpectedly collides with Uncle Silas.
Caught off guard, Huck, who is known to the Phelpses as 'Tom Sawyer,' quickly invents a new lie to explain his and 'Sid's' (the real Tom Sawyer's) absence.
He claims that he and 'Sid' were out hunting the runaway slave, Jim.
Huck elaborates that they followed the posse, lost them, then pursued sounds on the water by canoe, eventually tying up and falling asleep.

He further states they only woke up about an hour ago, paddled back to hear news, and that 'Sid' is currently at the post-office while he (Huck as 'Tom') is looking for food before they both head home.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, thinks I, that looks powerful bad for Tom, and I’ll dig out for the island right off.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and then we’re going home.”

events.text_segment:
Well, thinks I, that looks powerful bad for Tom, and I’ll dig out for the island right off. So away I shoved, and turned the corner, and nearly rammed my head into Uncle Silas’s stomach! He says:
“Why, Tom! Where you been all this time, you rascal?”
“I hain’t been nowheres,” I says, “only just hunting for the runaway nigger—me and Sid.”
“Why, where ever did you go?” he says. “Your aunt’s been mighty uneasy.”
“She needn’t,” I says, “because we was all right. We followed the men and the dogs, but they outrun us, and we lost them; but we thought we heard them on the water, so we got a canoe and took out after them and crossed over, but couldn’t find nothing of them; so we cruised along up-shore till we got kind of tired and beat out; and tied up the canoe and went to sleep, and never waked up till about an hour ago; then we paddled over here to hear the news, and Sid’s at the post-office to see what he can hear, and I’m a-branching out to get something to eat for us, and then we’re going home.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, thinks I, that looks powerful bad for Tom, and I’ll dig out for the island right off. I didn’t wait any longer than to shed my clothes and slap on my raftsman outfit, and I was overboard and clattering along down the river road in a minute. I was flying down past the church, and I see a nig— a man lumbering along up the road. He was going pretty good for a fat man, I says to myself; yes, he’s a fat man. I begun to slack up, for he was getting close now, and I begun to see he was a big man—long hair all down his back and black. Thinks I, it’s a nigger. Well, I was scared, and I begun to shake, not knowing what to do, but I knowed who it was now. I begun to shake worse than ever, for it was Uncle Silas, and I was coming right towards him, and he might see me and know me. I begun to sidle into the trees till I could think what to do. Then I says to myself, I’ll turn and run the other way, and get to the island that way. But I hadn’t got started yet when he see me. He sung out, “Why, who’s this?” He was tearing along at a astonishing gait. I says, to myself, this won’t do. I got to face it. I can’t get away. I can’t do it. So I says, “It’s me, Uncle Silas.” He come a-lumbering up, and says, “Why, bless my soul! if it ain’t Tom Sawyer! How did you get here?” “Why,” I says, “I come down the river, you know, and I got here about an hour ago.” “Well, I’ll be dod-durned,” he says. “I thought you was in bed, and Sid, too. events.title: Fruitless Search for 'Sid' and Aunt Sally's Relieved Welcome
detailed_summary: Huck and Uncle Silas proceed to the post-office to find 'Sid' (Tom Sawyer), but, as Huck anticipated, he isn't there.
Uncle Silas retrieves a letter from the office.
Despite waiting a while longer, 'Sid' does not appear.
Uncle Silas decides they should return home by riding, telling Huck that 'Sid' can walk or canoe back later.
Huck's attempt to persuade Uncle Silas to let him stay and wait for 'Sid' is unsuccessful; Uncle Silas insists he must come home to reassure Aunt Sally.
Upon their arrival home, Aunt Sally expresses immense relief at seeing Huck (whom she believes to be her nephew Tom), showing her joy through tears, laughter, hugs, and a gentle, symbolic 'licking.'
She mentions that 'Sid' will receive similar treatment upon his return.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So then we went to the post-office to get “Sid”; but just as I suspicioned, he warn’t there; so the old man he got a letter out of the office, and we waited a while longer, but Sid didn’t come; so the old man said, come along, let Sid foot it home, or canoe it, when he got done fooling around—but we would ride.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When we got home Aunt Sally was that glad to see me she laughed and cried both, and hugged me, and give me one of them lickings of hern that don’t amount to shucks, and said she’d serve Sid the same when he come.

events.text_segment:
So then we went to the post-office to get “Sid”; but just as I suspicioned, he warn’t there; so the old man he got a letter out of the office, and we waited a while longer, but Sid didn’t come; so the old man said, come along, let Sid foot it home, or canoe it, when he got done fooling around—but we would ride. I couldn’t get him to let me stay and wait for Sid; and he said there warn’t no use in it, and I must come along, and let Aunt Sally see we was all right.
When we got home Aunt Sally was that glad to see me she laughed and cried both, and hugged me, and give me one of them lickings of hern that don’t amount to shucks, and said she’d serve Sid the same when he come.

events.title: Neighbors' Speculation on Jim's Escape and Aunt Sally's Mounting Hysteria
detailed_summary: The Phelps' house is crowded with local farmers and their wives, all animatedly discussing Jim's escape and the bizarre items found in his cabin.
Old Mrs. Hotchkiss dominates the conversation, vehemently arguing that Jim must have been insane, citing the strange carvings on the grindstone as primary evidence.
Other women, like Mrs. Damrell and Sister Utterback, express bewilderment over the purpose of a rag ladder.
Brer Penrod and others question how the heavy grindstone was moved into the cabin and who dug the hole.
The discussion leads to a consensus that Jim must have had considerable assistance, with speculation on the number of helpers ranging from a dozen to forty.
They marvel at the tedious creation of case-knife saws, the effort to saw off a bed-leg, and the presence of a straw effigy of Jim.
Brother Marples highlights a shirt covered in what he calls 'secret African writ'n' done in blood, expressing a desire to have it deciphered.

Aunt Sally interjects, detailing a long list of stolen household items, from a shirt and sheet to flour, candles, spoons, and even her new calico dress, emphasizing that these thefts occurred despite her family's constant vigilance.
She concludes that spirits must have been involved in Jim's escape, as their highly skilled dogs never even found a trail, challenging anyone to explain it.
The neighbors react with various expressions of shock and fear at the audacity and mystery of the events.
Aunt Sally recounts her extreme fear the previous night, admitting she was so agitated she even locked her 'two poor boys' (Huck as 'Tom', and Tom Sawyer as 'Sid') in their room.
As she finishes speaking and her gaze falls upon Huck, he, realizing the implication of her statement for his earlier fabricated alibi, quietly excuses himself and leaves the room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And the place was plum full of farmers and farmers’ wives, to dinner; and such another clack a body never heard.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I got up and took a walk.

events.text_segment:
And the place was plum full of farmers and farmers’ wives, to dinner; and such another clack a body never heard. Old Mrs. Hotchkiss was the worst; her tongue was a-going all the time. She says:
“Well, Sister Phelps, I’ve ransacked that-air cabin over, an’ I b’lieve the nigger was crazy. I says to Sister Damrell—didn’t I, Sister Damrell?—s’I, he’s crazy, s’I—them’s the very words I said. You all hearn me: he’s crazy, s’I; everything shows it, s’I. Look at that-air grindstone, s’I; want to tell me’t any cretur ’t’s in his right mind ’s a goin’ to scrabble all them crazy things onto a grindstone, s’I? Here sich ’n’ sich a person busted his heart; ’n’ here so ’n’ so pegged along for thirty-seven year, ’n’ all that—natcherl son o’ Louis somebody, ’n’ sich everlast’n rubbage. He’s plumb crazy, s’I; it’s what I says in the fust place, it’s what I says in the middle, ’n’ it’s what I says last ’n’ all the time—the nigger’s crazy—crazy ’s Nebokoodneezer, s’I.”
“An’ look at that-air ladder made out’n rags, Sister Hotchkiss,” says old Mrs. Damrell; “what in the name o’ goodness could he ever want of—”
“The very words I was a-sayin’ no longer ago th’n this minute to Sister Utterback, ’n’ she’ll tell you so herself. Sh-she, look at that-air rag ladder, sh-she; ’n’ s’I, yes, look at it, s’I—what could he a-wanted of it, s’I. Sh-she, Sister Hotchkiss, sh-she—”
“But how in the nation’d they ever git that grindstone in there, anyway? ’n’ who dug that-air hole? ’n’ who—”
“My very words, Brer Penrod! I was a-sayin’—pass that-air sasser o’ m’lasses, won’t ye?—I was a-sayin’ to Sister Dunlap, jist this minute, how did they git that grindstone in there, s’I. Without help, mind you—’thout help! Thar’s wher ’tis. Don’t tell me, s’I; there wuz help, s’I; ’n’ ther’ wuz a plenty help, too, s’I; ther’s ben a dozen a-helpin’ that nigger, ’n’ I lay I’d skin every last nigger on this place but I’d find out who done it, s’I; ’n’ moreover, s’I—”
“A dozen says you!—forty couldn’t a done every thing that’s been done. Look at them case-knife saws and things, how tedious they’ve been made; look at that bed-leg sawed off with ’m, a week’s work for six men; look at that nigger made out’n straw on the bed; and look at—”
“You may well say it, Brer Hightower! It’s jist as I was a-sayin’ to Brer Phelps, his own self. S’e, what do you think of it, Sister Hotchkiss, s’e? Think o’ what, Brer Phelps, s’I? Think o’ that bed-leg sawed off that a way, s’e? think of it, s’I? I lay it never sawed itself off, s’I—somebody sawed it, s’I; that’s my opinion, take it or leave it, it mayn’t be no ’count, s’I, but sich as ’t is, it’s my opinion, s’I, ’n’ if any body k’n start a better one, s’I, let him do it, s’I, that’s all. I says to Sister Dunlap, s’I—”
“Why, dog my cats, they must a ben a house-full o’ niggers in there every night for four weeks to a done all that work, Sister Phelps. Look at that shirt—every last inch of it kivered over with secret African writ’n done with blood! Must a ben a raft uv ’m at it right along, all the time, amost. Why, I’d give two dollars to have it read to me; ’n’ as for the niggers that wrote it, I ’low I’d take ’n’ lash ’m t’ll—”
“People to help him, Brother Marples! Well, I reckon you’d think so if you’d a been in this house for a while back. Why, they’ve stole everything they could lay their hands on—and we a-watching all the time, mind you. They stole that shirt right off o’ the line! and as for that sheet they made the rag ladder out of, ther’ ain’t no telling how many times they didn’t steal that; and flour, and candles, and candlesticks, and spoons, and the old warming-pan, and most a thousand things that I disremember now, and my new calico dress; and me and Silas and my Sid and Tom on the constant watch day and night, as I was a-telling you, and not a one of us could catch hide nor hair nor sight nor sound of them; and here at the last minute, lo and behold you, they slides right in under our noses and fools us, and not only fools us but the Injun Territory robbers too, and actuly gets away with that nigger safe and sound, and that with sixteen men and twenty-two dogs right on their very heels at that very time! I tell you, it just bangs anything I ever heard of. Why, sperits couldn’t a done better and been no smarter. And I reckon they must a been sperits—because, you know our dogs, and ther’ ain’t no better; well, them dogs never even got on the track of ’m once! You explain that to me if you can!—any of you!”
“Well, it does beat—”
“Laws alive, I never—”
“So help me, I wouldn’t a be—”
“House-thieves as well as—”
“Goodnessgracioussakes, I’d a ben afeard to live in sich a—”
“’Fraid to live!—why, I was that scared I dasn’t hardly go to bed, or get up, or lay down, or set down, Sister Ridgeway. Why, they’d steal the very—why, goodness sakes, you can guess what kind of a fluster I was in by the time midnight come last night. I hope to gracious if I warn’t afraid they’d steal some o’ the family! I was just to that pass I didn’t have no reasoning faculties no more. It looks foolish enough now, in the daytime; but I says to myself, there’s my two poor boys asleep, ’way up stairs in that lonesome room, and I declare to goodness I was that uneasy ’t I crep’ up there and locked ’em in! I did. And anybody would. Because, you know, when you get scared that way, and it keeps running on, and getting worse and worse all the time, and your wits gets to addling, and you get to doing all sorts o’ wild things, and by-and-by you think to yourself, spos’n I was a boy, and was away up there, and the door ain’t locked, and you—” She stopped, looking kind of wondering, and then she turned her head around slow, and when her eye lit on me—I got up and took a walk.

And the place was plum full of farmers and farmers’ wives, to dinner; and such another clack a body never heard. Old Mrs. Hotchkiss was a-saying, at one end of the table: “You see, it comes of this kind of bringing up; here’s the law a-standing ready, and able, and willing, to protect your rights, and give you back your property when you’ve lost it; and here’s you, a-permitting yourselves to go and hire your own property out to yourselves to steal, as you may say, and the law a-standing idle, and unbeknown. Why, what did I tell you? I told you that that nigger was crazy—leastways, I told you he was liable to break out any minute, and do awful things. And I told you these things six months ago.”

Old Mrs. Grabbit said: “Lor, it’s awful, awful! Why, it warn’t two hours and a half from the time to-day that he had ‘em again. It was awful!”

“Well, it’s awful, sure enough,” said a farmer; “but I don’t see what you’re going to do with it. There ain’t any way to account for it.”

“Oh, yes, there is a way to account for it,” said old Mrs. Hotchkiss. “He’s crazy, that’s what’s the matter with him.”

“Why, I’ve heard of people’s being crazy before; but I never heard of anybody’s being crazy like that,” said a farmer.

“Well, then, says I, what’s the use of you talking? It’s the only way to account for it, and I’ve accounted for it. There ain’t any other way to account for it.”

“Well, it’s awful, awful, still,” said the farmer.

events.title: Huck's Elaborate Alibi and Aunt Sally's Renewed Anxiety for 'Sid'
detailed_summary: Having slipped away, Huck formulates an explanation for why he and 'Sid' were not in their locked room that morning.
He later returns and tells Aunt Sally that the noise and shooting from Jim's escape woke them.
He claims that, finding their door locked but wanting to see the excitement, they climbed down the lightning rod, both sustaining minor injuries in the process, and resolved never to try it again.
Huck then recounts the fabricated story he had earlier told Uncle Silas about their supposed pursuit of the runaway slave.
Aunt Sally, mollified, forgives them, attributing their actions to the typical harum-scarum nature of boys.
She expresses relief that no real harm came of it and decides to be grateful they are alive and well rather than dwelling on the past.
After a moment of thought, Aunt Sally suddenly realizes with concern that it is almost night and 'Sid' (Tom Sawyer) has still not returned, questioning his whereabouts.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Says I to myself, I can explain better how we come to not be in that room this morning if I go out to one side and study over it a little.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Why, lawsamercy, it’s most night, and Sid not come yet! What has become of that boy?”

events.text_segment:
Says I to myself, I can explain better how we come to not be in that room this morning if I go out to one side and study over it a little. So I done it. But I dasn’t go fur, or she’d a sent for me. And when it was late in the day the people all went, and then I come in and told her the noise and shooting waked up me and “Sid,” and the door was locked, and we wanted to see the fun, so we went down the lightning-rod, and both of us got hurt a little, and we didn’t never want to try that no more. And then I went on and told her all what I told Uncle Silas before; and then she said she’d forgive us, and maybe it was all right enough anyway, and about what a body might expect of boys, for all boys was a pretty harum-scarum lot as fur as she could see; and so, as long as no harm hadn’t come of it, she judged she better put in her time being grateful we was alive and well and she had us still, stead of fretting over what was past and done. So then she kissed me, and patted me on the head, and dropped into a kind of a brown study; and pretty soon jumps up, and says:
“Why, lawsamercy, it’s most night, and Sid not come yet! What has become of that boy?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Says I to myself, I can explain better how we come to not be in that room this morning if I go out to one side and study over it a little. So I went out and hid in the weeds, and thought it all over. When I had it all straight, I went in to see if I could outlick a woman. I judged I could, but it was a close call. I told her all about the row, and was very sorry they got away, but I couldn't help it. I couldn't hear nothing for the racket, and I didn't know they was in trouble till morning. I didn't know what time I got to sleep. I waked up all of a sudden about daylight, and heard them up stairs in a terrible state—one saying it was a judgment, and so on, and you see I begun to understand. I sung out, "What's the trouble?" and they answered, "You've been robbing none of your aunts nor uncles—what's the trouble?" "What do you mean, folks?" says I. "The door's locked, and I hain't been out of this room." Then they told me all about it, and I said it seemed moughty curious to me, I couldn't understand it. But I reckoned maybe I was dreaming when I thought I heard that racket, but anyway, I said, I was going to dress. They asked me if I was hurt. And I said I didn't know, but I would see. I began to dress, and I drownded out what they was saying. But them stairs was right over my head, and every now and then, drat it, I would spill something on them, and they would sing out, "Huck, you's letting on; you knows well you's hurt, cryin' like that. Don't try to hide it from us. It'll do you good to cry. Go right along with it—don't mind us—we'll fetch pap." Well, I couldn't make out what the trouble was, it made a body so cussed mad. I went to the door and sung out, "This ain't no time for fooling around and by-play, folks. You hear me?" They sung out, "O, yes, we hear you. You've been up stairs, and down stairs, and everywheres, this mornin', but if you think we'll stand here and listen to such rubbage, you're mistaken." I said, "Why, how you talk! I hain't been out of this room a minute." "You hain't?" "No, I hain't. I've been asleep the whole time." "Well, you're a sound sleeper, then," says she, and the way she said it, it showed a body it wasn't only just sound sleepin' that was the matter. They was all in a sweat and a worry. Says I, "Why, what's the trouble?" "Trouble?" says she, "ain't it trouble enough for you to be up stairs and down stairs and everywheres, and us locked in, and you a-spilling things on us, and a-crying and a-carrying on like that?" I said, "Why, you must be dreaming. I hain't been out of this room a minute—not since I come in last night." "Well, who was it, then?" "Why, I don't know. But I hain't been out of this room a minute." "Well, then, it was Sid," says she. "No, it warn't Sid. He was asleep in here with me." "Well, then, it was somebody else." "No, it warn't nobody else. I hain't been out of this room a minute." "Well, then, it was you, and that's all there is about it." I said, "Why, I tell you I hain't been out of this room a minute." "Well, then, it was you, and that's all there is about it." I said, "Why, I tell you I hain't been out of this room a minute." "Well, then, it was you, and that's all there is about it." I said, "Why, I tell you I hain't been out of this room a minute." "Well, then, it was you, and that's all there is about it." I said,

She said, she was mighty thankful to see me, and said it warn't no time to be fooling around, because the niggers had got away. I said I knowed that, and I told her how it happened. I said me and Sid was asleep in our room, and when the racket begun, we jumped up and tried to get out, but the door was locked; and we hammered and hammered at it. She said, she didn't hear us. Said it made her head ache just to think about the racket; and she said, if we had got out, she didn't know what we would a done, we would a got killed, sure. I said, no, we wouldn't; we got out. She said, we didn't! It warn't possible. I said, yes; we got out the lightning-rod. She said, did we really? Said, she never heard of such a thing. And she said, if we didn't get killed, it warn't because we didn't try hard to. Said, my heart did ache to hear her say it, and I couldn't help out with a little groan. She said, what was the matter? and I said, I didn't know; but I reckoned it was just a cold. She said, I was a lucky boy, and said no doubt I would get over it if I warn't too much shook up. And she said, was Sid hurt too? and I said, yes, mighty bad. She said, we oughtn't to done it at all. She said, it was awful. I told her, we didn't mean to, but we couldn't help it. Said, we was asleep, and the noise waked us up, and we didn't know what was the matter, and we was scared. I told her, I reckoned we was all right now, though we was a little shook up and sore. She said, she was thankful to hear it, and said, no doubt we would be all right in a day or two. events.title: Growing Concern for 'Sid,' Aunt Sally's Distress, and Huck's Guilt
detailed_summary: Huck quickly offers to go to town and find 'Sid,' seeing an opportunity.
Aunt Sally firmly refuses, stating that one boy lost at a time is enough and that if 'Sid' isn't back by supper, Uncle Silas will go.
When 'Sid' (Tom Sawyer) fails to appear for supper, Uncle Silas departs to search for him.
Uncle Silas returns around ten o'clock, somewhat uneasy, as he couldn't find any trace of 'Tom's track' (referring to Tom Sawyer, currently known as 'Sid').
Aunt Sally becomes considerably more anxious, though Uncle Silas tries to reassure her by saying boys will be boys and 'Sid' will likely turn up in the morning.
Though somewhat pacified, Aunt Sally resolves to stay up for a while and keep a light burning for 'Sid.'
Later, when Huck goes to bed, Aunt Sally accompanies him, tucks him in, and shows him such motherly affection that Huck feels guilty and finds it hard to look at her.
She sits on his bed, talking at length about what a wonderful boy 'Sid' is, repeatedly asking Huck if he thinks 'Sid' could be lost, hurt, or even drowned, her tears falling silently.
Huck reassures her that 'Sid' is fine and will be home in the morning, and she asks him to repeat his assurances, finding comfort in them.

events.text_segment:
I see my chance; so I skips up and says:
“I’ll run right up to town and get him,” I says.
“No you won’t,” she says. “You’ll stay right wher’ you are; one’s enough to be lost at a time. If he ain’t here to supper, your uncle ’ll go.”
Well, he warn’t there to supper; so right after supper uncle went.
He come back about ten a little bit uneasy; hadn’t run across Tom’s track. Aunt Sally was a good deal uneasy; but Uncle Silas he said there warn’t no occasion to be—boys will be boys, he said, and you’ll see this one turn up in the morning all sound and right. So she had to be satisfied. But she said she’d set up for him a while anyway, and keep a light burning so he could see it.
And then when I went up to bed she come up with me and fetched her candle, and tucked me in, and mothered me so good I felt mean, and like I couldn’t look her in the face; and she set down on the bed and talked with me a long time, and said what a splendid boy Sid was, and didn’t seem to want to ever stop talking about him; and kept asking me every now and then if I reckoned he could a got lost, or hurt, or maybe drownded, and might be laying at this minute somewheres suffering or dead, and she not by him to help him, and so the tears would drip down silent, and I would tell her that Sid was all right, and would be home in the morning, sure; and she would squeeze my hand, or maybe kiss me, and tell me to say it again, and keep on saying it, because it done her good, and she was in so much trouble.

events.title: Aunt Sally's Plea, Huck's Internal Conflict, and a Night of Vigil
detailed_summary: As Aunt Sally is about to leave Huck's room, she looks at him gently and earnestly.
She tells 'Tom' (Huck) that the door will not be locked and mentions the window and lightning rod, then pleads with him to be good and not leave, for her sake.
Huck, who desperately wants to go check on the real Tom Sawyer and had fully intended to, feels he cannot leave after her heartfelt request, not even for 'kingdoms.'
His mind is troubled by thoughts of both Aunt Sally and Tom, leading to a restless night's sleep.
Twice during the night, he secretly climbs down the lightning rod and observes Aunt Sally still sitting by her candle in the window, her eyes fixed on the road, tears visible.
Huck wishes he could comfort her but feels helpless, only able to resolve never to cause her further grief.
Waking a third time at dawn, he slides down again to find her still there, asleep in her chair, her head resting on her hand, the candle almost extinguished.

events.text_segment:
And when she was going away she looked down in my eyes so steady and gentle, and says:
“The door ain’t going to be locked, Tom, and there’s the window and the rod; but you’ll be good, won’t you? And you won’t go? For my sake.”
Laws knows I wanted to go bad enough to see about Tom, and was all intending to go; but after that I wouldn’t a went, not for kingdoms.
But she was on my mind and Tom was on my mind, so I slept very restless. And twice I went down the rod away in the night, and slipped around front, and see her setting there by her candle in the window with her eyes towards the road and the tears in them; and I wished I could do something for her, but I couldn’t, only to swear that I wouldn’t never do nothing to grieve her any more. And the third time I waked up at dawn, and slid down, and she was there yet, and her candle was most out, and her old gray head was resting on her hand, and she was asleep.

"Don't ask me, Aunt Sally—I can't it's impossible. I can't get it out of my mind. Don't ask me." "Now, do you want to kill me, Tom?" and she cried. So she got to pleading and pleading, and I didn't say nothing, but stood there, and the tears come into my eyes; and by and by she begun to cry, too; and next minute the less I see the more I couldn't stand it—the more my plans got mixed up with trouble; and next minute, without thinking, I says: "Looky here, Aunt Sally, I'll stay give you my word for it; and I won't budge a foot till Uncle Silas comes back, or I hear from Tom; if he's alive, the river'll fetch him here, or his uncle'll hear of him." Well, I thought him over, and him over, and him over, but couldn't seem to strike no place to harden myself against him, but always fetched up at the soft place, and went mushy every time. events.title: Anxious Wait and Tom's Dramatic Return
detailed_summary: Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally are consumed with worry at the breakfast table, having not heard from Tom.
Uncle Silas remembers he received a letter from the post office the previous day.
Aunt Sally takes the letter and identifies it as being from her sister in St. Petersburg.

Before Aunt Sally can open the letter, a commotion interrupts them: Tom Sawyer arrives on a mattress, carried by several people, accompanied by the old doctor, and Jim, who is in Aunt Sally's calico dress with his hands tied.
Huck, witnessing the scene, quickly conceals the unopened letter.
Aunt Sally initially cries out in fear that Tom is dead.
Upon seeing Tom move his head and mutter, she is overcome with relief that he is alive, though clearly not lucid.
She kisses Tom and then hurries off to prepare a bed, shouting instructions to everyone around her.

events.text_segment:
The old man was uptown again before breakfast, but couldn’t get no track of Tom; and both of them set at the table thinking, and not saying nothing, and looking mournful, and their coffee getting cold, and not eating anything. And by-and-by the old man says:
“Did I give you the letter?”
“What letter?”
“The one I got yesterday out of the post-office.”
“No, you didn’t give me no letter.”
“Well, I must a forgot it.”
So he rummaged his pockets, and then went off somewheres where he had laid it down, and fetched it, and give it to her. She says:
“Why, it’s from St. Petersburg—it’s from Sis.”
I allowed another walk would do me good; but I couldn’t stir. But before she could break it open she dropped it and run—for she see something. And so did I. It was Tom Sawyer on a mattress; and that old doctor; and Jim, in her calico dress, with his hands tied behind him; and a lot of people. I hid the letter behind the first thing that come handy, and rushed. She flung herself at Tom, crying, and says:
“Oh, he’s dead, he’s dead, I know he’s dead!”
And Tom he turned his head a little, and muttered something or other, which showed he warn’t in his right mind; then she flung up her hands, and says:
“He’s alive, thank God! And that’s enough!” and she snatched a kiss of him, and flew for the house to get the bed ready, and scattering orders right and left at the niggers and everybody else, as fast as her tongue could go, every jump of the way.

The old man was uptown again before breakfast, but couldn’t get no track of Tom; and both of them set at the table thinking, and not saying nothing, and looking mournful, and their coffee getting cold, and not eating anything. And by-and-by the old man he looked up and said:
“Looky here, Sally, I got certain reasons to b’lieve he’s up town.”
“I just as good as know he is,” said the old woman. “When did you find it out, Silas?—you ain’t said nothing to me before.”
“Well, I only just a little grain of a second ago spec’lated it out. You see, it’s this way. Supper-time last night all the dogs was up on Main Street barking and going on, and he warn’t nowhere around. Now I know what they was up to; they was trying to chase him off. That’s it. He’s up town somewhere or other.”
“Well, he’s awful foolish, I think. What business has he got to be fooling around uptown when he ought to be home and abed? Now, Silas, what do you reckon they’ll do to him? I got the fidgets, an awful fidgets. Everything’s so awful uncertain, everything’s so awful uncertain.”
“Well, I hain’t got no idee, Sally. But I ain’t uneasy; they’re uncommonly thick people, Sally; they ain’t going to hurt my boy. He’s all right. Spec’late he’s all right. Stuck up somewhere, I judge, and they hain’t got no wind of him yet. He’ll fetch up all right, Sally; he’ll fetch up all right.”
“You ain’t got no good reason to think so, Silas, and you know it.”
“Well, I hain’t got no good reason to think he ain’t all right, Sally, and you know it.”
They sat there thinking and worrying; by-and-by the old man he noticed a white something laying on the floor in the corner, and he says:
“What’s that white thing there, Sally?”
“I don’t know,” says she, “some rubbish the children’s done it, I reckon, high over the house.”
He looked closer, and says:
“No, it ain’t rubbish. It’s a letter. I know it now. Last night I give it to the child to fetch down, and she must a dropped it. It’s for you, Sally. Look at it.”
He reached for it and she snatched it and says:
“Why, it’s from St. Petersburg—it’s from Sis!”
I allowed I better shove out, now, in case somebody was to come, and so I done it and skipped in behind the woodpile. And not five minutes after, here comes about fifteen farmers and one doctor on a pile of mattresses, and they had Tom Sawyer stretched out, and Jim was along, all shackled up with a chain that drawed over his shoulder, and him looking like the deadest sick chicken you ever see, and his eye swelled up like half a biscuit, and his wrist bruised and bandaged. And they had a calico dress on him, and a sunbonnet, and all sorts of trash; and a nigger guard on every side. They come a-swarming around, and the doctor he says:
“Here he is, folks—he’s here—but he ain’t dead. He’s been shot in the leg; but it ain’t broke. He’s just got a little fever, and it ain’t much. He’ll be all right by-and-by. Just let him alone a minute, and don’t pester him; it’ll only make him worse.”
Old Mrs. Hotchkiss she says:
“Is he out of his head?”
“Yes, but it’s only from the fever. He’ll be all right by-and-by.”
“Well, and how’d you come to get him?”
“Why, we tracked him to the raft, and he warn’t there. But we found out where he was laying up, and we went for him. And we got him, and we got the

events.title: Jim's Fate Debated by the Mob
detailed_summary: Huck trails the group of men who have captured Jim, while the doctor and Uncle Silas take Tom inside.
The men are agitated, and some suggest hanging Jim as a warning to other slaves to prevent future escape attempts and the trouble they cause.
Others in the crowd argue against hanging Jim, pointing out that he is not their property and his rightful owner would likely demand financial compensation from them.
The prospect of having to pay for Jim tempers the anger of the most vocal proponents of hanging, as they are typically unwilling to bear such costs.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I followed the men to see what they was going to do with Jim; and the old doctor and Uncle Silas followed after Tom into the house.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So that cooled them down a little, because the people that’s always the most anxious for to hang a nigger that hain’t done just right is always the very ones that ain’t the most anxious to pay for him when they’ve got their satisfaction out of him.

events.text_segment: I followed the men to see what they was going to do with Jim; and the old doctor and Uncle Silas followed after Tom into the house. The men was very huffy, and some of them wanted to hang Jim for an example to all the other niggers around there, so they wouldn’t be trying to run away like Jim done, and making such a raft of trouble, and keeping a whole family scared most to death for days and nights. But the others said, don’t do it, it wouldn’t answer at all; he ain’t our nigger, and his owner would turn up and make us pay for him, sure. So that cooled them down a little, because the people that’s always the most anxious for to hang a nigger that hain’t done just right is always the very ones that ain’t the most anxious to pay for him when they’ve got their satisfaction out of him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I followed the men to see what they was going to do with Jim; and the old doctor and Uncle Silas followed after Tom into the house. The men was very huffy, and some of them wanted to hang Jim for an example to all the other niggers, and make them think twice before they tried to run away for the future. But the others said, no, the law wouldn't allow that; and besides, he warn't their nigger, anyway. He was Mr. Phelps's, or he was old Miss Watson's at the least; it warn't anything to them what become of him. Some of the crowd said that was so, and they allowed they'd swing back to the house and get something to eat, and then go home. But others said, no, it would be a shame to treat a nigger that way that had a white man's blood in him; and besides, he might tell who helped him run away, and then it wouldn't go so good with that person. But the others said, no, you couldn't scare that out of him; he hadn't ever told before, and he wouldn't tell this time. But others said, it might do good for an example. There was a good deal of arguing back and forth, and at last they agreed that the best way was to wait till daylight and see what come of him. So they stood around there, talking and smoking, and I went back to the house and got some breakfast.

I sneaked around the corner and watched. They tied Jim up again, right there in the yard, and put a guard over him. They was mighty mad, cussing and saying he was a runaway nigger and ought to be lynched. It made me sick inside. Then I went back to the house and peeked through the window. The doctor was looking at Tom's leg, and Aunt Sally was crying and wringing her hands. Uncle Silas looked pale and worried. The doctor said the bullet was still in there and it was a bad wound. He said Tom was lucky it didn't hit a bone or an artery. Everybody was talking at once, asking questions, and the house was full of noise and trouble. It was a terrible mess, all because of Tom's crazy notions.

events.title: Jim's Harsh Re-imprisonment and the Doctor's Defense
detailed_summary: Jim endures verbal abuse and some physical blows from the men but remains silent and does not acknowledge Huck.
He is confined to the same cabin as before, now dressed in his own clothes, and is more securely chained to a log, with his hands and both legs also bound.
The men declare that Jim will only receive bread and water until his owner claims him or he is sold at auction.
The escape hole Huck and Tom made is filled in, and a stricter guard routine is established, involving armed farmers at night and a bulldog during the day.
As the men are concluding their efforts, the old doctor arrives and addresses them.
The doctor urges the men not to be unnecessarily harsh with Jim, stating he is not a bad person.
He recounts how, upon finding Tom wounded, he realized he couldn't remove the bullet alone and Tom was too unwell to be left.
Jim, despite being a runaway, voluntarily came forward and provided excellent assistance in caring for Tom.

The doctor explains he was compelled to stay with Tom and Jim throughout the day and night, as he couldn't risk Jim escaping, and Jim proved to be a remarkably faithful and diligent nurse, even though it meant risking his own freedom and despite being clearly exhausted from recent hard work.
He emphasizes Jim's good character and considerable value, noting how Jim was eventually captured while asleep after his tiring vigil.
The doctor concludes by reiterating his positive assessment of Jim.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He ain’t no bad nigger, gentlemen; that’s what I think about him.”

events.text_segment:
They cussed Jim considerble, though, and give him a cuff or two side the head once in a while, but Jim never said nothing, and he never let on to know me, and they took him to the same cabin, and put his own clothes on him, and chained him again, and not to no bed-leg this time, but to a big staple drove into the bottom log, and chained his hands, too, and both legs, and said he warn’t to have nothing but bread and water to eat after this till his owner come, or he was sold at auction because he didn’t come in a certain length of time, and filled up our hole, and said a couple of farmers with guns must stand watch around about the cabin every night, and a bulldog tied to the door in the daytime; and about this time they was through with the job and was tapering off with a kind of generl good-bye cussing, and then the old doctor comes and takes a look, and says:
“Don’t be no rougher on him than you’re obleeged to, because he ain’t a bad nigger. When I got to where I found the boy I see I couldn’t cut the bullet out without some help, and he warn’t in no condition for me to leave to go and get help; and he got a little worse and a little worse, and after a long time he went out of his head, and wouldn’t let me come a-nigh him any more, and said if I chalked his raft he’d kill me, and no end of wild foolishness like that, and I see I couldn’t do anything at all with him; so I says, I got to have help somehow; and the minute I says it out crawls this nigger from somewheres and says he’ll help, and he done it, too, and done it very well. Of course I judged he must be a runaway nigger, and there I was! and there I had to stick right straight along all the rest of the day and all night. It was a fix, I tell you! I had a couple of patients with the chills, and of course I’d of liked to run up to town and see them, but I dasn’t, because the nigger might get away, and then I’d be to blame; and yet never a skiff come close enough for me to hail. So there I had to stick plumb until daylight this morning; and I never see a nigger that was a better nuss or faithfuller, and yet he was risking his freedom to do it, and was all tired out, too, and I see plain enough he’d been worked main hard lately. I liked the nigger for that; I tell you, gentlemen, a nigger like that is worth a thousand dollars—and kind treatment, too. I had everything I needed, and the boy was doing as well there as he would a done at home—better, maybe, because it was so quiet; but there I was, with both of ’m on my hands, and there I had to stick till about dawn this morning; then some men in a skiff come by, and as good luck would have it the nigger was setting by the pallet with his head propped on his knees sound asleep; so I motioned them in quiet, and they slipped up on him and grabbed him and tied him before he knowed what he was about, and we never had no trouble. And the boy being in a kind of a flighty sleep, too, we muffled the oars and hitched the raft on, and towed her over very nice and quiet, and the nigger never made the least row nor said a word from the start. He ain’t no bad nigger, gentlemen; that’s what I think about him.”

It’s for your own good that I say it. Come, I’ll take you home and clean you up.” He talked that way, but nobody paid no attention. Everybody was talking about Jim, and saying he ought to be hung. “Why, doctor,” says one, “you ain’t going to stand there and defend that nigger, be you?—that negro that’s been running off and planning all this mischief?” “Yes, I am going to stand there and defend him,” says the doctor. “The fact is, gentlemen, you are all mistaken about him. Nobody has hurt him. He hasn’t been mistreated, in any way. He’s been good to me, and he’s been kind to Tom, and I ain’t going to see him abused if I can help it.” They all said, “Why, who do you reckon it is?” and somebody said, “It’s the doctor, sure enough!” “Well, doctor,” says one, “what is it? How is Tom?” “He’s better,” says the doctor. “I was afraid the bullet had gone into the bone, but it didn’t. It went clean through. He’ll get well. He’s been shot in the leg, and it’s a bad wound, but he’ll get over it.” “Well, doctor,” says one, “that’s good news. But what about this here nigger? He’s the one that done it. He’s the one that shot Tom.” “No,” says the doctor, “he didn’t shoot Tom. He didn’t do anything. He was with me all the time. He was with me when I found Tom, and he stayed with me all night, and he helped me take care of Tom. He’s a good nigger. He’s a good nigger, and he’s a valuable nigger. He’s worth a thousand dollars, and I wouldn’t take a cent less for him. He’s a good nigger, and he’s a valuable nigger, and he’s a good friend to me, and he’s a good friend to Tom, and I ain’t going to see him abused if I can help it.” They all said, “Well, doctor, that’s events.title: Softened Attitudes and Huck's Anxieties
detailed_summary: A man in the crowd concedes that the doctor's account is compelling.
The other men also seem to soften their attitudes towards Jim, which greatly relieves Huck and confirms his initial good opinion of the doctor.
The group agrees that Jim behaved admirably and deserves acknowledgment, so they all promise to stop cursing him.
Despite these sentiments, Jim is locked up without any lessening of his heavy chains or improvement to his bread-and-water diet.
Huck wishes for better conditions for Jim but feels it is not his place to intervene directly.

He resolves to tell Aunt Sally about the doctor's account of Jim's help and simultaneously worries about the difficult explanations he will soon have to provide regarding his failure to mention "Sid's" gunshot wound when recounting their night adventure hunting for Jim.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence:
Somebody says:
“Well, it sounds very good, doctor, I’m obleeged to say.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they come out and locked him up. I hoped they was going to say he could have one or two of the chains took off, because they was rotten heavy, or could have meat and greens with his bread and water; but they didn’t think of it, and I reckoned it warn’t best for me to mix in, but I judged I’d get the doctor’s yarn to Aunt Sally somehow or other as soon as I’d got through the breakers that was laying just ahead of me—explanations, I mean, of how I forgot to mention about Sid being shot when I was telling how him and me put in that dratted night paddling around hunting the runaway nigger.

events.text_segment:
Somebody says:
“Well, it sounds very good, doctor, I’m obleeged to say.”
Then the others softened up a little, too, and I was mighty thankful to that old doctor for doing Jim that good turn; and I was glad it was according to my judgment of him, too; because I thought he had a good heart in him and was a good man the first time I see him. Then they all agreed that Jim had acted very well, and was deserving to have some notice took of it, and reward. So every one of them promised, right out and hearty, that they wouldn’t cuss him no more.
Then they come out and locked him up. I hoped they was going to say he could have one or two of the chains took off, because they was rotten heavy, or could have meat and greens with his bread and water; but they didn’t think of it, and I reckoned it warn’t best for me to mix in, but I judged I’d get the doctor’s yarn to Aunt Sally somehow or other as soon as I’d got through the breakers that was laying just ahead of me—explanations, I mean, of how I forgot to mention about Sid being shot when I was telling how him and me put in that dratted night paddling around hunting the runaway nigger.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Somebody says: “Well, it sounds very good, doctor, I’m obleeged to say. Considerin’ the source, it sounds very good. I’m obleeged to say that, and I’m obleeged to say, too, that you ain’t the only person that’s ben imposed on in this world. I ain’t the only person that’s ben maligned and slandered. I ain’t the only person that’s ben treated with suspicion and contempt. But I ain’t goin’ to hold it agin you, doctor. No, sir. I forgive you, and I hope you’ll forgive me for bein’ so unfortunate as to fall under your suspicion. It’s a hard thing to bear, the suspicion of an honest man, but I’ll bear it. I’ll bear it for the sake of my poor, dear departed brother, Peter Wilks, whose memory I honor and whose wishes I mean to carry out to the letter. I stand here before you all, a poor, broken-hearted old man, come from across the ocean to do my duty by my kin. I ask you, good people, look at me. Do I look like a man who would cheat and lie? Do I look like a man who would steal from orphans? I appeal to your hearts, to your sense of justice. Judge me by my actions, not by the venomous words of one who, for reasons unknown to me, seeks to destroy my good name and bring sorrow upon this already grief-stricken household. events.title: Tom's Awakening and Grand Confession
detailed_summary: Huck notes that he has ample time to prepare his explanations, as Aunt Sally is constantly by Tom's side in the sick-room, and Huck manages to avoid encountering Uncle Silas.
The following morning, Huck learns Tom is significantly better and Aunt Sally has gone to take a nap.
He slips into the sick-room, hoping that if Tom is awake, they can devise a believable story for the family.
He finds Tom sleeping peacefully, his appearance much improved.
Aunt Sally quietly enters the room, motions for Huck to be still, and whispers her joy that Tom's symptoms are excellent and he appears to be recovering well.
They sit and watch Tom, who eventually stirs and opens his eyes, recognizing he is at home.
Tom immediately asks about the raft and then about Jim.
Huck confirms Jim is also there, though his tone is somewhat subdued, which Tom doesn't notice.
Tom, assuming their plan was a complete success, exclaims that they are all safe and asks Huck if he has told Aunt Sally about it.
When Aunt Sally inquires what Tom means, he proudly announces that he and "Sid" (Huck) were responsible for freeing Jim.
Aunt Sally is shocked and exclaims that Tom must be out of his head again.

Tom insists he is perfectly lucid and proceeds to give a lengthy, enthusiastic account of their entire elaborate scheme: the weeks of work, stealing supplies like candles and clothes, making tools and inscriptions, digging into the cabin, dealing with rats and snakes, and the final chaotic escape attempt where he was shot, culminating in his belief that Jim was now a free man thanks to their efforts.

events.text_segment:
But I had plenty time. Aunt Sally she stuck to the sick-room all day and all night, and every time I see Uncle Silas mooning around I dodged him.
Next morning I heard Tom was a good deal better, and they said Aunt Sally was gone to get a nap. So I slips to the sick-room, and if I found him awake I reckoned we could put up a yarn for the family that would wash. But he was sleeping, and sleeping very peaceful, too; and pale, not fire-faced the way he was when he come. So I set down and laid for him to wake. In about half an hour Aunt Sally comes gliding in, and there I was, up a stump again! She motioned me to be still, and set down by me, and begun to whisper, and said we could all be joyful now, because all the symptoms was first-rate, and he’d been sleeping like that for ever so long, and looking better and peacefuller all the time, and ten to one he’d wake up in his right mind.
So we set there watching, and by-and-by he stirs a bit, and opened his eyes very natural, and takes a look, and says:
“Hello!—why, I’m at home! How’s that? Where’s the raft?”
“It’s all right,” I says.
“And Jim?”
“The same,” I says, but couldn’t say it pretty brash. But he never noticed, but says:
“Good! Splendid! Now we’re all right and safe! Did you tell Aunty?”
I was going to say yes; but she chipped in and says: “About what, Sid?”
“Why, about the way the whole thing was done.”
“What whole thing?”
“Why, the whole thing. There ain’t but one; how we set the runaway nigger free—me and Tom.”
“Good land! Set the run— What is the child talking about! Dear, dear, out of his head again!”
“No, I ain’t out of my HEAD; I know all what I’m talking about. We did set him free—me and Tom. We laid out to do it, and we done it. And we done it elegant, too.” He’d got a start, and she never checked him up, just set and stared and stared, and let him clip along, and I see it warn’t no use for me to put in. “Why, Aunty, it cost us a power of work—weeks of it—hours and hours, every night, whilst you was all asleep. And we had to steal candles, and the sheet, and the shirt, and your dress, and spoons, and tin plates, and case-knives, and the warming-pan, and the grindstone, and flour, and just no end of things, and you can’t think what work it was to make the saws, and pens, and inscriptions, and one thing or another, and you can’t think half the fun it was. And we had to make up the pictures of coffins and things, and nonnamous letters from the robbers, and get up and down the lightning-rod, and dig the hole into the cabin, and made the rope ladder and send it in cooked up in a pie, and send in spoons and things to work with in your apron pocket—”
“Mercy sakes!”
“—and load up the cabin with rats and snakes and so on, for company for Jim; and then you kept Tom here so long with the butter in his hat that you come near spiling the whole business, because the men come before we was out of the cabin, and we had to rush, and they heard us and let drive at us, and I got my share, and we dodged out of the path and let them go by, and when the dogs come they warn’t interested in us, but went for the most noise, and we got our canoe, and made for the raft, and was all safe, and Jim was a free man, and we done it all by ourselves, and wasn’t it bully, Aunty!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
But I had plenty time. Aunt Sally she stuck to the sick-room all day and all night, and every time I see Uncle Silas mooning around I dodged him. I warn’t afraid of him; but I was afraid she would say something about the prick that busted in my leg, and then he would start for me. So I didn’t wish to see him or anybody else at the time, and I didn’t. 
The next morning I waked up late, and knowed I was feeling pretty good, all considering. So I got up and went down stairs, and see Aunt Sally in the dining-room. She looked glad to see me, and says:
“Well, sakes alive, I clean forgot you, Sid! Why, what has become of you?”
“I hain’t been feeling very well, Aunt Sally, and I laid up.”
“Lay up, sakes alive, what on airth for? The doctor said there warn’t nothing the matter.”
“Well, it didn’t make no difference what the doctor said; I was feeling just that way, anyways, and so I laid up.”
“Why, what was the matter with you, Sid? Say!”
“Oh, not much. I just felt creaky and crawly and spiritless, and mean, and so I laid up.”
“Well, you old stump, I think you’ve been laying for a hiding! and you’ll get it, too. I hain’t cleaned out the stable yet. Come, stir yourself.”
With that she lit into me, and give me a most sound cussing. I got a little worried myself. By and by she says:
“Don’t stand there all day. What’s the matter with you? GO to bed? That’s what you better do. You ain’t looked right, ever since you come. Now you look worse. Old Mr. Brandish he come down last night, and he says you look like you was just from the sperrit-world. Lay down and stay down.”
I done it. I didn’t offer to say nothing; but just laid down, for I was feeling that way. I don’t know whether it was all on account of the doctor not saying anything about my leg when he was there, but I had had a good rest, and I knowed my conscience felt easy, and so I didn’t take it hard. If he had ’a’ said anything I would ’a’ got the fidgets and worried myself into the fever. I laid there till after dinner. Then I begun to feel better. Aunt Sally come in with a couple of apples and some doughnuts, and says:
“Don’t you want to set up and eat a bite, Sid? How do you feel now?”
“I feel better, Aunt Sally. I ain’t going to get the fever, I reckon.”
“When Tom’s well enough to be around, we’ll give you a hiding. That will do you good,” she says. 
“What did he say?”
“Nothing.”
“Well, then, what did you say?”
“Tell you? Why, he said he’d got all that iron by him, and he’d got it all out of Uncle Silas’s blacksmith shop, and he had swiped the bed-sheet and the shirt and the rags and the candle and the sugar and the gourd and the tin plate, and he had stole the spoon, and he had broke into the cabin with it, and he had writ with his blood, and he had dug the hole with the spoon, and he had broke out with it, and we had dug the ditch, and we had done it all, and they hadn’t been no Jim there at all! And besides, he said he had wrote the letters and stuck them on the fence, and they was all lies. And I told him he was crazy, and he said he warn’t, and I said he was, and he said he warn’t, and said he’d prove it. Then he told me all about the rats and the snakes, and how he had bit a snake himself and been bit by the rats, and how he got the rats and the snakes into the cabin, and how he got the leg-chain on Jim’s leg, and how they was going to saw it off, and how he had got the saw, and how Jim was a free man the minute he was out of the cabin and we was out of the ditch, and he was going to march Jim down to the river and put him on the raft and shove off and go down the river to New Orleans, and Jim would be all right and free forever and ever. And I told him he was crazy, and he said he warn’t, and I said he was, and he said he warn’t, and said he’d prove it. And he said we had done it all, and they hadn’t been no Jim there at all! And besides, he said he had wrote the letters and stuck them on the fence, and they was all lies. And I told him he was crazy, and he said he warn’t, and I said he was, and he said he warn’t, and said he’d prove it.
